The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported casualties in Aleppo due to barrel bomb attacks, while the Syrian government denied bombarding civilian areas. The government also denied reports of rebels seizing most of Aleppo's central prison, though the situation remains uncertain. Russia has set a deadline for the transfer of Syria's chemical weapons to be completed by 1 March, with all weapons to be destroyed by the end of June. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) has acknowledged that security concerns have slowed down the process.</s>

The Man Booker Prize shortlist for 2014 includes Mukherjee's The Lives of Others, a sweeping account of life in 1960s Calcutta, which is the 5/2 favorite to win with bookmakers William Hill. This is the first year the prize is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night. Other authors on the shortlist include former Booker winner Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler, and Richard Flanagan.</s>

A celebrity, referred to as PJS, is appealing against a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban on him being named in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will hear arguments about whether to grant an appeal and decide if it should be allowed or dismissed. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish an account of alleged extra-marital activities by PJS, but he argues he has a right to privacy. The Court of Appeal judges said the celebrity had "occasional sexual encounters" with another person, referred to as AB, starting in 2009. The judges ruled that PJS was now unlikely to be able to get a permanent injunction as the details about the allegations were now "so widespread" that confidentiality had "probably been lost".</s>

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1, was purchased for £345.5m in August. The new owners are planning improvements to parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of units. They have met with Blaby District Council to address potential planning questions. The owners aim to enhance the park's appearance as it serves as the gateway from Blaby into the city. Crown Estates, the new owners, are focused on addressing parking and congestion issues and improving the quality of common areas and facilities to make Fosse Park as good as it can be.</s>

The film "Beauty and the Beast" sparked controversy in Malaysia due to its "gay moment." Although the Malaysian Censorship Board approved the film with a minor edit, the release date has not been announced. The live-action remake received a "P13 parental guidance classification." Local cinema chains have offered refunds for customers who purchased tickets in advance. The "gay moment" involves LeFou, the sidekick of the film's main antagonist Gaston, who struggles with feelings for Gaston. The decision to review the film in Malaysia received criticism from netizens.</s>

Landlords in Southampton must obtain a license for Houses of Multiple Occupation (HMO) if they rent to more than three unrelated people, but many avoid this due to the £1,000 license cost, despite facing fines up to £20,000. Southampton City Council estimates 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Shelter helpline adviser Nadeem Khan said tenants often fear eviction and live in poorly maintained properties. Mandatory licensing for HMOs nationally applies to houses with three or more stories and occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, licenses affect specific areas and have been introduced in two designations since 2013 and 2015. The council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for not obtaining licenses.</s>

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny and Micheál Martin aim to prevent a second election by forming a minority government. However, they disagree on water charges, with Fianna Fáil advocating for removal and Fine Gael supporting their role. A commission to consider the future of Irish Water is being considered as a proposal. After the election, Fine Gael had 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and the Labour Party 7, but no party could form a majority government, and a Taoiseach has not been elected.</s>

The Sorrento, a ferry traveling to Valencia, caught fire and quickly escalated, forcing passengers to evacuate onto lifeboats. They were later rescued by another ship. At least three people were injured and taken to the hospital. The fire started on one of the car decks, and the cause is unknown. Several ships, including two passenger ferries, assisted in the rescue. The passengers boarded the Puglia ferry and were en route to Palma de Mallorca. Psychologists were requested to provide counseling at the port. The Sorrento may sink due to the fire, and the ferry's owner, Atlantica di Navigazione, sent out distress signals. The captain initially believed the ship could be saved, but the fire became too intense, leading to a full evacuation.</s>

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs had identified cases of people, including students, voting twice, which is a criminal offense. The watchdog suggested that individual electoral registers should be better connected to help identify duplicate entries. A record number of 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the 8 June election, with 68.7% voting on the day. Concerns over duplicate applications persist, as there is no direct link between electoral registers and the online registration service. The watchdog recommended clearer information on registration sites and a verification function, similar to that used in Australia, New Zealand, and the Republic of Ireland.</s>

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player and University of Nebraska star, killed himself in prison at the age of 40. He had a troubled past, both on and off the field, and was serving a 30-year sentence for assault convictions. Recently, he was accused of killing his cellmate and was about to face trial for another inmate's death. Despite his intelligence and some positive qualities, Phillips struggled with anger issues and could not overcome the challenges in his life.</s>

Lance Corporal Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted for good behavior at an event in Chester. He is the 30th mascot in a line dating back to the Indian Mutiny War and joined the regiment in 2014. Derby XXX has his own army number, gets paid for rations, and takes holidays during the mating season. He has participated in events such as switching on Christmas lights and meeting Prince William at a memorial unveiling.</s>

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory against Borussia Dortmund, moving closer to earning a place in the Champions League. The match was played at Anfield, with Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp's passionate touchline demeanour and the young coach Thomas Tuchel from Borussia Dortmund. The win showcased the transition from doubt to belief within Liverpool, both on and off the pitch. The match was filled with emotion, drama, and brilliant football, with Liverpool's Dejan Lovren scoring the winning goal in injury time.</s>

The EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee met in London, where Mr. Davis stated that the UK government would keep Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed about negotiations. Mr. Russell called for transparency from the UK government and emphasized the importance of single market membership for Scotland's economic prosperity. Mr. Davis proposed monthly meetings to share analysis and views with the devolved administrations as the Westminster government prepares talks with Brussels. The Scottish government plans to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court during the appeal of the High Court judgment on Article 50.</s>

The passage describes a group of 13 cloned sheep, including four identical twin sisters of Dolly the sheep, living on a University of Nottingham farm. These sheep are undergoing extensive physical examinations and tests to determine if cloning causes premature aging and related health issues. The results of the study could have significant implications for the future of cloning.</s>

The passage discusses a horse race where the unbeaten 4-7 favorite, Shutter Speed, won and will be going to Chantilly next instead of the Oaks at Epsom. Trainer John Gosden has other top contenders, Enable and Coronet, for the Oaks. Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes, and Gosden is concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes.</s>

The passage discusses the volatility of the pound sterling in the context of the Brexit referendum. The currency initially fell against the dollar and euro but recovered before falling again. The "volatility index" reached levels last seen during the 2008 financial crisis. The Leave campaign argued that the pound's decline was due to it returning to March levels. Investors were concerned about the chances of a Remain vote and global economic worries. Two weekend polls showed the Leave camp ahead, and the implied probability of a vote to Remain fell. The outcome of the referendum is expected to cause further volatility in the pound. The FTSE 100 ended the day down 1.1%, while Asian stock markets also experienced a decline. Nigel Farage argued that a weaker pound was beneficial for UK exporters, as it had led to a narrowing of the UK trade deficit in April.</s>

The Iron are currently sixth in the National League, just outside the play-off spots. They faced a challenging match against a strong Barrow team, conceding a goal early on. Despite the loss, Cowley remains positive about their performance and the team's potential in their toughest challenge yet.</s>

The passage discusses the controversial move of putting politicians in charge of most planning decisions in Northern Ireland, starting from April 2015. Currently, the Planning Service makes the final decision on applications, but from the mentioned date, councils will have the authority to accept or reject developments in their areas. Michael Corr, creative director of Northern Ireland's architecture and planning centre, PLACE, sees this as a positive move and an opportunity for local councils to develop their communities. However, environmental group Friends of the Earth express concerns about the potential for discrimination and unfairness in the handling of planning matters, as well as the close relationships between developers and political parties. They argue for the importance of transparency and disclosure of political donations.</s>

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times, twice in the shoulder and once in its left back leg, which had to be amputated. The Scottish SPCA deemed the cat "incredibly lucky" to survive and called for the implementation of air gun licensing to prevent further incidents. Last year, the Scottish government held a consultation on licensing air weapons, but a majority of responders opposed the plan.</s>

Belgium international Christian Benteke has joined Liverpool as their second most expensive signing on a long-term contract. Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Aston Villa, was triggered to join Liverpool after they sold Raheem Sterling to Manchester City for £49m. Liverpool struggled for goals last season and manager Brendan Rodgers has added Benteke to revive the team's attack.</s>

The study commissioned by education technology charity Tablets for Schools found no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using tablet devices. However, tablets are being used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with the highest use in academy schools. The number of tablet computers in schools is expected to rise from about 430,000 to almost 900,000 between 2014 and 2016. While researchers could not isolate the impact of technology as the specific cause of a rise in attainment, head teachers reported a positive impact and suggested that tablets help motivate disengaged pupils and increase family involvement.</s>

The Growing Up in the City exhibition at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs spanning over 100 years, showcasing the lives of children and the social history of Liverpool. The images, curated by Kay Jones, range from the 1880s to the 1990s and depict various aspects of childhood, including play, work, and special occasions. The exhibition runs until September 25th.</s>

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has left Barrow to join National League rivals and may play against his former club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, was recommended to Gulls boss Nicholson and is awaiting international clearance. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.</s>

The passage discusses a new law in Bolivia that allows 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, aiming to address the country's extreme poverty. The law also imposes harsher punishments for violence against children, including a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. Despite the International Labour Organization's recommendation against child labor, the Bolivian government believes this law will help eradicate poverty in the country. The ILO is currently studying the legislation to determine if it violates international regulations on child labor.</s>

A 50-year-old actress experienced a "widow maker" heart attack after helping a woman in her village. She searched for symptoms online, took aspirin, and visited a cardiologist who inserted a stent into a nearly blocked artery. The actress, who has acted in several films and TV shows, warned women to know the symptoms and call 911.</s>

A 17-year-old boy named Che Labastide-Wellington was fatally stabbed at a party in Kenton, London, after a fight with a group of youths who tried to gain entry. He was later targeted in an alleyway. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and remains in stable condition. Police have arrested a 21-year-old man, two boys aged 15 and 16, and a 14-year-old boy in connection with the incident.</s>

The Danish health system reorganized patient diagnosis by GPs and specialists to address cancer cases that are not initially obvious. This change was prompted by alarming cancer survival statistics 15 years ago, showing Denmark performing poorly compared to other European countries. The new model has three routes: fast-track diagnosis and treatment for patients with alarm symptoms, diagnosis centers for patients with symptoms GPs cannot diagnose, and "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms. The changes have not led to an increase in GP referrals but better organization of patient diagnosis within existing resources and improved survival rates. Wales and Denmark, with similar health systems, can share lessons on better organization to improve cancer care.</s>

The passage discusses the transfer of estate agent regulation from the disbanded OFT to Powys, which will receive £170,000 annually for this role. Powys will issue warnings and banning orders against dishonest agents and enforce the Estate Agents Act. Local authority trading standards departments will still handle complaints but may refer cases to Powys if the Act is breached. James Munro from Powys council hopes this new role will lead to more contracts and outside work for the council.</s>

The NHS Employers has approved a plan to expand the roles of support staff, such as nurses and pharmacists, after a Nuffield Trust review found they could handle additional tasks with more training. The review highlighted examples of areas already experimenting with this approach. The report suggests that reshaping the workforce could improve patient care and provide staff with more rewarding roles. However, unions warn against using it as a quick fix for problems in the NHS and emphasize the need for proper funding for training courses.</s>

A crash occurred at Lower Bristol Road in Bath, causing the closure of the A36 road and disruption to commuters and bus services. The road was reopened at 14:00 GMT, and investigations are ongoing. First services resumed with a normal schedule, with the managing director expressing gratitude for public support and staff efforts.</s>

The passage discusses a dispute between NRW and Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) regarding the potential impact of a proposed tidal lagoon project on fish populations. NRW estimates that 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout would die annually due to the lagoon, while TLP claims these figures have no clear scientific basis and cites their own expert computer modeling, which estimates a worst-case scenario of 2% fish mortality. The £1.3bn Swansea tidal lagoon project is being considered by UK government ministers, and Wales' Environment Secretary Lesley Griffiths supports the scheme but calls for clarity on the UK government's position. NRW disagrees with TLP's criticism and maintains confidence in their methodology and evidence.</s>

The passage discusses the announcement of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body in Northern Ireland, which aims to provide strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities of both government and private sector organizations. The marketing body will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB) and is similar to the successful Scotland Food and Drink initiative. The agri-food industry is considered hugely important in Northern Ireland, with almost 100,000 jobs involved in farming, fishing, retail, and distribution. The establishment of this new body is seen as a positive step towards better coordination of marketing activities in the region.</s>

The Woodland Trust is organizing a tree planting project at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, one of four new woods being created across the UK. The project aims to plant millions of native UK trees to commemorate the millions of people who died during WW1. In Brackfield Wood, 40,000 trees will be planted in tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The trust is inviting local people and visitors to participate in the tree planting, providing saplings and advising volunteers to wear appropriate footwear. The project aims to create a space where wildlife will thrive and people can walk, relax, and reflect.</s>

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her book "Someone Else's Skin," which features Det Insp Marnie Rome and tackles domestic violence and honor crime. Radio Times TV editor Alison Graham praised the book as "emotionally exhausting and powerful." US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honor for her 23-year career writing about female private investigator VI Warshawski and for founding Sisters In Crime, an organization supporting female crime writers.</s>

The passage discusses Santner, a 24-year-old cricket player who broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire County in 2016. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes mentions the impact of Santner's injury on the team's chances of qualifying. Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner, made his Test debut in 2015 and will rejoin the Rapids after June's ICC Trophy. He expresses excitement about returning to Worcester and making up for lost time. In August, Worcestershire signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.</s>

In 2008, Barry Pring was killed by a speeding car while attempting to hail a taxi on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway in Kiev. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, had left him momentarily to retrieve a missing glove. The coroner at Exeter County Hall, Dr. Elizabeth Earland, recorded a verdict of unlawful killing. Although much of the evidence was circumstantial, Dr. Earland stated that it was overwhelming and that Barry had been unlawfully killed. Close friend Peter Clifford, a lawyer, also expressed his belief that Barry was murdered. Ganna Ziuzina, who was 19 years younger than her husband, tried to claim his assets within days of his death. Barry's family believes she was involved in his death to inherit his money and property. The Ukrainian police initially closed the inquiry into his death but relaunched it in 2011 as a murder inquiry, which remains active but not actively pursued.</s>

Sophie Fearns shared that her son Charlie, from Merseyside, requires experimental T-Cell Therapy in Seattle, America, as the last transplant in the UK failed. A generous anonymous donor paid for the treatment, leaving the family overwhelmed and grateful. Charlie has been ill since age three, and the treatment will begin as soon as possible at Seattle Children's Hospital.</s>

Apple has implemented new security measures to prevent third-party software from stealing intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud. The two-step verification system, which was previously offered, now comes into play when device owners use the firm's back-up service. This change guards against the technique used in the recent hacks, and Apple plans to more aggressively encourage people to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.</s>

The passage discusses a potential deal in which Wright may buy 20% of Billericay football club, with him possibly becoming a club director. The club is currently in the eighth position in the Isthmian League Premier Division and has recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin. The club also signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March.</s>

Mr. Ashley was asked to give evidence about the treatment of his workers at a Derbyshire company, following a BBC investigation. He has until March 21 to respond to a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright. Mr. Ashley invited the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, chaired by Mr. Wright, to a meeting at the company's base in Shirebrook. The committee plans to review the treatment of low-paid workers and enforcement of the national minimum wage. Several alternative dates were offered for the meeting, but Mr. Ashley has not accepted any. If he fails to agree on a date, the committee may take further action, including seeking support from the House of Commons. Sports Direct has not commented on the matter and has previously pledged to review worker rights with oversight by Mr. Ashley, who also owns Newcastle United Football Club.</s>

The passage discusses a report titled "Putin. War," which accuses President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for his own ends. The report, based on facts from Russian and foreign media, claims that Russian soldiers and equipment were crucial to pro-Russian rebels' victories in Donetsk and Luhansk. It presents evidence of volunteer soldiers admitting that Russian generals, not separatists, directed the main battles in eastern Ukraine. The report also documents names and numbers of military units and photos of weaponry. However, the opposition's report may face challenges in publishing and distribution, as well as gaining public interest.</s>

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire with head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield and are in police custody.</s>

The passage discusses the disagreement between the Welsh First Minister, Carwyn Jones, and the UK government regarding the drafting of the Article 50 letter. Jones claims that he and other devolved administrations were not given the opportunity to contribute to the letter's content, which he finds unacceptable. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defends the UK government's actions, stating that they have been in discussion about the letter's contents for months. The passage also raises questions about which powers will be devolved to Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, and whether there will be funding to accompany these powers after 2020.</s>

Two cars were damaged in an incident in Newry on Friday night, with Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressing his disgust at the attacks on police officers and the community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page urged parents to keep track of their children's activities during the incident.</s>

Mr. Charney, the founder of American Apparel, was ousted last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds. The board filed a court document stating they don't expect him to return to the firm. In response to Mr. Charney's defamation lawsuit, the court filing reveals evidence of inappropriate emails and racially offensive comments. The company claims he violated their sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy, making it unlikely for any board to hire him. Recently, American Apparel obtained a restraining order preventing him from making negative statements about the company and attempting to remove board members.</s>

The passage discusses an upcoming basketball game between Great Britain and Greece, which will be held at the Copper Box in London. The game will be broadcasted on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. Greece won their previous match in Patras, but three key players will be missing, giving GB a chance for revenge. This game is part of GB's preparation for the EuroBasket 2017 tournament, with their only other home game before that being this match against Greece.</s>

The passage describes the introduction of the iPhone and its impact on technology and society. The author recalls attending the iPhone launch event and being able to handle the device before its release. The iPhone revolutionized the way people used their phones, making powerful computers accessible to billions and changing the way we think about activities like photography. The passage also acknowledges the innovations of other companies like Amazon and Google, but emphasizes the significance of the iPhone as the beginning of the mobile connected era.</s>

Five cats in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have died after ingesting antifreeze, with the most recent case being a seven-month-old cat named Meereen. The RSPCA is investigating whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and urges residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, especially during the time when people use antifreeze in their cars.</s>

The Syriza government in Greece is set to agree to more austerity and liberalisation measures, despite its previous opposition to such policies. Athens airport expects 25 million arrivals this year, and tourists may be visiting Greece to avoid areas controlled by the Islamic State. Greeks are not protesting these measures, possibly due to the country's near-death experience in July, which forced the government to accept the measures as the only alternative. Despite the unpopularity of these policies, Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras remains popular. The new bailout deal will only work if creditors ease Greece's unsustainably large debts, which may require debt forgiveness.</s>

Ross Kemp, who last played Grant Mitchell in 2006, is returning to EastEnders for a brief appearance to reunite the Mitchell family as Barbara's character is killed off due to her cancer. Dame Barbara returned to the show recently and announced her character's death. Grant Mitchell is a memorable character from the soap's 30-year history and his return will bring him back to Walford to say goodbye to his mother and reunite with his brother Phil and old loves.</s>

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles in October. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, were informed by Northumbria Police officers. Dhillon had become obsessed with the 24-year-old and had stalked her. Dr. Hills felt guilt for reassuring Alice that the police were aware of the situation and that if she ignored Dhillon, he would ignore her. Alice's parents have set up the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness of the dangers of stalking. Dhillon denied murder but was found guilty and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years.</s>

The French firm EDF has approved the funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point project in Somerset, with contracts set to be signed on Friday. However, the UK Business Secretary Greg Clark has said the government will "consider carefully" before backing the project. Critics have raised concerns about environmental damage, escalating costs, and the involvement of foreign governments, as one third of the cost is being provided by Chinese investors. The UK government has launched a further review of the project, causing uncertainty for the project's future.</s>

The newly-designed divorce application form in England and Wales includes a section asking for the name of the person the spouse has committed adultery with. Family lawyers express concern that this may increase conflict and complexity in cases. The Ministry of Justice states that there is no obligation to name the third party, but the inclusion of the section may lead individuals to fill it in. The online form has been updated to make the legal process more user-friendly, particularly for those completing it without legal advice.</s>

The passage discusses the challenges faced by the forestry industry in Wales, as ministers emphasize environmental aspects over timber production. Since 2001, 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost and need replanting. The industry is worth over £450m a year to the Welsh economy but faces conflicts with environmental policies. The Welsh government aims for a balance between environmental, economic, and social aspects in forestry development, with schemes like Glastir encouraging woodland planting. However, Confor, a forestry promotion organization, argues that the current system is too bureaucratic and that 90 hectares planted last year fall short of the 20,000 hectares needed annually to meet long-term targets.</s>

A boy was severely injured after being hit in Coatbridge on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School around 16:40. He was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is considered serious.</s>

Captain Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to the men of the Arctic Convoys, who resupplied the Soviet Union during World War II. The Foreign Office initially did not allow Russia to honor the veterans, but an exception was made. The Arctic Convoys faced constant threats from German U-boats and aircraft, severe cold, storms, and ice floes, resulting in the loss of thousands of lives. The Ushakov medal is awarded to sailors who have displayed courage in defending Russia or its interests.</s>

The HM Inspectorate of Probation found delays and inefficiencies in the unpaid work program for offenders, with many being let off if they did not attend. The Ministry of Justice is acting on the report's recommendations. Unpaid work, or "community payback," is given for offenses like shoplifting, theft, drug offenses, and criminal damage. In 2014, 70,000 offenders were ordered to do unpaid work such as garden maintenance, decorating, or litter-picking. The report outlined 15 recommendations for improvement, including reducing the number of offenders turned away from work and creating objectives that match the offender's circumstances. The chief inspector of probation, Paul Wilson, called for urgent remedial action, and the Ministry of Justice said it wanted more effective rehabilitation and is taking action to implement the recommendations.</s>

The passage discusses the accusation of hypocrisy against a comedian who campaigns for economic and political revolution to help poorer people but lives in a luxury home. The comedian, known for his vlogs called "The Trews," has been asked about his own accommodation in the past. He has acknowledged the hypocrisy charge and believes in personal change and sharing wealth, but also recognizes the need for systemic change. The comedian has faced criticism for his wealth and lifestyle, but continues to advocate for addressing economic disparity and ecological disaster.</s>

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated the human genome mapping process and created a competitive race in the scientific community. He founded the J. Craig Venter Institute, which published details of Synthia, the first synthetic life form, in the journal Science. Dr. Venter's determination and innovative approach in molecular biology led to breakthroughs in gene sequencing and the first complete genome of a free-living organism. Despite controversy, his work has the potential to revolutionize industries and help combat environmental issues.</s>

The passage states that researchers found that 80% of children in England who ate school lunches had tried food at school that they had not tried at home. A survey of about 1,000 parents revealed that the most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least popular. The School Food Trust commissioned the research after a Mumsnet survey suggested some parents gave their children packed lunches because they thought they were too fussy to eat anything else. The passage also mentions that school meals in England now have to comply with strict nutritional guidelines, and about four in 10 primary school children in England eat school lunches.</s>

The passage discusses Spanish footballer Morata, who joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid. His move included an option for Real to buy him back for up to 30 million euros. Morata has scored three goals for Spain at Euro 2016 and 27 goals for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He also played in two Champions League finals, scoring in one. Morata began his career at Real Madrid, making his first team debut at 18 and scoring 10 goals for the La Liga side.</s>

Wilson, a 30-year-old football player, rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013, making 51 appearances during his second spell at the club. He previously spent four seasons at Forest, as well as playing for Preston North End and Notts County. Wilson was released in May and is currently without a team.</s>

The British supermarket giant Tesco is selling its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, to private equity firm Yucaipa. Around 4,000 employees will transfer to the new business, while Tesco will loan it £80m. Fresh & Easy has lost money since opening in 2007, and Tesco will incur a £150m cost to dispose of the brand. If Yucaipa makes the business profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake.</s>

The passage discusses an individual who faced racial abuse but overcame it, considered representing France in martial arts, and is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. The passage also mentions a special guide on how to get into martial arts.</s>

The passage discusses the significant decrease in glacier coverage in the French Alps between the late 1960s/early 1970s and the late 2000s. The area of ice has fallen from approximately 375 sq km to 275 sq km. The research, presented at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting, was conducted by Marie Gardent and colleagues from the University of Savoie. They assessed around 600 glaciers in various massifs, including the Mont Blanc Massif. The retreat is not uniform across the French Alps, with the greatest losses occurring in the southern sectors. The northern region, which includes the largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, has experienced less retreat due to lower elevation and different climatic conditions.</s>

The Scots have won all five qualifiers and are set to face Iceland at Falkirk Stadium. A victory would likely secure their place in the finals. Both teams are unbeaten, with the outcome of the upcoming matches determining the group's top position. Scotland has a strong chance of reaching the finals without needing a play-off. The presence of international players in the squad, such as Evans, has been beneficial to the national team, as they bring different playing styles and experiences from various leagues.</s>

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish independence campaigner and blogger, was arrested in the west of England following a complaint from a woman in south London about online harassment over a two-year period. Mr. Campbell, who was released on bail, stated that the allegations concerned some tweets and insisted they were not threatening. He accused the media of "innuendo" designed to encourage "speculations." The Metropolitan Police are investigating the allegation, and Mr. Campbell has been bailed, pending further inquiries, to a date in mid-September.</s>

Peta suggests replacing the Jolly Fisherman mascot with a modern, animal-friendly version, a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." The mayor of Skegness welcomes suggestions but doubts there will be much support for changing the mascot. The original Jolly Fisherman poster was created in 1908 by the Great Northern Railway to promote seaside visits to Skegness. Peta argues that the mascot represents cruelty to animals, while the mayor believes Jolly Fisherman is seen as happy and friendly, and the mascot has been successful in promoting the resort.</s>

In a rugby match between Scotland and Georgia, Scotland emerged victorious with a strong performance, scoring multiple tries and demonstrating possession and territory control. Despite Georgia's brief moments of success, such as two penalty tries and two tries from Vasil Lobzhanidze, Scotland's aggressive approach and tactical play led to a final score of 38-11.</s>

Widnes secured a victory against Castleford with a 14-6 lead at half-time, thanks to tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge. Despite Castleford's three tries in four minutes, Widnes maintained their lead, resulting in a nervy finish. The win moved Widnes into seventh place, above Wakefield, while Castleford remained in sixth place.</s>

Fawzi al-Odah, a Kuwaiti detainee at Guantanamo Bay since 2002, was released after a US review panel deemed him not a significant threat. He was the first inmate to be freed since May and will now face a year at a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait. His release brings the total number of inmates at the US naval base to 148.</s>

Thousands attended the early morning service at Hyde Park Corner for Anzac Day, commemorating the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. Up to 400 people participated in a parade before the wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. A service was also held at Westminster Abbey, where the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia were sung. The first time Anzac Day was commemorated in the capital was in 1916 when King George V attended a Westminster Abbey service. The services have since become an important moment for expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians to honor the sacrifices of their countrymen and women in all wars.</s>

Clarkson, a 30-year-old footballer, has joined Premiership Well for a second spell and may make his St Mirren debut against Alloa on Saturday. He scored nine goals at Dundee last season and has been mainly a substitute this term. Clarkson is fit and ready to play, having trained hard to maintain his match fitness. He has played for Scotland twice and has made almost 400 senior club appearances. St Mirren is currently eighth in the Championship, and Clarkson hopes to help the team improve their standing.</s>

The turkey firm was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan, who assured Unite regional officer Steve Harley that existing workers' pension agreements would be honored. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, and members have an alternative unaffected pension scheme. Boparan Private Office confirmed that current pension arrangements would continue under new ownership. Boparan plans to restore Bernard Matthews to its former profitability through greater investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity for chicken processing.</s>

The council has decided to make the Cowes crossing free until 2 July due to issues with the new ferry, which has experienced multiple breakdowns, run aground, and faced suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Local businesses are suffering losses, and compensation is being considered. The council has ordered a review of the project by auditors and is working on resolving the problems.</s>

The House of Lords European Union Committee has released a report on the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit. The report states that the fishing industry may not be a priority for the government, but it should not be marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The UK and EU coastal states share most commercial fish stocks, and continued market access is crucial for the industry. However, this access may come at the price of allowing EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters. The report also suggests that some elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy should be retained post-Brexit, and the UK should continue to cooperate with neighboring states.</s>

Timothy Geaney, a former teacher, admitted to taking or permitting inappropriate images between 2004 and 2014. He was put on the sex offenders register and given a community payback order. After a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, he was removed from the profession's register due to his conduct being incompatible with being a registered teacher. The panel found that his offending behavior was likely to recur and prohibited him from re-registering for two years.</s>

The passage discusses a fire that occurred on 2 March at a site in Duncan Street, reducing train services and causing travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the incident. The company, which was run by Asset and Land Group, was found to be "broadly compliant" with fire safety law. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) visited the premises nine times in the last 12 months. The EA decided to take enforcement action against the site operators, revoking the environmental permit effective from 7 August, unless an appeal is made. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.</s>

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister, Faisal al-Mekdad, stated that the country is doing its best to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons. However, Syria missed the deadline to hand over its entire stockpile, with the second shipment being attacked by terrorist groups on its way to the port of Latakia. Al-Mekdad criticized the US Secretary of State, John Kerry, for condemning the government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, and denied reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison. The US expressed concern that the UN-backed plan to destroy Syria's chemical weapons was falling behind schedule, while Russia urged Damascus to complete the transfer of its chemical weapons to the coast for removal by ship by 1 March.</s>

England won the second Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England made 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, setting up their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. England's captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, while Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment in his team's performance.</s>

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review on the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She will gather evidence from pensioners, their friends, and families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will examine factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. The commissioner aims to ensure that older people living in residential care have the best quality of life and to address unacceptable variations across Wales. Care Forum Wales supports the review's overall aims but expresses disappointment that a provider expert is not included on the main advisory panel.</s>

Former Dons midfielder Sheerin, who has been player-manager at Arbroath since 2010, replaces Neil Cooper as the new manager at Aberdeen. Arbroath was relegated to Scottish League Two in 2013-14. Aberdeen chief executive Duncan Fraser said Derek McInnes chose Sheerin after a comprehensive process, and Arbroath chairman John Christison was cooperative. Sheerin won a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s and guided Arbroath to their first national trophy, the Scottish Third Division title, in 2011.</s>

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley's sacking. Swansea aims to appoint a new boss quickly, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement as the first choice. The club faces the possibility of relegation and recognizes the difficulty of bouncing back to the Premier League. Swansea, promoted in 2011, has experienced a remarkable rise from near bankruptcy in 2003. Curtis believes the club has lost its way since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014 and that the current squad is good enough to stay up.</s>

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated the human genome mapping process and faced criticism for his competitive approach. He founded the J. Craig Venter Institute, which created Synthia, the first synthetic life form, and has pursued other projects, such as sequencing ocean microbes' genomes. Dr. Venter's work has sparked controversy but also holds potential for industrial and environmental applications.</s>

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in the UK are low quality and too short compared to other European countries. The report suggests that thousands of apprenticeships should be created to boost the economy and improve young people's job prospects. The study reveals that only 20% of employers in England offer apprenticeships, compared to 51% in Germany. The report calls for up to 300,000 new apprenticeships each year, with a majority at level three or higher, lasting at least three years. The Department for Education says apprenticeships are being reformed to drive up standards.</s>

The passage discusses the achievements of British Paralympian, Storey, who recently won her 16th cycling world title, finishing ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska in Nottwil, Switzerland. Storey, who is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals, is targeting further success at the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Paralympic Games. She has won 11 gold, eight silver, and three bronze medals in both cycling and swimming across six Paralympics and has now won 21 world titles across both sports. Storey began her career in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, before switching to cycling in 2005.</s>

The passage discusses the financial troubles of Hereford United Football Club, which led to their expulsion from the Conference Premier. The club faced debts of approximately £225,000 and failed to meet multiple payment deadlines. Despite efforts by fans and a takeover by London businessman Tommy Agombar, the club was unable to resolve its financial issues and was replaced by Chester FC in the Conference Premier.</s>

The passage is about a former Manchester City player who has won 61 caps for England, playing in two World Cups and two European Championships. He has also held the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps and scored a goal in the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers. He has decided to retire from international football, wishing success to Sam Allardyce and the team.</s>

Christopher Hogwood, a prominent conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), passed away at his home in Cambridge after an extended illness. Hogwood was a key figure in the early-music movement and worked with numerous leading orchestras worldwide. He directed the AAM for over 30 years, during which the ensemble produced more than 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood was also a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service scheduled for a later date.</s>

A boy from Northern Ireland with special needs was removed from mainstream schooling due to his inability to cope. His family requested a place at a special school, but all schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full. The boy's mother expressed concern about the capacity issue and its impact on other families. The Education Authority is currently reviewing the profile of need for special school places in Northern Ireland and working to ensure availability close to where children reside.</s>

The Welsh Rugby Union is attempting a takeover of Newport Gwent Dragons, with plans to use Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. Newport County AFC has a lease to use the ground until 2023 and expects it to be honored. The WRU's takeover will be voted on in early May. Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey stated that both County and Newport Squash Club are protected under their current agreements. The WRU plans to install an artificial surface, which goes against Football League rules. Newport County is currently two points clear of the League Two relegation and can secure survival with a win and a rival's loss.</s>

The passage tells the story of a man who survived the civil war in Sierra Leone and later worked to fight the Ebola virus. He was kidnapped by the Revolutionary United Front rebels at 15 and underwent brutal training. After escaping, he met a preacher who helped him rebuild his life and encouraged him to contribute to society. During the Ebola crisis, he and his team educated people about the virus, provided them with food and other supplies, and set up an Ebola treatment clinic. Despite regretting his past actions, he believes in investing in young people for a better future.</s>

A public fundraising campaign saved 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs from being auctioned to pay off the pottery firm's pension debt. The collection will remain at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, and will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum before being loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The campaign's success prevented the collection from being "sold and scattered around the globe."</s>

The passage discusses a potential deal in which Wright may buy 20% of Billericay football club, with him possibly becoming a club director. The club is currently in the eighth position in the Isthmian League Premier Division, and has recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin. The club also signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March.</s>

In a match between Blackpool and Colchester United, the game ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool scored first with Jamille Matt turning the ball into the net after a chip from Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized with Kurtis Guthrie scoring from a close-range scramble during a corner. Both teams had chances to win, but crucial saves and missed opportunities led to the final score. The game also saw Colchester finish with 10 men after Sean Murray was given a red card for violent conduct.</s>

The passage discusses the transformation of the disused Fawley power station chimney into a tourist attraction, making it the tallest such attraction south of London's Shard. Developers Fawley Waterside plan to make the chimney the centrepiece of a "merchant city" development, which includes a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The power station, which closed in 2013, was capable of powering one million homes. The 300-acre site was sold to Fawley Waterside developers in 2016, and an application for outline planning permission is due later this year, with building potentially starting in 2018.</s>

23-year-old British cyclist Latham won a bronze medal in the Hong Kong championships, following Elinor Barker's silver medal in the women's scratch. Latham secured third place in the men's scratch race, chasing down Poland's Adrian Teklinski, who won gold, and Germany's Lucass Liss, who took silver. In the men's team pursuit, GB won bronze, while in the women's team pursuit, they finished fifth in the heats.</s>

Ross Kemp, who last played Grant Mitchell in 2006, is returning to EastEnders for a brief appearance to reunite the Mitchell family as Barbara's character is killed off due to her cancer. Dame Barbara returned to the show recently and announced her character's death. Grant Mitchell is a memorable character from the soap's 30-year history and his return is expected to be emotional and classic.</s>

Sadio Mane scored two goals in a 138-second span, leading to a disappointing performance by second-placed Spurs at Anfield. Pochettino expressed concern about the team's lack of desire and inability to cope with pressure, stating it would be difficult to fight for the Premier League title. Spurs have struggled on the road, winning only twice since September 24th, and have a poor record against top-six rivals away from home. Former Liverpool and Spurs midfielder Danny Murphy criticized the team's performance and suggested they need to improve quickly.</s>

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in Nigeria's recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on May 29th after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP's decline has been reinforced by results from Saturday's elections for governors and state assemblies. The APC has made historic gains, relegating the once-powerful PDP to a regional party. However, the APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could be a concern for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari due to the potential for militant groups to disrupt oil production.</s>

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will offer visitors an augmented reality experience through an app that provides online information from signs and posters on the site. The app will allow users to view videos, band interviews, and other content on their phones and tablets. The festival's director, Caroline Maclennan, said the new feature aims to enhance the visitor experience and allow people worldwide to interact with the festival and capture its atmosphere.</s>

The passage discusses the inadequate ratings given to several Birmingham academies, including Park View and Nansen Primary, by Ofsted. These schools will have their funding agreements terminated, and the Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running them. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School were also rated inadequate and warned they could lose funding unless concerns were addressed. A head teacher at one of the Trojan Horse schools claimed parents tried to undermine her authority during an Ofsted inspection. The Department for Education and Birmingham City Council plan to work together to install a temporary governing board at Saltley School, the only local authority school placed in special measures. Education minister Lord Nash expressed deep concerns about the way Park View School was run and criticized the trust for failing to promote the spiritual, moral, social, and cultural development of pupils.</s>

Vinnie Barker died in July 2012 after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich, where eye specialist Honey Rose allegedly failed to detect his swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation. The prosecution claims that Rose's conduct was so far below the expected standard it was "criminal" and that Vinnie's death was preventable. Ms. Rose denies a charge of gross negligence manslaughter, and the trial is ongoing.</s>

Clive Weatherhogg, a 42-year-old man, was found guilty of coercing a woman to engage in sexual activity with a man he found through an adult website. He filmed the encounters and sent a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and faced trial at Dundee Sheriff Court. The case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh due to its greater sentencing powers. He was also convicted of causing the woman's sister and father to look at sexual images and behaving in a threatening or abusive manner. The woman felt "blackmailed" by Weatherhogg. The judge stated that his sentence must reflect society's abhorrence at such conduct. Weatherhogg, a first offender, was assessed as posing "a moderate risk" of sexual re-offending.</s>

In a T20 cricket match in Greater Noida, Ireland scored 165-5 with notable contributions from Stuart Thompson (56), Gary Wilson (41 not out), and William Porterfield (39). However, Afghanistan reached 171-4 with Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47) and won the match. Afghan spinner Amir Hamza took two wickets. Ireland's Paul Stirling was dismissed for a duck, and Boyd Rankin is unavailable due to a back problem. The teams will play again in the second T20 at the same venue on Friday.</s>

The Spanish champions, Barcelona, have denied any offence in their signing of Neymar, a 22-year-old Santos striker, for £48.6m. The club's statement aimed to cover interpretations of the contracts involved in the operation. Neymar's parents received £34m of the fee, and including signing-on fees, wages, agents fees, and tax payments, the player cost the club £106.8m. Last month, former Barcelona president Sandro Rosell resigned due to accusations of misappropriating money and is being investigated, but denies any wrongdoing. A judge in Spain ruled that there was sufficient evidence against Barcelona to continue investigations into the transfer. The club has made a complimentary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros to defend its reputation and good name, although they remain convinced that the original tax payment was in line with their fiscal obligations.</s>

The passage discusses the murders of David Miller and Hannah Witheridge, whose bodies were found on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September. Metropolitan Police officers traveled to Thailand to work with local authorities, who have two Burmese suspects in custody. The UK detectives have completed their work and will return to the UK to compile a report and update the families of the victims. The suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape and robbery, and could face the death penalty if found guilty. The UK Foreign Office has expressed concerns about the police investigation, including the verification of DNA samples and allegations of mistreatment of the suspects. The visit of the UK police delegation came after Thai Prime Minister Gen Prayuth Chan-ocha met with UK Prime Minister David Cameron and agreed to the assistance. Post-mortem examinations revealed that Mr. Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Miss Witheridge died from head wounds. Thai police have confirmed that DNA found on Ms. Witheridge matched samples taken from the suspects.</s>

The Scots have won all five qualifiers and are set to face Iceland at Falkirk Stadium. A victory would likely secure their place in the finals. Both teams are unbeaten, with the outcome of the upcoming matches determining the group's top position. Scotland has a strong chance of reaching the finals without the need for a play-off. The presence of international players in the squad, such as Kim Little, is seen as beneficial for the national team.</s>

Apple has implemented new security measures to prevent theft of intimate photos from iCloud, following the recent celebrity photo leak. The two-step verification system, which had been offered in the past, now guards against cyber-thieves using stolen or guessed passwords. The process requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted mobile phone number or via Apple's Find My iPhone app. The security improvements also include an email notification when a backup starts downloading. However, some experts suggest that Apple should make two-factor authentication the default option, rather than an opt-in choice.</s>

The passage provides information on the campaign expenditure of various political parties during the European election in May. UKIP won the election, spending £2,956,737, followed by the Tories at £2,980,815, Labour at £1,027,339, the Lib Dems at £1,580,575, and the Green Party at £534,249. The campaign spending per vote for each party is also mentioned. The total spending of the six highest-spending parties was £9,347,087, with all but Labour spending more than in the 2009 European election campaign.</s>

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has left Barrow to join National League rivals and may play against his former club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, was recommended to Gulls boss Nicholson and is awaiting international clearance. Anderson is described as a leader-type, while Keating is young and hungry to prove himself. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone.</s>

The passage discusses the death of a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds, who collapsed after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed that the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage." Although Many Clouds had shown symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, he had never collapsed before and had no significant underlying health issues. The passage also mentions that the horse had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, and that his trainer, Oliver Sherwood, described him as the "horse of a lifetime."</s>

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick, former first minister Alex Salmond, and veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil are among those standing down as MSPs ahead of the election on 5 May. In his valedictory address, Salmond expressed his belief that Scotland is "not divided, but diverse" and emphasized the need for the parliament to assume greater responsibility for the governance of Scotland. Marwick thanked Salmond for his contributions, and McNeil warned that Holyrood had things to learn from Westminster, particularly with regard to the committee system.</s>

The passage announces the casting of a star as Mrs. Potts in an upcoming film adaptation of Beauty and the Beast, with a release date of March 17, 2017. Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Bill Condon will direct the movie, which will begin filming in May at Shepperton Studios.</s>

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decisions on whether to bring charges against 23 suspects in relation to the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster, which resulted in the deaths of 96 football fans, at a meeting with victims' relatives. Last year, new inquests concluded that the fans had been unlawfully killed. The suspects include individuals related to the causes of the disaster and the conduct of the police in its aftermath.</s>

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages being thrown over the wall, containing contraband such as mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the issue and is looking into ways to ensure prisons have the tools to tackle this problem. A woman living near the prison has witnessed these incidents, and a former inmate claims drones are used to deliver contraband goods. The Ministry of Justice stated that laws have been introduced, which could result in a two-year jail sentence for those smuggling packages over prison walls.</s>

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being hit by Brian Wright's car outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston. Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red light before striking Blackburn. He denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Blackburn is now being treated in residential care. The trial is ongoing.</s>

The passage discusses Scottish middle-distance runner Laura Muir's decision to prioritize her veterinary medicine studies over participating in the Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast next year. Despite finishing fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, Muir will focus on completing her final year of university. She expresses disappointment at missing the Commonwealth Games but believes in the importance of obtaining her degree. Muir considers the World Indoor Championships in March a potential target and remains optimistic about her future in athletics, potentially competing in two or three more Olympics.</s>

In December 2000, 22-year-old Trevor Deely disappeared while walking home from a Christmas party. A search for him began in Chapelizod, Dublin, involving excavations and expected to last several weeks. Earlier in the year, a team of detectives reviewed his case and released enhanced CCTV footage of Deely and a man in black, who they believe followed him. The man has not been identified, and authorities continue to appeal for him to come forward.</s>

Del Potro secured a 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 victory over Wawrinka in a thrilling match. The Argentine, who is 165th in the rankings, had missed more than two years due to injury problems. Del Potro will next play either France's 32nd seed Lucas Pouille or American Donald Young.</s>

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations until apologizing to Caf for complaints lodged against the organization during the 2015 Nations Cup. Morocco was able to enter the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned a ban on its participation. Morocco was punished in February after being replaced as the 2015 Nations Cup hosts due to concerns over the Ebola virus. Equatorial Guinea stepped in to host the 2015 finals. Tunisia's participation in the 2017 Nations Cup seemed in doubt until a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou in Senegal led to a resolution. Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will face Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F.</s>

The passage discusses the history of McLaren, a once-great Formula 1 team that has experienced a significant decline in recent years. Despite having 182 grands prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, the team has struggled with poor performance since 2013. The slump began with issues in chassis design and has continued due to problems with the Honda power-unit. The team has had a cycle of triumph and decline throughout its history, with periods of success followed by periods of struggle. McLaren has had a partnership with Honda in the past, which led to some of its greatest successes, and they hope to regain their former glory with the renewed partnership.</s>

On 6 October 2014, paramedics attended a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven, where alcohol was being served outside licensing hours. Limavady Magistrates Court charged Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas for allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months and fined O'Neill £3,000 and Thomas £1,000. The judge expressed concern over O'Neill's "appalling record" and the lack of power to impose a custodial sentence.</s>

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points and helping the Golden State Warriors secure a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry hit eight three-pointers, surpassing his previous record of 272 made in a single season. Teammate Klay Thompson scored 26 points, and together they helped the Warriors overcome a 13-point deficit.</s>

YouTube star Bas van Velzen, known for his free-kick skills, visited Liverpool's Melwood training ground, where he was mistaken for a competition winner. He impressed Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic with his dead-ball skills. Van Velzen described the experience as amazing and enjoyed playing football with his idols. He also surprised Balotelli by unveiling the forward's infamous slogan t-shirt.</s>

The passage discusses how carriers of the BRCA1 gene, like Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of death from breast cancer by having their ovaries removed. A study found that this procedure can cut their risk of dying from breast cancer by over 60%. Women with a BRCA1 mutation who have their ovaries removed within two years of diagnosis experience a 73% reduction in death compared to those who never undergo the procedure. The protective effect of oophorectomy against breast cancer is apparent immediately after diagnosis and lasts for 15 years.</s>

A married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were tragically killed by an Amtrak train on Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina. The train, number 80, the Carolinian, was traveling from Charlotte to New York City when the accident occurred on property owned by Norfolk-Southern. None of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, but there was a delay of about two hours and 45 minutes before the train continued its route. The couple may have lived in a homeless camp, according to a man who met them while collecting scrap metal.</s>

Carlos Toro, a former Medellin cartel member, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s. In exchange for his cooperation, he was promised US citizenship, which has not been granted. Now 66 and retired due to declining health, Toro faces deportation and fears for his life if sent back to Colombia. Despite his significant contributions to the DEA, including aiding in the prosecution of Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, the agency has refused to help him with his citizenship.</s>

The US body that regulates internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for potentially illegal actions in using the new '.sucks' domain name. The company has been charging exorbitant fees to celebrities and companies, such as Kevin Spacey and major brands, to remove their names from the domain. ICANN has sent a letter to the US Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to determine the legality of Vox Populi's actions.</s>

A mother was arrested 27 years after her stillborn baby's body was found in a village pond. The baby's body was exhumed last year, and a DNA sample led the police to the mother. The woman explained that the baby was stillborn and she had concealed the pregnancy from her family and friends. The police have ruled out foul play, and the woman remains on bail while the CPS decides whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby was reburied at St Peter's Church in Norfolk, and was given the name Peter.</s>

A taxi driver, Michael Young, has been ordered to pay compensation to a passenger, Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of the moving car. The incident occurred five years ago when Young mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to "do a runner" and drove him back to the rank to teach him a lesson. When Hicks objected, Young continued driving, leading to Hicks jumping from the vehicle at over 20mph. Hicks developed epilepsy and now requires round-the-clock care from his mother. The exact amount of compensation is yet to be decided but is expected to be around 50% of what the family requested, potentially hundreds of thousands of pounds.</s>

Tornado sirens were sounded in Kansas as several storms brought reports of twisters. A tornado was spotted near Goddard, moving northeast and posing potential risks to other communities. CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers warned of nighttime tornadoes being the most deadly and dangerous. Other tornado sightings occurred in southwestern Kansas. Kansas was not the only state affected, as a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage, flooding, and fallen trees. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes.</s>

Luke Rockhold is preparing to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight fight in New Jersey. Rockhold aims for his fourth consecutive victory and a title shot. He plans to dominate Machida by cutting him off and progressing slowly, making him fight Rockhold's fight. Rockhold believes he has various advantages over Machida and respects his fighting style. Machida, confident in his own abilities, thinks he can stop Rockhold and earn a title shot. Both fighters are well-prepared for the upcoming match.</s>

An aeroplane touched down on a runway without deploying its landing gear and skidded along the runway on its belly in Fort Pierce, Florida. The light general aviation aircraft, an Aerostar plane, approached the Aero Acres residential airpark and touched down without its landing gear deployed. The propellers ricocheted off the ground and the wings bounced up and down from the impact. The pilot re-engaged the engines and took off back into the air. The plane's pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, managed to fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. The most common cause of a gear-up landing is human error, when the pilot forgets to deploy the landing gear before touchdown. The FAA is investigating the incident.</s>

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in midfielder Yaya Toure's performance this season but has vowed to support him until the end of the season. The club is reportedly open to offers for the Ivorian player as they look to overhaul their aging squad. Toure, who has two years left on his £220,000-a-week contract, has faced criticism amid Manchester City's faltering Premier League campaign. City goalkeeper Joe Hart believes the players should take responsibility for their poor performances, but Pellegrini maintains that he chooses the players.</s>

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," had his extradition to Italy dropped and was allowed to remain in the UK. Rancadore was given a seven-year sentence by an Italian court in 1999 for being a member of the Cosa Nostra. In February, he lost his battle against extradition, but his case expired in October, leading to the withdrawal of his European arrest warrant. Although his conviction remains intact, Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished once a period of more than double the time of the penalty has passed.</s>

The passage discusses the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown, where Mr. Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls and ridden by AP McCoy, is one of the three 7-2 co-favorites. Other co-favorites include Irish horse Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's sprinter Sacre, ridden by Cheltenham Gold Cup winner Nico de Boinville. Mr. Mole will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race, and his final book of rides will be finalized on Friday morning. McCoy announced his intention to quit riding after winning with Mr. Mole at Newbury in February. The other runners in the Celebration Chase include Mick Channon's Somersby.</s>

The mother of a girl murdered 40 years ago recently saw crime scene photos of her daughter's body and now wants revenge. Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter, Marcia, was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcia's body was found 33 days after she disappeared. Ritter's then-husband advised her against seeing the body and the crime scene photos, which she finally viewed last year with the help of a metro police lead investigator. Barrett was found guilty of second-degree murder and sentenced to 44 years in prison.</s>

Rory McIlroy believes it is essential for him to win the Masters at some point to complete the career Grand Slam. The world number one golfer aims to claim his first Green Jacket and become the sixth player to win all four major titles. McIlroy has just one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances and hopes to complete his Grand Slam with a victory at Augusta later this month.</s>

The passage highlights various trending stories from the week, including four rainbows appearing in the New York sky, exotic dancers being banned from wakes in China, a lip-plumping trend inspired by Kylie Jenner, 102-year-old Alice Barker's prom-posal, Ewan McGregor's casting in "Beauty and the Beast," Johnny Depp's transformation in "Black Mass" trailer, a creative pregnancy announcement referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," and a military dad's photobomb.</s>

The passage reveals that 272 children were hospitalized in England in the past 12 months due to being born brain damaged from exposure to alcohol in the womb, according to the official Health and Social Care Information Centre. The actual number of affected children could be higher. The World Health Organization estimates that at least one in 100 babies born in the UK could suffer learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure, amounting to about 7,500 cases every year. The passage also shares the story of a teenager with Foetal Alcohol Syndrome and discusses the various medical issues associated with alcohol consumption during pregnancy. Pregnant women are advised not to drink alcohol, but some experts believe the guidance should be changed to advise women not to drink at all during pregnancy.</s>

An axe-wielding robber, Shaun Andrew Mckerry, attempted to rob a store in Shildon Post Office and Stores, County Durham. However, his attempt was foiled when the shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, tackled him to the floor, and Dhillon's wife, Sam, hit Mckerry with a baseball bat. Mckerry was arrested by the police and later jailed for six years after pleading guilty to attempted robbery. Mckerry, a former juvenile offender, had been arrested 80 times by the age of 15 and earned the nicknames "Boomerang Boy" and "Homing Pigeon Boy" for always returning home after committing crimes.</s>

Four Royal Navy sailors have been charged with gang rape at a Canadian barracks and must stay in Nova Scotia until they are tried. They were given unusual bail conditions, including surrendering their passports and living at the Stadacona Naval Base in Halifax. The sailors will continue to work for the Royal Navy and draw their current pay. They are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, which are punishable by up to 14 years in prison.</s>

A mother of a four-year-old boy with Netherton's syndrome, a rare skin disease affecting only 70 people worldwide, was reported to the police for child abuse by a stranger who mistook his condition for abuse. The boy's skin appears red and inflamed with a scaly appearance, requiring regular application of creams to prevent drying out. The mother has faced taunts and ignorance from the public, and the family has struggled with the challenges and stigma associated with the rare condition.</s>

The controversial Protein World advertisement featuring a bikini-clad model has caused a backlash among feminists and body image campaigners, leading to a Change.org petition with over 50,000 signatures calling for its removal. Transport for London (TFL) has confirmed that the posters will be removed as they have reached the end of their three-week advertising period. The advertising standards authority has received over 200 complaints about the adverts promoting an unhealthy body image.</s>
