The memorial will be dedicated to their courage and sacrifice and is expected to be completed by 2019. The UK government has committed £1m towards the £4m needed for the project.</s>

Manchester United remains 15 points ahead at the top of the table with eight games left after a 1-0 win against Sunderland. Manager Ferguson emphasizes focusing on upcoming matches and praises the team's record of 25 wins in the first 30 matches. The next league game is a derby against Manchester City, where United will have a 15-point head start. The team has won 50 of a possible 54 points in their last 18 Premier League games and aims to better Chelsea's record of 95 points in 2005. Ferguson plans to make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea due to injuries sustained during the Sunderland match.</s>

Google's chairman, Mr. Schmidt, told the BBC that the company paid the right amount of taxes legally required and that it's up to the government to change its tax system if it wants companies to pay more. He stated that Google will comply with any changes in tax laws and that taxes are not optional. Margaret Hodge, head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, suggested a new committee to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms. Google has been criticized for organizing its tax affairs to minimize the amounts paid in the UK. European Union leaders agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an automatic information exchange between tax authorities. Mr. Schmidt has called for a debate on international tax reform and hopes for a clearer, simpler system.</s>

The regulator, NHS Improvement, aims to reduce the NHS's agency bill by £1bn by the end of the financial year. A cap was introduced in October, saving £600m so far, limiting hospitals, mental health trusts, and ambulance services to pay no more than 55% above normal shift rates for staff. The progress made is considered "promising" but still leaves the NHS short of its goal. NHS Improvement plans to publish "league tables" of the best and worst-performing trusts on agency spending and collect information on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust to address suspicions of large sums being earned from agency work.</s>

The Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of prosperity, now represents the aftermath of the Republic of Ireland's economic crash. Local traders, like Matt O'Brien, have experienced a decline in business but are starting to see a turnaround. The government is investing in tourism, with the proposed Center Parcs development set to employ 1,000 people in 2019. However, local businesses still face challenges, such as parking fees and a lack of foreign direct investment.</s>

The passage provides information about an ongoing cricket tournament with eight teams participating. The competition will finish on 29 May in the same stadium. The top four teams will qualify for the play-offs. The passage also lists the leading run-scorers, most sixes, highest score in an innings, and most wickets. Additionally, it mentions that four current or former England players will take part in the tournament. The passage includes a detailed list of fixtures and results with dates and times.</s>

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013, causing environmental issues as many bags are non-recyclable and end up in rubbish dumps and rivers. Starting in October, people in England will pay 5p for plastic bags to encourage reusing existing bags. Supermarkets in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where bags are charged, have seen a decrease in usage. Campaigners hope the charge in England will reduce bag waste and benefit the environment.</s>

A yellow 'be aware' warning for wind across Wales caused disruptions, including a school roof being ripped off, power cuts for hundreds of homes, train delays, and lane restrictions on major bridges. Irish Ferries cancelled six sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, and Arriva Trains Wales warned of possible delays due to winds. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham. Winds eased in the evening, but a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend led to the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip in Denbighshire.</s>

The passage discusses Michael B. Jordan's excitement about joining the cast of an upcoming film, which will be directed by Ryan Coogler. He is looking forward to working with Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman, and mentions his previous role as the Human Torch in Fantastic Four. The film, Black Panther, is set to be released in February 2018.</s>

The passage discusses the restoration of Alexandra Palace's theatre and BBC studios, which were founded in 1875 and have been unused for decades. The goal is to reopen the theatre in 2018 as part of a larger east wing restoration project to transform the palace into a cultural destination. The Heritage Lottery Fund and Haringey Council are contributing funds, while the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust is raising the remaining £1m. The theatre will be used for various performances and events, and the glazed east court will become an exhibition space.</s>

The passage is about a former Manchester City player who has won 61 caps for England, played in two World Cups and two European Championships, and holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps. He made his senior debut in 2009, played only three minutes at Euro 2016, and scored his only international goal in a 2014 World Cup qualifier match. He wishes success to Sam Allardyce, the players, staff, and supporters in the future.</s>

A fire broke out in Marcy Smith's house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, while her son David was on FaceTime with his father. David woke up the family, and they managed to escape, but their house was destroyed and their pets did not survive. The fire was started by rubbish burned in the wood stove, and the fire alarm did not go off. The community has since supported the family by donating clothes and other items.</s>

The energy drinks giant is reportedly considering a £200m offer for the Premier League club, West Ham. Sullivan and Gold, who bought a majority stake in the club in 2010, now own over 85% of it. West Ham has also been linked to takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups. Sullivan mentioned the possibility of selling a minority shareholding to clear debts, but intends for ownership to pass on to his children.</s>

The passage describes an unofficial awards ceremony in Los Angeles, which featured fan-voted awards and served as a promotional platform for upcoming summer blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars was the night's big winner, with Shailene Woodley receiving multiple awards. Other winners included Bradley Cooper, Channing Tatum, Meryl Streep, and Kevin Hart. Robert Downey Jr. received the Generation Award, presented by his Avengers co-stars. Clips from Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck, and Marvel's Ultron were shown during the event.</s>

The passage discusses the loan of 21-year-old footballer Smith from Dundee United to St Mirren. Smith has scored five goals this season and has previously played for Aberdeen. St Mirren's manager, Jack Ross, is excited about the acquisition, praising Smith's abilities and maturity, and believes he will be a valuable addition to the team's attacking options. St Mirren, currently at the bottom of the Championship, will face Falkirk on Saturday.</s>

The Northumberland County Council plans to fill 145 potholes daily for the next four months using Jetpatcher machines, as the weather is now suitable. Additionally, extra staff will work on repairing drainage systems and clearing debris from gutters due to heavy rain.</s>

In December 2016, six workers on EnQuest's Thistle platform, off Shetland, were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing a piece of pipework. The workers, employed by Wood Group under a contract with EnQuest, were not wearing proper personal protective equipment (PPE) as they were not informed of the radiation risk. EnQuest has taken additional precautionary steps since the incident, while Wood Group has prioritized the health and safety of its employees. The workers now face cancer fears and ongoing blood tests.</s>

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007. The dealer's manager later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including the sculpture. The item is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. Following discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and the Indian government's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), the sculpture was returned. ACM will pursue legal action for compensation due to the fraud.</s>

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km. The tremor was felt in Milan, Florence, and other cities, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. Italy is prone to earthquakes, with a deadly quake in L'Aquila in 2009 killing nearly 300 people. Several aftershocks of lower magnitude were felt across a large area, and phone lines and power supplies were cut in the Garfagnana area. Schools in the vicinity were evacuated as a precaution.</s>
Austin Grant from Sheffield has successfully grown a fruit in South Yorkshire, despite initial doubts about the climate. The fruit is not yet ripe for eating and remains attached to the plant.</s>

Rockstar has delayed the game's release until 24 March, originally scheduled for 27 January, to allow for extra testing and polishing. The company also announced that online heists will come to consoles before the PC release, which will feature improved graphics and support for multiple monitors. Minimum specifications for PC users have been published, and Grand Theft Auto V remains the fastest-selling entertainment product ever since its September 2013 release.</s>

The 76-year-old artist won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work "Squint (19)," which is displayed at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. The painting depicts a leper squint and was praised by the judge, Ansel Krut, for its subtlety and minimal language. The artist plans to use the prize money to purchase materials for his future works. The John Moores Painting Prize is a prestigious British art award, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.</s>

The offices of Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, two pro-government newspapers in Turkey, were attacked by four masked assailants early on Thursday. No casualties were reported, and firefighters quickly extinguished the fire at the Yeni Safak building. Police have cordoned off the area, and spent bullet casings were found at both scenes. The assailants are still being hunted, and no group has claimed responsibility for the attacks. In a similar incident last September, pro-government protesters attacked the offices of daily Hurriyet, accusing the paper of misquoting President Erdogan.</s>

A 24-year-old player, previously under contract with the Stags, will join Marcus Bignot's team on a free transfer. He was on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances. The former Burton player will officially join on 1 January and is Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.</s>

The passage discusses Arsene Wenger's comments on Gareth Southgate's potential appointment as England manager, stating that Southgate has accumulated experience and is a good observer of the national team. Wenger also mentions that he is focused on his own job and believes that the most important factor in a candidate's competency. Additionally, Wenger talks about offering a new contract to 21-year-old defender Hector Bellerin, who has been linked with moves to Barcelona and Manchester City, and provides an update on midfielder Aaron Ramsey's injury.</s>

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are conducting a joint inquiry, with the company cooperating fully.</s>

The Transport Minister, Humza Yousaf, announced a new charter arrangement to resolve the long-standing dispute over seafarers' pay. The RMT union claimed that some workers on two freight boats were paid less than £4 an hour. The charter change will result in contracted out services returning to operator Serco Northlink from next month. The freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay have been operated by Seatruck, which is contracted to run the service by Serco Northlink. Seatruck argued that the national minimum wage was not applicable to the crew, many of whom are non-UK residents. Serco Northlink claimed it had repeatedly offered to bridge the pay gap and backdate it, but Seatruck declined to accept. The new arrangements will come into force early next month, subject to some financial and regulatory details being finalized.</s>

Ken Dickie, 64, died after an incident at Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted to intervening in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother. Mitchell and his mother Samantha, 57, pleaded guilty to common assault and attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the events. They will be sentenced on 6 February.</s>

Renowned songwriter Rod Temperton passed away at 66 in London after a brief battle with cancer. Temperton was known for writing hits like "Rock With You" and "Thriller" for Michael Jackson, as well as "Boogie Nights" for Heatwave. He began his career in the 1970s with Heatwave and later worked with Quincy Jones, contributing to Jackson's breakthrough solo album, "Off The Wall." Temperton won a Grammy Award in 1990 and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986. His family and colleagues, including Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, and Mark Ronson, paid tribute to his immense talent and influence on the music industry.</s>

Swansea University's Dr. Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof. Alayne Street-Perrott are part of a team that discovered ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon. The researchers, from universities in the UK and Brazil, found over 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs" concealed by rainforests for centuries. The function of these sites is still unclear, but they are thought to have been used as ritual gathering places. Dr. Loader analyzed soil samples from the geoglyphs to understand the ancient vegetation, forest burning, and type of vegetation growing there in the past. The research also indicates that the Amazonian forests were not pristine ecosystems but were influenced by humans, who created a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products.</s>

The passage describes a tennis match where Australian player Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Querrey with a score of 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes, advancing to the second round. Kyrgios mentioned feeling tired and bored during the match, attributing his fatigue to his recent success in the Japan Open and the challenging travel and sleep conditions in Shanghai. The passage also mentions a previous incident where Kyrgios was fined for a foul-mouthed outburst at the Shanghai Masters last year.</s>

The human papilloma virus (HPV) jab, which protects against head and neck cancers, is currently only given to girls aged 12 and 13 in Wales to prevent cervical cancer. However, charities and organizations are urging the Welsh government to roll out the vaccination for both boys and girls, as the number of head and neck cancer cases is increasing, with 5% of the global cancer burden attributed to HPV. The Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision.</s>

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old boy, suffered from a rare form of blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. He attended a school prom in his honor but passed away shortly after. Jak's journey with cancer was documented on a Facebook page called "Jak's Journey," which gained over 28,000 likes and followed his positive attitude and love for Rangers FC. Despite his illness, Jak participated in various activities and received support from many people, including visits from players and cast members. His family raised funds for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, and a special football match was held in his memory.</s>

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 in a Group D match, with Abdallah El Said scoring the winning goal in the 89th minute. The victory means Egypt will play Ghana for the top spot in the group, while Uganda is out of their first tournament since 1978. Ghana has already secured a place in the quarter-finals after defeating Mali 1-0.</s>

Lancashire County Council has chosen land on the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a new railway station project. The decision was based on a study by Network Rail and is part of a partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council. The project aims to provide Skelmersdale with two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. County councillor John Fillis said the location is suitable for future expansion and has good connectivity to the town and surrounding area. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961, is one of the largest towns in the north west of England without its own railway station.</s>
A man in his late 40s was arrested at a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning after police discovered an elaborate grow house with plants.</s>

A 28-year-old woman of Kurdish origin was found injured on a pavement in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, after being dragged by the neck through several streets. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old German citizen of Kurdish origin from Bad Muender, has been arrested. The motive for the attack is still unclear, and police are seeking witnesses.</s>

The research found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise but are less likely to get one. The study, conducted by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, analyzed 4,600 workers and found no support for the "reticent female" theory, which suggests that women avoid asking for more money. When like-for-like male and female workers were compared, men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked. The study also found that women and men under 40 both asked for and received pay rises at the same rate, indicating that negotiating behavior may be changing.</s>

The passage discusses the issue of limited burial space in Oxford, as two of the city's cemeteries are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for many years but has not found a suitable location due to various factors such as site size, ground conditions, and restrictions. After the remaining cemeteries are full, the council will only be able to offer reopening of family plots, using reserved plots, and interment of ashes. The last increase in burial space in Oxford occurred in 1932.</s>

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will feature an augmented reality app that allows visitors to access online information from signs and posters on site, as well as videos and band interviews. The app will also enable people around the world to interact with the festival and experience its atmosphere.</s>

The passage discusses the death of a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, who collapsed after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed that the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage." Although Many Clouds had shown symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, he had never collapsed before and had no significant underlying health issues. The passage also mentions that the horse had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014, and that his trainer, Oliver Sherwood, described him as the "horse of a lifetime."</s>

In 2004, a 15-year-old girl met David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage. Now 34 and known as Davina, she has been found guilty of raping the teenager while two others slept in the garage. Davina, who has learning difficulties and changed her name in 2012, will be sentenced on 4 March. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody, stating she would likely be held in a male prison due to the risk she poses to herself and the potential for failing to attend court. The victim reported that she had not consumed much alcohol and clearly recollected the events. In 2014, Davina confessed to the attack while living in a care home in Fordingbridge, Hampshire.</s>

The passage discusses the Serbs losing 6-4 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. This loss followed Djokovic's defeat in the singles by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. Earlier in the year, Djokovic experienced a surprise third-round loss at Wimbledon to American Sam Querrey. However, he later claimed his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.</s>

The passage describes an upcoming carving competition in Carrbridge, where over 20 competitors from various countries will use chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher, will return to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.</s>

Webb, a 27-year-old rugby player, has been recovering from a foot injury since September. He is close to returning and aims to be fit before the Six Nations in February. Webb has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down other offers to stay with his home region.</s>

On Tuesday morning, US border agents encountered two men carrying backpacks near the border in Washington, attempting to smuggle 58lb of MDMA, or ecstasy, from Canada to San Francisco. One of the men fired a weapon at the agents and fled, while the other was arrested. Canadian and US police searched for the fugitive and arrested him the next day. Three other individuals were also arrested in connection to the smuggling plan. The three defendants in US custody face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges.</s>

The passage discusses the increasing issue of online bullying, with Childline counseling more than 4,500 children in the past year compared to 2,400 in 2011-12. Children as young as seven have been affected, with online trolls causing misery and humiliation. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, emphasizes the importance of adult intervention and for schools to take the problem seriously. The passage highlights the need for help during Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, which works with parents, schools, and other organizations to combat the issue.</s>

The Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee has postponed a vote on authorizing 492 new homes in the settlements of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot, following a request from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office. This decision comes ahead of a speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict by US Secretary of State John Kerry. The move is seen as an attempt to avoid further straining relations with Washington after the US chose not to veto a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to settlement construction.</s>

In a BBC interview, Prince William praised the Queen as a "guiding example" of a good monarch on the eve of her 90th birthday. A picture of the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George was released for stamps to mark the occasion. The Queen visited Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office and met with staff, viewing an exhibition. She also opened a new bandstand in Alexandra Gardens and was sung to by local schoolchildren. Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn expressed their anticipation of wishing the Queen a happy birthday. Prince William discussed his commitment to royal duty and his plans for his future role as king.</s>

In a League Two vs Premier League match, West Ham United secured a 2-0 victory against Cheltenham Town with goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew. Despite Cheltenham Town's efforts, they could not equalize, and West Ham United could have won by a greater margin. This result eliminated League Two's representation in the EFL Cup before the third-round draw.</s>

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion on Sunday. Andreas Werner, 46, of Leipzig, failed to notice McNicholl on his motorcycle and caused the fatal crash while turning his VW Transporter right. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court, was fined £1,000, and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not see value in sending Werner to jail, considering it a momentary lapse. Werner was remorseful and could not explain the crash.</s>

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British jihadist, returned to the UK last year after fighting in Syria and is now facing a possible life imprisonment. Khawaja was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with the Islamic State, and was involved in creating propaganda videos and recruiting young British Muslims. He left the UK in January and faked his own death before attempting to return unnoticed. Upon his return, he was arrested and charged with four offenses, while his cousin, Tahir Bhatti, pleaded guilty to assisting an offender.</s>

22-year-old Jackson, who scored four goals in 36 appearances last season for Wrexham, has signed with Barnsley as their third signing for the upcoming season. Barnsley's caretaker boss, Paul Heckingbottom, praised Jackson's pace and ability to get at defenders. Jackson rejected a contract offer from Wrexham for the next season.</s>

Bottles containing detergent have been washing up on Cornish beaches, posing a risk to wildlife. It is believed a container containing the bottles was lost from a ship during stormy weather. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency has not confirmed if the bottles are from the MV Blue Ocean. Cornwall Wildlife Trust is concerned about the impact on marine life, and the National Trust is working to clear the bottles away. The public is advised to keep children and dogs away from the bottles.</s>

A crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at around 14:00, resulting in minor injuries for several people. The road was closed and diverted via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road while Police Scotland conducted ongoing inquiries.</s>

Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season, contributing to Wanderers' second place finish in League One and promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in total. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite's excellent contribution last year. Dervite is one of four players, including David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan, to sign new contracts with Bolton following their promotion to the Championship.</s>

The passage discusses the conflict between the Labour and Lib Dem parties in the UK's House of Lords. They had previously worked together to oppose the government on issues related to Brexit and other matters. However, their cooperation ended when MPs rejected their amendments. The Labour party accused the Lib Dems of giving false hope to people, while the Lib Dems criticized Labour for supporting the government's plans. Both parties have a history of forming alliances on various issues, but the passage suggests that future cooperation may be hindered by residual tensions.</s>

In this election, defence is low on the priority list for most political parties, with it only just scraping into the top 10 concerns for the electorate. The UK has been making significant cuts to its armed forces, and the size of the regular Army is being reduced, as well as the Royal Navy and RAF. The UK has fallen to sixth place in defence spending globally, and is at risk of falling below the NATO threshold. Most analysts agree that the world is becoming more dangerous and unstable, but defence is not a key issue in this election campaign.</s>

The Spanish champions, Barcelona, insist they did not commit any offence in signing Neymar for £48.6m, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. The actual cost of the player is alleged to be far greater when considering other contracts. Last month, former Barcelona president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriating money and is being investigated but denies any wrongdoing. A judge in Spain ruled there was sufficient evidence against Barcelona to continue investigations into the transfer. The club has made a complimentary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros to defend its reputation and good name, but remains convinced that the original tax payment was in line with their fiscal obligations.</s>

A 27-year-old man, Michael Luciw, was killed in a car accident caused by a 76-year-old driver, Albert Kenneth Newman, who was driving the wrong way on the motorway. Michael's family believes that older drivers should undergo regular driving tests, while Age UK emphasizes the importance of supporting older people to continue driving safely. Currently, drivers over 70 in the UK must renew their licenses every three years by filling out a self-assessment form, but this does not include a medical or driving test. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) has no plans to restrict licensing based on age, stating that there is no evidence that older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents.</s>

The passage discusses concerns about the safety of implants used to treat incontinence, as many women have experienced debilitating side effects. Two patients quit the original review group, and independent expert Alison Britton will now examine the final report. The report recommends that procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse and that patients should be given a range of treatment options and information to make informed choices. It also suggests that reporting of adverse events should be mandatory. The health secretary confirmed that the recommendations would continue to be implemented, despite calls for a ban. The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for not uniting all panel members around the final report, and over 400 women are currently taking legal action against Scottish health boards and manufacturers as a result of mesh implant surgery.</s>

23-year-old Muir broke McColgan's 25-year-old 5K record by 14 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow, finishing with a time of 14 minutes and 49.12 seconds. McColgan initially questioned whether the race met UK Athletics' criteria for record-breaking attempts, but British Athletics confirmed Muir's time was expected to be classified as official. McColgan praised Muir's performance and believes she has the potential to win world medals.</s>

Jung won the equestrian event on Sam, a late replacement for Fischertakinou who had an infection. Astier Nicolas from France took silver, and Phillip Dutton from the US won bronze. William Fox-Pitt from GB finished 12th, despite being in an induced coma 10 months prior. He led after the dressage phase but dropped to 21st in the cross-country phase. Jonty Evans from Ireland finished ninth.</s>

British tennis player Andy Murray won a tense match against 29th seed Fabio Fognini, securing a place in the last 16 for the 11th time. The match lasted two hours and 39 minutes, with match point clinched at 20:57 BST. Murray will play Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday.</s>

On 6 October 2014, paramedics attended a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven, where alcohol was being served beyond licensing hours. Limavady Magistrates Court charged Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas for allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months and fined Ms. O'Neill £3,000 and Mr. Thomas £1,000. The judge expressed concern over Ms. O'Neill's "appalling record" and the lack of power to impose a custodial sentence.</s>

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionists, launched the party's manifesto, emphasizing partnership over domination. The manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership', includes proposals to tackle waiting lists, increase PSNI numbers, prioritize the York Street interchange, support the LGBT community, and protect groups from Brexit negative impacts. Nesbitt faced questions about his comments on preferring an alliance with the SDLP over Sinn Féin, but denied any regrets or mistakes. The election is seen as a referendum on the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle and the performance of the DUP and Sinn Féin at Stormont.</s>

Justice Minister Claire Sugden announced that a motion will be presented to the assembly for approval, aiming to bring Northern Ireland in line with England and Wales by offering automatic pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences. Dubbed 'Turing's Law', after Alan Turing, the law will allow both posthumous and living pardons for gay and bisexual men. The minister has secured executive agreement to ask the assembly to pass a legislative consent motion for pardons related to abolished sexual offences, with arrangements to be implemented as soon as possible for equal treatment.</s>

A 23-year-old runner from Kinross finished second in a race, setting a new Scottish record and moving her to second on the British all-time list. She now holds the Scottish 1500m and mile records and hopes to secure an Olympics place for Great Britain in Rio.</s>
The passage mentions 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked for their excellent water quality and includes pictures of these beaches.</s>

The passage discusses the case of former Russian spy Alexander Litvinenko, who was poisoned with radioactive polonium-210 in 2006 in London. UK officials believe suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, both Russian nationals, are responsible for the poisoning, but they deny any wrongdoing. Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC argues that the Russian state likely sponsored the plot, as there were many reasons for them to want Litvinenko dead. However, he clarifies that this does not necessarily implicate Russian President Vladimir Putin. Litvinenko had defected to the UK in 2000, accusing the FSB of murder and corruption. Horwell also mentions that the public risk from polonium radiation will never be known and that Litvinenko had been poisoned twice before his death. The suspects have left a "trail of polonium" and have no credible answer to the scientific evidence against them. Despite attempts to extradite the suspects, they remain in Russia, and their trial for murder is unlikely to happen.</s>

The passage announces that Steve Smith, a 26-year-old cricket player, has been appointed as the captain of Australia's one-day and Twenty20 teams on an ongoing basis, following Michael Clarke's retirement. David Warner, another batsman, has been named as Smith's vice-captain. National selector Rod Marsh praises Smith's talent and potential, while also expressing confidence in Warner's ability to handle the added responsibility despite his past disciplinary issues. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in limited-overs matches after the final Ashes Test at the Oval on 20 August.</s>

The passage discusses Tim Farron's stance on LGBT-plus rights and his commitment to defending equal marriage and extending marital rights for transgender people. Despite refusing to answer whether he believed homosexual sex was a sin, he emphasized his support for equality and his role as the leader of a liberal party. He also addressed concerns about his vote against the Equality Bill in 2007, stating that it was due to concerns about "protection of individual liberties" and not because he was against equal access under the law for all people, regardless of their sexuality.</s>

Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses. Accord Healthcare has now taken over the plant for pharmaceutical production, aiming to employ ex-Sanofi staff. The investment is expected to have a positive impact on the area, and Newcastle City Council leader, Councillor Nick Forbes, praised the announcement as fantastic news for Newcastle and the North East, highlighting Accord's global presence and the boost to the local economy. Accord Healthcare produces over 130 pharmaceutical products for around 60 countries.</s>

Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland are leaving their positions at the local authority due to the end of Ellis' contract and voluntary redundancy and early retirement for Monaghan and Sutherland. Stephen Flynn, the leader of the opposition SNP group, believes this reflects the council's inability to retain senior staff and anticipates more departures in the future. Ellis was the council's former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, while Monaghan and Sutherland held positions in the chief executive's office and human resources and customer services, respectively. Council chief executive Angela Scott expressed gratitude for their dedication and professionalism.</s>

The English rider crashed at this year's TT and the Fireblade bike has been plagued by mechanical problems. Martin initially announced he was quitting road racing but later clarified his position, stating he hasn't given up on racing but won't do any more road racing on Hondas this year. He didn't race at the North West 200 and won't compete in the Ulster Grand Prix. Martin described the TT as a disaster and said the bike won't be competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix, leading the team to withdraw him from the event.</s>

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in Nigeria's recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on 29 May after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP's decline has been reinforced by results from Saturday's elections for governors and state assemblies. The party lost for the first time in key northern states and failed to get a national spread of votes. The APC made historic gains, relegating the once-powerful PDP to a regional party. However, the APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could be a concern for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari due to the potential for militant groups to disrupt oil production.</s>

Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, accuses agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek, of turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices that may contribute to the annual haze caused by fires in Indonesia. Olam and Temasek reject the allegations. Olam claims to have a "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" compliance policy and insists that its suppliers meet strict requirements. Temasek states that it does not direct the business operations of its portfolio companies, including Olam. The palm oil industry is projected to be worth $88bn by 2022 but is often accused of unfair and illegal labour practices, deforestation, and the burning of plantations.</s>
Summary: A restaurant started serving puppy platters outdoors after a new law allowed dogs to eat at restaurants.</s>

Fernando Forestieri may miss the game due to a knee injury, while David Nugent might return after missing the last match. Jacob Butterfield aims for a recall after scoring a late equalizer in the previous game.</s>

The ban on YouTube in Pakistan has been lifted after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of the platform. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) confirmed that all internet service providers have been directed to open access to YouTube. While many young Pakistanis have welcomed the decision, some activists are calling for greater transparency in the deal between Google and the government. YouTube has stated that government requests for content removal will not be automatically granted and will be recorded in their Transparency Report. The ban was initially imposed in 2012 after the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims" was uploaded.</s>

Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is facing pressure to withdraw due to a potential conflict of interest as he shares nationality with one of the presidential candidates, Gianni Infantino. LFA boss Musa Bility has threatened to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. The election to replace long-standing president Blatter will take place in 18 days.</s>

Two men, Daniel Timbers and Barry Joy, were killed at Harford Attachments in a suspected flashover explosion, which caused a fire-ball effect. The company, which manufactures buckets for diggers, underwent a forensic search and witness statements were obtained. The Health and Safety Executive is also gathering evidence.</s>

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations until apologising to Caf for complaints lodged against the organisation during the 2015 Nations Cup. Morocco was able to enter the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned a ban on its participation. Morocco's FA fine was reduced from $1m to $50,000. Tunisia's participation in the 2017 Nations Cup seemed in doubt until a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou in Senegal led to a resolution. Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will face Cape Verde, Libya and Sao Tome in Group F.</s>

In the 95th minute of a game at Etihad Stadium, Chelsea won 3-1, a mass fracas occurred. City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off, while Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas faced no further action. Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's involvement. Aguero received a four-match ban for his second violent conduct dismissal this season. Fernandinho got a three-match ban for clashing with Fabregas. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.</s>

The passage discusses a pilot program in Cwm Taf and Castell-nedd focusing on the consequences of early-stage cancer in Wales. The program aims to detect cancer in family doctors who may not show any clear symptoms or signs. This comes after a visit by doctors to Denmark to learn about their diagnostic systems, which has improved early-stage cancer rates. The program involves referring patients to a diagnostic center at the Royal National Hospital for Wales, Llantrisant, within seven days, where six clinics will be held each week. Currently, only 35% of patients with "peripheral" symptoms are diagnosed in the Cwm Taf area. The program aims to reach the majority of patients without clear symptoms of the disease. A clinig trial will be established at Port Talbot's Ysbyty Castell-nedd as part of another trial by Swansea Bay NHS Board. The trial was developed during the 12 months that Welsh patients traveled to Aarhus. Denmark established diagnostic centers after realizing the country was lagging in early-stage cancer rates. Dr. Gareth Davies, Director of Cancer Network Wales, says the program will not only change the mindset but also streamline the process. Gareth Jordan, a family doctor in Aberdar, says the pilot program could make a significant difference in patients' lives. If the Cwm Taf pilot program succeeds, health boards in the area will offer the same service in the following months.</s>

England won the second Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England made 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, setting up their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment, stating that the team is short of confidence and struggled with shot selection.</s>

Head coach Warren Gatland has named interim coach Rob Howley for the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand, with forwards coach McBryde assuming head coach responsibilities for the third time. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour, and union chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team.</s>

Hull City secured their first league win since 20 August, ending a six-game losing streak with a 2-1 victory over Southampton. Charlie Austin's sixth-minute penalty initially put Saints in control, but Hull's Robert Snodgrass and Michael Dawson scored two quick goals in the second half to turn the game around. Despite Southampton's late push for an equalizer, Hull's goalkeeper David Marshall made several crucial saves, and Sam Clucas produced a goalline clearance in added time to secure the win.</s>

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, at around 14:15 BST. The tractor driver was unharmed, and Lincolnshire Police are seeking witnesses. The B1191 was closed between Woodhall Spa and Horncastle junctions.</s>

The passage discusses the cancellation of an investigation into claims of abuse of power in Macedonia by President Ivanov, which was met with condemnation from the opposition and EU officials. The crisis began with the release of covert recordings in 2015, revealing alleged vote-rigging and cover-up of a murder. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev has been releasing recordings accusing the government of corruption, while the government denies the accusations and accuses Zaev of trying to destabilize the nation.</s>

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley's sacking. Swansea aims to appoint a new boss quickly, with ex-Derby manager Paul Clement as the first choice. The club faces the possibility of relegation and recognizes the difficulty of returning to the Premier League. Swansea's current situation contrasts with their rise to the Premier League in 2011 and their exciting, possession-based football. Curtis believes the club lost its way after Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014 and has seen a change in management and loss of key players. Despite these challenges, Curtis believes the current squad is capable of staying in the Premier League.</s>

The Daggers faced relegation after losing to the O's, with goals from Jay Simpson, Armand Gnanduillet, Jamie Cureton, and Clevid Dikamona. Dagenham and Redbridge, who reached League One in 2010, now return to the National League under manager John Still. Despite struggling this season, Still remains committed to helping the Daggers gain promotion next season. The victory leaves Leyton Orient two points away from the play-off spots, following the removal of player-manager Kevin Nolan from his managerial role.</s>

The passage discusses the former Liverpool captain, Steven Gerrard, who is set to return to his former club as a youth coach in February after retiring as a player. Gerrard has expressed his desire to become a manager in the future and is currently working towards his Uefa A coaching licence. Liverpool manager, Klopp, praised Gerrard's appointment and expressed confidence in his potential as a future manager.</s>

The passage describes a football match where McManus scored first, followed by Forbes' goal, giving Morton a 2-0 lead. Alloa managed to score one goal before half-time. However, Morton secured their victory with two more goals from McManus and Johnstone.</s>

Ofsted has found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three closed illegal schools in Birmingham, with those running such schools facing up to 51 weeks in jail. The Chief Inspector of Schools in England, Sir Michael Wilshaw, expressed concern that children were at risk of abuse or radicalisation. A total of 18 unregulated schools have been visited as part of an investigation, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands. The government has provided funding for a team of six inspectors to investigate illegal schools, and the Education Secretary has asked Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools.</s>

Lilliard Gin, based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is the first whisky distillery in the Scottish Borders since 1837. The gin aims to capture the local flavors and terroir of the Teviot valley, using Borders botanicals. The distillery is a natural companion to the Scottish Borders Brewery on the site and plans to use one of the smallest production stills in the UK. The gin is named after a legendary Borders figure, Lilliard, who was the heroine of the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545.</s>

In August 2013, Harry Whitlam died after being hit by a vehicle driven by Gary Green, who was over twice the legal driving limit, at Swithens Farm, Rothwell. Green, who had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer, was jailed for 16 months and two weeks for failing to ensure the safety of others. The case was prosecuted under health and safety legislation rather than road traffic law as the incident occurred on private land. Harry's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed her hope that her son's life would be remembered for more than just the accident and stated that the family had been "changed forever."</s>

Uruguayan striker Luis Suarez, who recently joined Barcelona, can now train and play in friendly matches after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) reduced his four-month ban for biting Italy's Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup. The CAS ruling still prevents him from playing "organised" matches, but allows him to participate in all "football-related activities." Suarez will have to serve the remaining eight games of his record nine-match ban in competitive international games. His competitive Barcelona debut is likely to be at Real Madrid on 26 October in El Clasico.</s>

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a challenging race against Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene, in which competitors faced a 380-metre course with various obstacles. The couple will represent their country at the World Championships in Finland in July.</s>

The passage discusses the changes in job roles at the DVLA due to the scrapping of the paper system for car tax discs in October. The new electronic system will allow people to pay the charge by monthly direct debit. Minister Stephen Hammond assures that any reductions in staff will be managed through redeployment to other growth areas of the business, and these changes are likely to result from the introduction of a direct debit scheme and the withdrawal of the tax disc.</s>

The EU is objecting to Hungary's tight controls on asylum seekers, NGOs, and a higher education law, which critics say could lead to the closure of the prestigious Central European University. Hungary's government is refusing to backtrack on these issues, stating that they belong to national competence and should not be interfered with by European institutions. Poland has also pledged to veto any EU sanctions against Hungary.</s>

The passage announces the casting of a star as Mrs. Potts in an upcoming film adaptation of Beauty and the Beast, with a release date of 17 March 2017 in US cinemas. Emma Watson stars as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Bill Condon will direct the movie, which begins filming in May at Shepperton Studios.</s>

The passage discusses the life and career of columnist Adrian Gill, who was diagnosed with various cancers and passed away. Gill was known for his wit, fearless writing, and intelligence, and was considered a "giant among journalists." He joined the Sunday Times in 1993 and wrote about coming to terms with his illness in his final column. Many writers, broadcasters, and journalists paid tribute to Gill, acknowledging his contributions to the field. Despite his popular writing, Gill's articles often caused controversy due to his provocative statements. Born in Edinburgh in 1954, Gill overcame dyslexia to become a successful writer, working for Tatler and the Sunday Times. He was married to Amber Rudd, the current Home Secretary, and had four children in total.</s>

Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar was attacked during a performance in Ulan Bator, allegedly by a Russian diplomatic officer. The rapper wore a traditional Mongolian robe with a swastika, which is not a hate symbol in Mongolia but has Nazi associations. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident, calling local press reports "distorted." The rapper's father stated that his son spent 10 days in a coma after the beating, and the suspect has not been arrested.</s>

On Monday, members of Plane Stupid staged a demonstration against an airport's expansion plans, resulting in charges of aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area. They will appear in court on August 19th. The protest occurred on the northern runway at 03:30 BST, and the Metropolitan Police will review security at the airport.</s>

In the match between Glamorgan and Gloucestershire, Glamorgan's total was largely contributed by Nick Selman's 101 runs off 144 balls, his second first-class century. However, seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles ensured regular wickets fell in cloudy conditions. Gloucestershire also struggled as bowlers remained dominant throughout the day. Glamorgan is being led by Michael Hogan in the absence of Jacques Rudolph, who has a neck problem. Both teams ended the day with evenly balanced scores.</s>

Craig Hughes, a 33-year-old man from Flint, was arrested in August after chatting online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee and planning a murder attempt on police officers. He admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. The threats were made while Hughes was drunk, and he had a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009. The court heard that North Wales Police was concerned because Hughes was on bail, awaiting trial for firearms offences, of which he was later cleared.</s>

In a cricket match, Surrey posted a score of 255-7, with Davies and Ben Foakes sharing a stand of 130. Yorkshire's run-chase was hindered by Stuart Meaker's three-wicket burst in nine balls. Yorkshire made a strong start but lost key players, and despite Tim Bresnan's 68, they were all out for 236. Surrey's Gareth Batty praised Davies and Foakes, while Yorkshire's Alex Lees expressed disappointment in not reaching the target.</s>

A 56ft converted trawler experienced water ingress and contacted coastguards at 07:00 BST, 6 miles west of South Stack. Holyhead coastguards provided a pump, and the RNLI lifeboat crew towed the vessel to Holyhead.</s>

The passage discusses Scottish middle-distance runner Laura Muir's decision to prioritize her veterinary medicine studies over participating in the Commonwealth Games next year. Muir, who finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, will be focusing on her final year at university and plans to return to competitive running in the World Indoor Championships in March. Despite missing the Commonwealth Games, Muir believes she has at least two or three more Olympics in her future and is optimistic about her potential for success.</s>

The passage discusses Liverpool's struggles in the current season and how they are far from repeating last season's title challenge. The team has lost key players like Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge, and their replacements have not been up to par. Liverpool's defense is still weak, and their midfield lacks the same intensity as last season. Despite these issues, the author believes that Steven Gerrard can still be a part of Liverpool's long-term future if he can overcome the mental battle of proving himself after his slip against Chelsea last season.</s>

A £45m educational facility will be built at Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock, housing primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. The East Ayrshire Council plans to ask the McIlvanney family for permission to name the campus after the renowned writer, William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. Council leader Douglas Reid expressed his delight in preserving McIlvanney's name in Kilmarnock, as the writer was passionate about providing good education for young people. McIlvanney, known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir," was an English teacher, poet, journalist, and broadcaster before becoming a full-time writer. He passed away at his Glasgow home on 5 December.</s>

An area near a swimming pool in Gourock was evacuated, and residents were advised to stay indoors and avoid going outside due to the presence of a sea mine. The mine, believed to be British and dating from the 1940s or 1950s, was spotted on Monday. The evacuation affected three streets, and an exclusion zone was in place at sea. Ferry services were disrupted, and the Royal Navy's Northern Diving Unit was working to make the mine safe. The evacuation was a precautionary measure, and there was no immediate danger to the community.</s>

UK Sport has cut funding for several sports, including archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby, and badminton, which has led to criticism from Badminton England's chief executive. Cycling, which brought Team GB 12 medals in Rio, has had its funding reduced by over £4m. A total of £345m will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports, £2m less than the £347m allocated for the Rio Games. UK Sport has set Team GB a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo.</s>

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth will be demolished to make way for a new six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. The development, which received support from the council and 246 letters, was opposed by English Heritage and the Ancient Monuments Society due to its impact on the conservation area. However, councillors voted in favor, stating it would help tourism and improve living conditions for older people in the town.</s>

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier, was attacked and killed by Jake Vallely during a night out in Brecon. Vallely, who had been drinking for seven hours, punched and beat Boyd before dragging his body away. Vallely's friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. Vallely will be sentenced on December 8th. The community of Brecon was shocked by the incident, and Boyd's family described him as a loving, caring, and loyal person whose promising career was cut short.</s>

Andrew Travers left his position at Barnet Council after an error caused voters to be turned away from polling stations due to missing names from the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched, and Travers has made a statement acknowledging the issue. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over, and the council's review will conclude by the end of May.</s>

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1 in a football match. Josh Gillies and Ryan Bowman scored for Gateshead, while Sean Newton scored for Wrexham. Gateshead's manager, Malcolm Crosby, praised his team's performance, while Wrexham's manager, Gary Mills, expressed disappointment with his team's second-half performance.</s>
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks the social and economic welfare of people over 60 in 96 countries, with Norway ranking highest and Afghanistan ranking lowest.</s>

The OneWeb project aims to create a network of at least 600 spacecraft, eventually expanding to over 2,000, to provide global broadband links from orbit, with a focus on connecting schools. Airbus is manufacturing these satellites using new assembly line methods to achieve high volume and low cost. The first assembly line is in Toulouse, France, with two more planned in Florida. The OneWeb constellation will require the largest rocket campaign in spaceflight history, with over 20 Soyuz vehicles launching clusters of satellites. The project faces competition from other companies such as SpaceX, Boeing, and ViaSat, but OneWeb believes it has a first-mover advantage.</s>

The UK government's recent spending review has placed "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure in Scotland, according to Mr Swinney. The Scottish government argues that cuts imposed by the UK government since 2010 mean that its discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11. Mr Swinney said 4.2% of that reduction would come between now and 2019-20. The Scottish government is determined to defend and protect key priorities such as schools, hospitals, and the police service in Scotland.</s>

The passage discusses the challenges faced by people with severe disabilities and their families due to the lack of suitable and accessible toilet facilities. Recommendations are in place to support installing Changing Places toilets with enhanced facilities in larger buildings, but campaigners are calling for these to be made compulsory. Currently, there are 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, which are different from standard disabled toilets as they have extra features and more space to meet the needs of people who use them. Campaigners are focusing their efforts on making it compulsory for newly built larger complexes such as shopping centres, cinemas, and sports stadiums in the building regulations.</s>

A group of Italian consumers' organizations has filed a formal complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, accusing the company of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. McDonald's responded by stating that they share risks and rewards with their licensees. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions are supporting the complaint. The European Commission will study the submission and may launch an investigation if they believe the allegations are founded. The consumer organizations claim that franchisees are unable to switch to competitors due to long contracts and above-market lease rates, leading to poorer consumer choice and higher prices in franchise stores compared to company-owned locations.</s>

The passage is about a social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The campaign started as a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father is on the pastoral staff, and has since gone viral. A mystery donor paid for a billboard with the hashtag #prayforjosh in Holywood. The campaign has received support from people all over the world, and Josh's family and friends continue to support him in his recovery.</s>

The UK government has decided to close Brecon Barracks, a historic military site since 1805, as part of a shake-up of military buildings and resettling of regiments. Brecon and Radnorshire Conservative MP Chris Davies condemned the closure, stating that the government has many questions to answer regarding the decision. He also mentioned that he would be launching a petition against the closure. The nearby Sennybridge training ground and infantry school at Dering Lines are not expected to be affected. The reorganisation in Wales will see a specialist light infantry centre created at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan.</s>

The House of Lords European Union Committee has released a report on the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit. The report states that the fishing industry may not be a priority for the government, but it should not be marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The UK and EU coastal states share most commercial fish stocks, and the majority of UK fish are exported to the EU. The report suggests that continued market access may come at a price, as EU member states may demand more access to UK waters in exchange for maintaining zero tariffs on fish sales to the European market. The report also highlights the potential for four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland after Brexit.</s>

Ed Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, revealed himself as the source of leaks exposing the US National Security Agency's (NSA) extensive surveillance activities. The NSA had access to individual chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data of individuals. The US government confirmed it requested millions of phone records from Verizon, including call duration, location, and phone numbers. The NSA also had "backdoor" access to the servers of major technology companies such as Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, and Apple. These companies denied their involvement, and the true extent of Prism's powers remains unclear. Different countries have varying data protection laws, but most individual company privacy policies include clauses allowing information sharing if legally obliged. User data is often stored in the US under the US Patriot Act of 2001, which gives American authorities new powers over European data. It is unknown whether other governments, such as the UK, have access to Prism. Privacy concerns surrounding internet use have been a longstanding issue, and the existence of Prism raises further concerns about potential privacy violations.</s>

The passage discusses OpenAI, a venture backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, which aims to advance digital intelligence for the benefit of humanity without financial obligations. While some scientists, like Stephen Hawking, warn that AI could threaten humanity, others believe the risk is remote. OpenAI's statement emphasizes the potential positive impact of AI, but also acknowledges the potential for harm if not built or used correctly. The venture plans to spend only a small portion of the $1 billion pledged in the near future.</s>

In 2006, L/Bdr Parkinson was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan. Since carrying the Olympic torch on 26 June, he has received thousands of friend requests on Facebook, but is limited to 5,000 due to site restrictions. Despite a brain injury affecting his speech, Parkinson's intelligence, wit, and sense of humor remain unchanged. He spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab, walks with crutches, and raises money for military charities. His mother, Diane, expressed gratitude for the overwhelming support and friendship shown to her son. Facebook suggested creating a page or using subscribe as alternatives for public figures like Parkinson.</s>

In 2011, the poverty rate in the US remained at 15%, with 46.2 million people in poverty. Real median income dropped by 1.5%, and the average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality increased by 1.6%, and the percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased from 16.3% to 15.7%. Poverty reached a record high in 2010 at 15.1%.</s>

The passage discusses a 25-year-old cricketer who moved to the Red Rose from Somerset in 2013 and has recently signed a new deal with the club until 2019. This short-format specialist has scored England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball ton against Pakistan. Cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles praises the player's talent and contributions to the team, mentioning his presence in the T20 Blast final as a factor in their victory. The player, who also plays in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, is set to return to Lancashire for a T20 Blast home game against Durham.</s>

The passage discusses the decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall, which are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to register their interest in the ships, and no proposals for preservation have been submitted yet. Viewings are set to take place in late February and March, with a final decision expected in the spring. The government's Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one of the frigates to a UK ship recycler to assess the capacity of the UK's industry in this field. Conservative MP Penny Mordaunt is keen to see at least one of the ships saved from the scrapyard and turned into a reef and diving attraction. The Ministry of Defence will consider all options to ensure the best financial return for the taxpayer.</s>

The passage discusses the history of political and racial tensions in Fiji since 1987, which have led to instability and international isolation. It mentions several coups, including one in 1987 by indigenous Fijians and another in 2000 led by George Speight, both of which negatively impacted the economy and tourism industry. Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth in 2009 due to lack of progress towards democracy but restored ties after agreeing to hold free elections in 2014. The population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with the former now forming a small overall majority. The economy is diverse but has faced persistent trade and budget deficits, making it a significant recipient of aid.</s>

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister, Faisal al-Mekdad, stated that the country is doing its best to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, despite missing the deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. He mentioned that a shipment of weapons was attacked twice on its way to the port of Latakia and emphasized the need for the US and others to consider the ongoing war in Syria. Al-Mekdad also criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of the government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported casualties in Aleppo due to barrel bomb attacks, while the Syrian government denied bombarding civilian areas. The government also denied reports of rebels seizing most of Aleppo's central prison, though the situation remains uncertain. Russia has set a deadline for the transfer of Syria's chemical weapons to be completed by 1 March, with all weapons to be destroyed by the end of June. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) has acknowledged that security concerns have slowed down the process.</s>

The Man Booker Prize shortlist for 2014 includes Mukherjee's The Lives of Others, a sweeping account of life in 1960s Calcutta, which is the 5/2 favorite to win with bookmakers William Hill. This is the first year the prize is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night. Other authors on the shortlist include former Booker winner Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler, and Richard Flanagan.</s>

A celebrity, referred to as PJS, is appealing against a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban on him being named in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will hear arguments about whether to grant an appeal and decide if it should be allowed or dismissed. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish an account of alleged extra-marital activities by PJS, but he argues he has a right to privacy. The Court of Appeal judges said the celebrity had "occasional sexual encounters" with another person, referred to as AB, starting in 2009. The judges ruled that PJS was now unlikely to be able to get a permanent injunction as the details about the allegations were now "so widespread" that confidentiality had "probably been lost".</s>

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1, was purchased for £345.5m in August. The new owners are planning improvements to parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of units. They have met with Blaby District Council to address potential planning questions. The owners aim to enhance the park's appearance as it serves as the gateway from Blaby into the city. Crown Estates, the new owners, are focused on addressing parking and congestion issues and improving the quality of common areas and facilities to make Fosse Park as good as it can be.</s>

The film "Beauty and the Beast" sparked controversy in Malaysia due to its "gay moment." Although the Malaysian Censorship Board approved the film with a minor edit, the release date has not been announced. The live-action remake received a "P13 parental guidance classification." Local cinema chains have offered refunds for customers who purchased tickets in advance. The "gay moment" involves LeFou, the sidekick of the film's main antagonist Gaston, who struggles with feelings for Gaston. The decision to review the film in Malaysia received criticism from netizens.</s>

Landlords in Southampton must obtain a license for Houses of Multiple Occupation (HMO) if they rent to more than three unrelated people, but many avoid this due to the £1,000 license cost, despite facing fines up to £20,000. Southampton City Council estimates 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Shelter helpline adviser Nadeem Khan said tenants often fear eviction and live in poorly maintained properties. Mandatory licensing for HMOs nationally applies to houses with three or more stories and occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, licenses affect specific areas and have been introduced in two designations since 2013 and 2015. The council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for not obtaining licenses.</s>

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny and Micheál Martin aim to prevent a second election by forming a minority government. However, they disagree on water charges, with Fianna Fáil advocating for removal and Fine Gael supporting their role. A commission to consider the future of Irish Water is being considered as a proposal. After the election, Fine Gael had 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and the Labour Party 7, but no party could form a majority government, and a Taoiseach has not been elected.</s>

The Sorrento, a ferry traveling to Valencia, caught fire and quickly escalated, forcing passengers to evacuate onto lifeboats. They were later rescued by another ship. At least three people were injured and taken to the hospital. The fire started on one of the car decks, and the cause is unknown. Several ships, including two passenger ferries, assisted in the rescue. The passengers boarded the Puglia ferry and were en route to Palma de Mallorca. Psychologists were requested to provide counseling at the port. The Sorrento may sink due to the fire, and the ferry's owner, Atlantica di Navigazione, sent out distress signals. The captain initially believed the ship could be saved, but the fire became too intense, leading to a full evacuation.</s>

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs had identified cases of people, including students, voting twice, which is a criminal offense. The watchdog suggested that individual electoral registers should be better connected to help identify duplicate entries. A record number of 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the 8 June election, with 68.7% voting on the day. Concerns over duplicate applications persist, as there is no direct link between electoral registers and the online registration service. The watchdog recommended clearer information on registration sites and a verification function, similar to that used in Australia, New Zealand, and the Republic of Ireland.</s>

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player and University of Nebraska star, killed himself in prison at the age of 40. He had a troubled past, both on and off the field, and was serving a 30-year sentence for assault convictions. Recently, he was accused of killing his cellmate and was about to face trial for another inmate's death. Despite his intelligence and some positive qualities, Phillips struggled with anger issues and could not overcome the challenges in his life.</s>

Lance Corporal Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted for good behavior at an event in Chester. He is the 30th mascot in a line dating back to the Indian Mutiny War and joined the regiment in 2014. Derby XXX has his own army number, gets paid for rations, and takes holidays during the mating season. He has participated in events such as switching on Christmas lights and meeting Prince William at a memorial unveiling.</s>

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory against Borussia Dortmund, moving closer to earning a place in the Champions League. The match was played at Anfield, with Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp's passionate touchline demeanour and the young coach Thomas Tuchel from Borussia Dortmund. The win showcased the transition from doubt to belief within Liverpool, both on and off the pitch. The match was filled with emotion, drama, and brilliant football, with Liverpool's Dejan Lovren scoring the winning goal in injury time.</s>

The EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee met in London, where Mr. Davis stated that the UK government would keep Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed about negotiations. Mr. Russell called for transparency from the UK government and emphasized the importance of single market membership for Scotland's economic prosperity. Mr. Davis proposed monthly meetings to share analysis and views with the devolved administrations as the Westminster government prepares talks with Brussels. The Scottish government plans to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court during the appeal of the High Court judgment on Article 50.</s>

The passage describes a group of 13 cloned sheep, including four identical twin sisters of Dolly the sheep, living on a University of Nottingham farm. These sheep are undergoing extensive physical examinations and tests to determine if cloning causes premature aging and related health issues. The results of the study could have significant implications for the future of cloning.</s>

The passage discusses a horse race where the unbeaten 4-7 favorite, Shutter Speed, won and will be going to Chantilly next instead of the Oaks at Epsom. Trainer John Gosden has other top contenders, Enable and Coronet, for the Oaks. Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes, and Gosden is concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes.</s>

The passage discusses the volatility of the pound sterling in the context of the Brexit referendum. The currency initially fell against the dollar and euro but recovered before falling again. The "volatility index" reached levels last seen during the 2008 financial crisis. The Leave campaign argued that the pound's decline was due to it returning to March levels. Investors were concerned about the chances of a Remain vote and global economic worries. Two weekend polls showed the Leave camp ahead, and the implied probability of a vote to Remain fell. The outcome of the referendum is expected to cause further volatility in the pound. The FTSE 100 ended the day down 1.1%, while Asian stock markets also experienced a decline. Nigel Farage argued that a weaker pound was beneficial for UK exporters, as it had led to a narrowing of the UK trade deficit in April.</s>

The Iron are currently sixth in the National League, just outside the play-off spots. They faced a challenging match against a strong Barrow team, conceding a goal early on. Despite the loss, Cowley remains positive about their performance and the team's potential in their toughest challenge yet.</s>

The passage discusses the controversial move of putting politicians in charge of most planning decisions in Northern Ireland, starting from April 2015.
