The passage describes Qatar Airways, headquartered in Doha, operating a hub-and-spoke network connecting over 150 international destinations across various regions from its base at Hamad International Airport, using a fleet of more than 200 aircraft.</s>
Maxthon is the second most popular browser in China with over 400 million downloads worldwide.</s>
Maxthon is the second most popular browser in China with over 500 million downloads worldwide.</s>

The passage states that there have been more cases, deaths, and recoveries from a certain situation than have been reported worldwide. Specifically, over 16,700 people have died, and over 102,000 have recovered.</s>
Summary: Over 392,000 cases, 17,100 deaths, and 102,000 recoveries reported globally.</s>

Paul Merson reignited his feud with Andros Townsend after the Tottenham midfielder was brought on late in a 0-0 draw with Burnley. Merson had previously criticized Townsend's inclusion in the England team, but admitted he was wrong when Townsend scored a goal against Italy. However, Merson took another dig at Townsend on Twitter following the recent match against Burnley.</s>

Chelsea has made a formal offer for 22-year-old FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto, who will join Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season if he completes a move to Stamford Bridge. FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane claims Chelsea's interest in Muto is not connected to their £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who recently graduated with an economics degree from Keio University, would be the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea if he moves to the Premier League club.</s>

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in their first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. Researchers suggest that antibiotics may contribute to the obesity epidemic by affecting gut bacteria and appetite. The study did not prove causation, but the association between antibiotic exposure and increased body mass in children raises concerns about the judicious use of antibiotics in infancy.</s>

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard, an incident caught on camera by a tourist. The embarrassed soldier quickly stood up as his colleagues marched past, but he blushed when he realized how many people had witnessed his fall. The guard is thought to have slipped due to metal protectors on his boots.</s>

The passage discusses the reimagining of the 1977 TV miniseries "Roots," which had an audience of over 100 million viewers. A&E networks are set to remake the miniseries in 2016, with LeVar Burton, who portrayed Kunta Kinte in the original, co-executive producing the new version. The new miniseries will be "original" and "contemporary," drawing more from Alex Haley's novel, and will consult scholars for added authenticity. The remade "Roots" aims to reach both fans of the original and a new generation who may not be familiar with the story or its importance.</s>

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, has accused palace aides of attempting to force him into an orgy on his first day at Clarence House in 1978. He claims he was pinned to a chair and groped by a male staff member, which left him in tears and prompted him to leave the job that day. Lawler's complaints were allegedly ignored for months before being notified to the police. The Royal Household has stated that they will work cooperatively with any police investigation.</s>

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song of the '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, featuring the couple rapping in a car, has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube. The Meeks made the video to share the news with loved ones living far away. They may create another video after finding out the gender of their child.</s>

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind was auctioned for $137,000. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble featured a black zigzag applique and was worn in several key scenes. The outfit was part of a private collection of over 150 items from the film, owned by James Tumblin, who began collecting memorabilia in the 1960s. Other top-selling items included a straw hat worn by Leigh, trousers and jacket from a suit worn by Clark Gable, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland.</s>

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. The child was rescued by his parents before firefighters and paramedics arrived on the scene. He suffered minor bumps and bruises and was listed in stable condition at the hospital. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family.</s>

A speed camera that was previously used to enforce the 30mph speed limit on a residential road in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been angled directly at a house after not working for two years. The camera was among 300 speed and traffic cameras turned off across the West Midlands in March 2013, as they used outdated technology. Birmingham City Council is now aware of the issue and plans to take appropriate action, including possibly removing the camera.</s>

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medalist, will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3 as part of the Jamaican team. He expressed his excitement and readiness for the event, stating that he always does his best to make his country proud. The Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association is pleased with Bolt's availability for selection, and the full Jamaican team list will be announced shortly.</s>

Neymar and Dani Alves, Barcelona football team-mates, showed their support for the club's basketball team by attending an El Clasico match alongside Neymar's sister, Rafaella. The match ended with a narrow 85-80 victory for Barcelona in the Euro League contest, but Real Madrid still leads the division by a small points difference. Neymar recently helped Brazil secure a 1-0 win over Chile at the Emirates Stadium, and Barcelona is currently leading La Liga. The team is aiming to win a treble of trophies and will face Celta Vigo in their next match.</s>

Italy is currently dealing with a large number of migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe. From Friday to Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued by the Italian coast guard. Save the Children fears that 400 migrants may be missing after their ship capsized in the Mediterranean Sea. The Italian coast guard has not yet found evidence to confirm this incident. There has been a recent increase in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean into Italy, with the Italian Coast Guard performing more rescues. According to the International Organization for Migration, over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first three months of 2015, and about 2,000 were rescued during the first weekend of April. Most migrants come from West African countries, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. At least 480 migrants have died while crossing the Mediterranean this year due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels used by smugglers.</s>

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is glad that Alexis Sanchez chose to play for Arsenal instead of Liverpool. Sanchez had his choice of clubs after Barcelona decided to let him leave and had interest from several elite clubs. He eventually chose Arsenal and has made an instant impact in English football, scoring 19 goals so far this season. Wenger believes Sanchez's quick adaptation to a new environment proves his quality as a player.</s>

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break the cycling hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The current record of 52.491km was set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins, who has three Olympic gold medals in track cycling, aims to motivate people to challenge themselves and aims for a capacity crowd of 6,000 spectators during his attempt.</s>

Serena Williams, a twice French Open champion, struggled to beat Sara Errani in the Fed Cup on Sunday, winning 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3. Despite her victory, Williams admitted that the match was an "eye-opener" as she was not as prepared for the claycourt season as she thought. The US team was defeated 3-2, resulting in their relegation to World Group II. Williams' doubles defeat marked a flaw in her otherwise perfect Fed Cup record, and the US team now faces a challenge to return to the elite nations next year.</s>

River Plate is interested in signing Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, who previously played for the Argentine side for four seasons. River Plate's vice president, Matias Patanian, has expressed the club's desire to have Falcao return, stating that "the doors are open." However, a deal is complicated, and it is uncertain whether Manchester United will keep Falcao or send him back to his parent club, Monaco. Despite his struggles in the Premier League, Falcao has been in good form for Colombia's national team, scoring three goals in two games.</s>

X Factor finalist and pop star Ella Henderson has been announced as the official face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson showcasing various hairstyles against a blurred city background. The partnership between the singer and the UK's number 1 dry shampoo brand was facilitated by the MILES agency and launched with a TV advertising campaign featuring her single, Mirror Man.</s>

A billboard featuring Officer Pablo Torres, who fatally shot Aaron Siler last month, was erected in Kenosha, Wisconsin, causing shock and outrage among Siler's family and friends. Torres is on leave pending the outcome of the investigation into the shooting. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, thanks the community for its support. Siler's family and friends have called the billboard disrespectful and are asking for it to be taken down.</s>

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the border with Pakistan. The militants, who crossed from Pakistan, were fought by Iranian forces in the town of Negur. A group called Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility for the attack. The group is an anti-Iranian Sunni Muslim group that targets Shiites and aims to thwart Iranian influence in Pakistan. Iran has criticized Pakistan for not controlling the terrorists, while Pakistan condemned the attack and promised to apprehend the militants if they entered their territory.</s>

The Japanese government's top military official revealed that the country's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object. This statement was made in response to a question from former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki. Defense Minister Gen Nakatani stated that while the ASDF detects unidentified flying objects that could violate Japan's airspace, they have never found any that originated from outer space.</s>

A passenger at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in China was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after a toilet he was standing on collapsed. The man, Jin Pai, was concerned about the cleanliness of the seat and had been standing on the rim of the toilet when it shattered on the floor. He was too embarrassed to shout for help and was eventually taken to the hospital for multiple stitches. Authorities believe the incident was an accident and reminded people that toilets are for sitting, not standing.</s>

A 56-year-old Pennsylvania man, Kevin Rebbie, was arrested for allegedly sexually abusing a girl for four years and filming her and others with a hidden camera in a bathroom. The investigation began when the 15-year-old victim found the camera and Rebbie faces multiple charges, including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The videos captured by the camera were uploaded to Rebbie's computer and included close-up images of children's genitalia. His preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1 and he is being held on a $500,000 bail.</s>

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's latest series of images captures teenage daughters smiling directly into the camera next to their leaping fathers, showcasing the fathers' fun side. The images are part of a book titled "Daughter and Salaryman" and feature fathers in sharp suits and daughters in casual clothing posing in front of various Japanese landmarks. The project has gained significant online interest for its unique and curious nature.</s>

The passage discusses the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director and the shift in focus to the county championship season. Kevin Pietersen, who was controversially axed from the England team in 2014, posed for a Surrey team photo and appeared in deep thought, possibly reflecting on his potential return to the England set-up. Pietersen has rejoined Surrey in an attempt to force his way back into the Test team, as England hopes to regain the Ashes urn this summer on home soil.</s>

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a relegation-threatened Romanian club, has fired Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. The decision came after a poor run and a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani. Ze Maria, a former Inter Milan and Parma right back, had been reinstated the day before by owner Angelo Massone. He will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.</s>

Nabil Dirar, Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate, believes that Falcao regrets his failed loan move to Manchester United, despite not being happy in France. Falcao, who suffered a serious knee injury, has struggled to score goals for Manchester United. United would have to pay £46 million to make Falcao's transfer permanent, but it is unlikely they will do so. Dirar thinks Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he would have played in the Champions League and had a better atmosphere.</s>

A man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and an orange sweatshirt robbed a Christchurch dairy, taking the cash register and about $1,500 in cash. The police are appealing to the public for help in identifying the offender, who was seen on security footage and is described as very tall. The robbery occurred on Saturday when the masked man demanded cash from the dairy owner's daughter, causing her to flee the shop and alert the police.</s>

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice for inappropriate relationships with 15-year-old students. The first arrest occurred on March 19, after she admitted to kissing a student and allowing him to touch her breasts in April the previous year. She was released on bail. Granado was arrested again on Monday for allegedly having sex with another 15-year-old student on two consecutive nights in January. She was released after posting a $50,000 bail. Granado is currently on administrative leave and cannot work with students or be present on any Irving ISD property.</s>

A video of a large crocodile swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its mouth has been viewed over half a million times online. The incident occurred while New Zealander Tim Weston was on holiday with his wife. The crocodile, a common sight in the area, held onto the dog for hours before releasing it. The dog belonged to the local bike shop's owner, and the crocodile's sanctuary is located 200 meters up the river.</s>

Steve Bruce, Hull City's manager, is confident that he can keep the team in the Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat by Southampton. Hull City has six games left to avoid relegation, and Bruce believes that they can achieve this by maintaining a positive attitude. He attributes the team's struggles to long-term injuries to key players. Southampton's win moved them up to fifth place in the table.</s>

A teacher, Ian Guffick, has been banned from the classroom for at least two years after he allowed pupils to change their exam answers, invalidating the whole school's SATs results. The incident occurred at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire. Guffick altered some of the students' exam answers himself before submitting the papers. After an investigation by the local education authority, the Department for Education annulled the school's SATs exam results for the previous year. Guffick admitted to the allegations and accepted that his actions amounted to unacceptable professional conduct.</s>

Anders Lindegaard, a Manchester United goalkeeper, enjoys time with his wife, Misse Beqiri, a Swedish model. The couple married in a beach wedding in Mauritius and have a son together. Lindegaard has struggled for playing time at Manchester United, making only 19 league appearances in five seasons. He is currently third-choice at Old Trafford.</s>

The glowing blue letters that once lit the Bronx from above Yankee Stadium failed to find a buyer at a Sotheby's auction. The 13 letters were expected to bring in $300,000 to $600,000, but the only bid came from a Sotheby's employee for $260,000. The current owner is Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who purchased the 10-feet-tall letters for an undisclosed amount after the stadium's final game in 2008. Jackson said he wanted a new generation to own and enjoy the iconic signage.</s>

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has reminded Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities after they were seen with shisha pipes. Sterling, who will lead Liverpool's line at Wembley, was also exposed for inhaling nitrous oxide. Rodgers spoke to the players but will not discipline them, instead focusing on the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa.</s>

Arsenal playmaker Mesut Ozil returned to London after Germany's 2-0 win against Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier. He posted a picture on Twitter relaxing with his dog and is now focusing on the upcoming Premier League match against Liverpool. Ozil, who was signed for £42.5 million in 2013, missed Arsenal's game against Newcastle due to illness but is expected to start against Liverpool. Since January, he has scored three goals and made four assists, and he says he is adjusting well to English football.</s>

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has stated that the club has no plans to replace manager Luis Enrique, as they are 'very happy' with his performance. Enrique, who took charge last summer and signed a two-year-deal, is close to winning the La Liga title. Despite speculation about his replacement, Bartomeu praised Enrique's work and mentioned that the club is capable of winning three trophies this season.</s>

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, has agreed to a new long-term contract with the club, worth around £100,000-a-week and running until 2020. This comes after the club's FA Cup heartache and follows contract extensions for Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. Henderson's excellent form this season has led to speculation that he may replace Steven Gerrard as club captain when Gerrard moves to LA Galaxy. Talks with Raheem Sterling are not expected to resume until the end of the season.</s>

Filipe Luis, a full back at Chelsea, wants to stay with the club until the end of his contract despite Atletico Madrid considering re-signing him in the summer. He has struggled to secure the left back position at Chelsea, but is happy at the club. Luis played in Brazil's friendly wins against France and Chile and is now focusing on the Premier League title run-in. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is urging the team to stay focused and concentrate on winning every game.</s>

Nathan Hughes had his ban for accidentally knocking out George North overturned on appeal after an outcry on his behalf. Initially suspended for three matches, Hughes was found to be 'reckless' for failing to prevent his knee from colliding with North's head. However, the appeal lodged by Wasps was upheld, and the ban was thrown out. Many observers and players defended Hughes, stating there was no intent in the accident.</s>

A fiery sunset in Washington caught the attention of Seattle native Tim Durkan, who photographed and shared aerial shots of the sunset on CNN iReport. The stunning sunsets were caused by wildfires in parts of Siberia, which started in southeastern Siberia due to farmers burning grass in their fields. The fires quickly grew out of control on April 14, destroying dozens of villages in the region. Rescue crews extinguished the flames, but the lingering smoke was carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest. The smoke particles filtered out shorter wavelength colors from the sunlight, resulting in intense red sunsets. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the reddish hue of the sunsets will fade.</s>

A Missouri mom, Becky Schoenig, had her new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. The car was found by police after a tip from a man who recognized it. The car had been modified with red rims, red detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig thanked the thieves on Facebook and had the car professionally cleaned due to the smell of cigarettes and marijuana. She also created a smoothie at her restaurant to honor the man who located and returned her car.</s>

Manchester City players will lose £500,000 each in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. The club gives star players incentivised contracts to ensure they stay within financial fairplay requirements. Manchester City is currently in fourth place, and the top three finishers in the Premier League automatically qualify for the Champions League. The City squad has around £12 million at stake, depending on their European finish.</s>

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 in the 'mini-derby' with Callum Gribbin scoring the winning goal through a free-kick. The match took place at Altrincham's 6,000-capacity home, and featured a formation similar to that used by the first team. Both teams showcased local talent, with the result leaving United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League end-of-season play-off series.</s>

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised fellow goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon, calling him a "legend of the game" after Buffon earned his 147th cap. Hart, who celebrated his 50th cap, expressed admiration for Buffon and said he continues to learn from him.</s>

Mexican restaurant Chipotle has decided to enter the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to deliver burritos to customers' doors in 67 cities. The delivery service will have a nine percent service charge, with fees starting at $5 and increasing based on distance and demand. Chipotle has previously turned down offers to collaborate with third-party delivery services, but has now approved Postmates, which uses independent contractors driving their own cars. Other franchises, such as Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King, are also exploring delivery services.</s>

The parents of the youngest victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings are urging the Justice Department to take the death penalty off the table for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the man convicted in the case. In a front-page opinion piece in The Boston Globe, Bill and Denise Richard wrote about the toll taken on their family after the death of their 8-year-old son, Martin, and the severe injury of their daughter, Jane. They understand the "heinousness and brutality of the crimes committed" but are in favor of the defendant spending the rest of his life in prison without any possibility of release and waiving all of his rights to appeal. The sentencing phase begins after the conviction on all 30 charges faced by Tsarnaev.</s>

A mystery billionaire has converted an enormous jumbo jet into a luxury home, complete with bedrooms, multiple lounges, and an onboard restaurant. The custom-built Boeing 747 cost £400 million and was customized over a three-year period. The plane can accommodate dozens of guests and features a large dining room, a lounge, a state room, and an aeroloft with eight full beds. The interior resembles a top hotel, with a conference room, an executive room, and a main suite. The luxurious private plane is far more glitzy than first class on commercial flights.</s>

SpaceX successfully launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed cargo spacecraft, Dragon, from Cape Canaveral to the International Space Station. However, the company was unsuccessful in its attempt to land the rocket stage on a floating barge for the first time, as it landed but tipped over. SpaceX aims to reduce the cost of access to space by reusing rockets like airplanes. The Dragon will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the space station, including an espresso maker, and will later return with over 3,000 pounds of science experiments, trash, and other items. This is the sixth SpaceX mission to the International Space Station.</s>

Priscilla Presley will serve as a witness at the first wedding at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas, which was launched through a contest with NBC's Today show. The winning couple will be announced next Monday and will marry on April 23. The winners will also receive a free wedding reception, two-night hotel suite, airfares, and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla emphasized that this is a first-class event and not a joke.</s>

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after a 2-0 win over Newcastle United. Both Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignoet played their 47th game of the season, equaling the record for appearances in the top five European leagues. Manchester City is currently four points ahead of Liverpool, but they have been faltering, losing 4-2 to Manchester United. Henderson is optimistic about Liverpool's chances, stating that they will continue to win games and put in strong performances.</s>

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home with a victory over Napoli in Serie A, moving provisionally four points ahead of city rivals Lazio. Miralem Pjanic scored the winning goal in the 25th minute, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several crucial saves in the second half. Napoli's winless streak was extended to five matches, and they remained in fifth place.</s>

The passage describes a dull and uneventful League One match between Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town, which ended in a 0-0 draw. The match was so uninteresting that Doncaster's media team struggled to create highlights, eventually releasing a 27-second video with only 14 seconds of gameplay.</s>

The passage describes a man named Roland Giroux who has a unique bond with his blood parrot cichlid fish. He interacts with the fish by gently cupping it in his hand, massaging it, and feeding it frozen blood worms. The fish, which was initially bullied by other fish in the tank, has become more sociable and enjoys these daily interactions. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid of the midas and the redhead cichlid, first bred in Taiwan around 1986.</s>

Ben Stokes, a fiery character in the England cricket team, has returned to the team after a year of ups and downs. Stokes has a reputation for his aggression, which can be both positive and negative. England coach Peter Moores has provided guidance on how to manage Stokes' aggression, and the team wants to help him reach his full potential without quashing his natural exuberance.</s>

The passage discusses the highly anticipated Euro 2016 qualifier match between Wales and Belgium, which has been declared a 33,000 sell-out. Both teams have 11 points from five games, with Belgium in the top spot due to a better goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel has increased expectations for their chances of qualifying for the 2016 finals in France. The match will be held at the Cardiff City Stadium, as the Wales squad prefers playing there rather than the larger Millennium Stadium.</s>

The England coach, John Peacock, has announced the squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where the Young Lions are the defending champions. The team has a 100% record in qualifying and is placed in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. They will open their campaign against Italy on May 7. The squad includes talented young players from various Premier League clubs, such as Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo from Chelsea, and the Arsenal duo Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, who is called up for the first time. Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold have earned a recall after missing the Elite Round of qualifiers.</s>

Manchester City is interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is also sought after by Arsenal and Barcelona. Patoulidis previously rejected a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy to focus on his studies. City has discussed a compensation package with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock, as manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to secure the young talent for the future.</s>

A 33-year-old transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found strangled and beaten to death in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, south west London, at the end of March. A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed and told to return for further questioning. Scotland Yard is appealing for anyone who had contact with Miss Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward.</s>

A woman named Dawn, who has suffered seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle show to accuse her family friend and housemate, Jamie, of stealing £207 that was set aside for a grave stone for her baby, Daniel James. After taking a lie detector test, it was revealed that Jamie had indeed taken the money. Dawn was left devastated and furious by the revelation.</s>

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, a minority group in northern Iraq, mostly women, children, ill, and elderly. The release was coordinated by Arab tribal leaders, but the motivation is unclear. The freed Yazidis were received by Peshmerga and sent to the Kurdish regional capital, Irbil. ISIS has previously released other Yazidis since attacking their towns last year. Yazidis are of Kurdish descent and follow a pre-Islamic sect. They have faced persecution and suffered cruelty from ISIS, including slaughter, rape, and enslavement.</s>

Harry Kane, a Tottenham and England football player, is having an incredible season, scoring 20 Premier League goals and being nominated for PFA Player and Young Player of the Season. A new animation featuring his best goals and celebrations has been released by Copa90, ahead of the awards ceremony on Sunday, where he competes against top players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.</s>

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers is still the right person to lead Liverpool forward despite a season without trophies and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher, who received a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside, stated that Rodgers' future should not be determined by one game and that the signings made in the upcoming transfer window will be crucial for the team's success.</s>

A four-year-old boy, James Hayward, had his toy nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport during a security check. The toy gun, which fires sponge darts, was deemed a security risk after being picked up on the X-ray machine. The boy's father criticized the security checks as "ludicrous" and the staff's reaction. The family was offered a replacement toy gun, which they purchased after returning from their holiday in Lanzarote. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience and stated that the safety and security of passengers is their first priority.</s>

A lonely 31-year-old man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend/wife who loves pets and enjoys the outdoors. The man, identified as "Rich," offers accommodation, a possible company car, phone, and laptop to the successful candidate. He prefers a non-drinker and smoker, who is fit, attractive, reliable, honest, and loyal. The advertisement states that all reasonable offers will be considered, and former partners should not apply.</s>

FA chairman Greg Dyke is pushing for radical changes in English football, including increasing the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12 and changing the rules for what constitutes a "home-grown" player. He faces opposition from the Premier League. Five former England managers, Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren, have backed Dyke's proposals, warning that the English game will suffer if they are not implemented. They argue that the pool of English talent playing at the top level is shrinking, which is a disadvantage for the national team.</s>

Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, gives birth to a baby girl in the latest episode of the show. Despite the quick timeline of her pregnancy, Ross Poldark, portrayed by Aidan Turner, expresses his love for Demelza. Fans have noticed the fast relationship development and shared their amusement on social media.</s>

Boss Nigel Pearson urges Leicester to focus on their own games and not worry about relegation rivals during the run-in. The team is three points from safety after back-to-back wins and aims to remain focused on their own tasks.</s>

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has completed the longest migration of a mammal ever recorded, covering nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpassed the previous record set by a humpback whale and revealed new information about the whale's origin and the potential mixing of eastern and western gray whale populations.</s>

A 1,000ft section of seabed was forced to the surface overnight on the east coast of Japan's Hokkaido Island, creating a new stretch of coastline on Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu. Geologists believe the emergence is due to a landslide caused by melting ice and snow. The mass, which has risen 30 to 50ft above sea level, measures roughly 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide. Local residents reported no sounds or tremors, and authorities do not expect the landmass to expand further.</s>

Gregory van der Wiel, a Dutch footballer, has denied rumors of leaving Paris Saint-Germain in the summer and expressed his love for the club. Despite a recent disagreement with his coach, Laurent Blanc, Van der Wiel is happy in Paris and plans to stay with the Ligue 1 team. He is open to signing a new contract and is ready to play whenever needed. Paris Saint-Germain is also rumored to be pursuing Barcelona's Dani Alves, which may affect Van der Wiel's future with the club.</s>

Carlos Tevez has expressed his desire to leave Juventus and return to his former club, Boca Juniors in Argentina. Although his contract with Juventus does not expire until the end of next season, Boca Juniors has confirmed they are close to completing a deal for the 31-year-old striker. However, club president Daniel Angelici has emphasized that Tevez must first terminate his contract with Juventus. Tevez has been a top scorer for Juventus, netting 17 times this season, but the club is prepared to find potential replacements.</s>

During a Champions League match at the Allianz Arena, Bayern Munich's manager, Pep Guardiola, tore a hole in his trousers, exposing his underwear. This occurred during an exciting night for Bayern, who led their opponents, Porto, 5-0 at half-time and eventually won 6-1. The victory secured Bayern's place in the Champions League semi-finals, with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski.</s>

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, on Wednesday afternoon. Three patients with severe injuries were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital in Brisbane, while six others with minor injuries were taken to Ipswich Hospital. One person was trapped in their vehicle and had to be freed by emergency crews. The affected stretch of the highway has been closed off with diversions in place south of Fernvale.</s>

Arsenal playmaker Mesut Ozil received an Apple Watch and shared his excitement on Instagram, comparing it to TV character Michael Knight's watch from Knight Rider. Arsenal is set to face Chelsea in a Premier League match, with Jack Wilshire's return boosting the team. Ray Parlour, a club legend, believes Wilshere's fitness record is the main factor holding him back from reaching his potential.</s>

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby between Manchester United and Manchester City at Old Trafford on Sunday. Clattenburg has been accused of favoring United in the past, but has only sent off two players this season in the Premier League, both from United. City captain Vincent Kompany is suspended for the match due to a red card received during a Euro 2016 qualifier. The derby could decide who finishes second behind expected winners Chelsea.</s>

Outspoken MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of believing embattled MP Billy Gordon was "a little black puppet on a string" and assumed he would quit after being accused of domestic violence. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, has faced racist attitudes from both major parties in the past and sympathizes with Gordon's position. The statement sparked criticism on social media, with some questioning Katter's terminology. He later defended the statement, saying he used the term "black puppet" based on his personal experiences and understanding of racial overtones.</s>

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, is creating dancing videos to inspire others and challenge stereotypes about people with disabilities. She hopes her videos will entertain and encourage people to think before judging. Dayna has also started motivational speaking at local schools, sharing her experiences and proving that she is just like everyone else despite her disability.</s>

Orlando City, a Major League Soccer (MLS) team, has expressed interest in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who has struggled during his loan at Real Madrid. The Mexico international would be a significant commercial draw for the Florida-based team, which has a large Latin-American fanbase. Eight European clubs are also interested in Hernandez, who has one year left on his contract. In other news, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old midfielder Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from several clubs in Europe.</s>

A gang of at least three people attempted to carjack a man at a 76 Station gas station in South Los Angeles early on Saturday morning. After a heated argument, the suspects covered the man's white Dodge Charger with gasoline and set it on fire while there were two passengers inside. The car's front end was torched, but no one was injured. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as an arson and the suspects remain at large.</s>

A southern Iowa chiropractor, Charles Manuel, has surrendered his state license after being accused of accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. He signed an agreement admitting his misdeeds and pledging not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years. Despite the allegations, Manuel received outstanding evaluations for patient satisfaction on HealthGrades.com. The agreement requires Manuel to prove that the circumstances surrounding the revocation of his license no longer exist before he can resume practicing chiropractic in the state.</s>

A Russian SU-27 fighter jet intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner" over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland. The U.S. crew believed the Russian pilot's actions were aggressive due to its close proximity and high speed. Russian state news agency Sputnik reported the U.S. plane had its transponder off, but a U.S. European Command official said this was false. The Pentagon and State Department will file a complaint through diplomatic channels with Russia. This is not the first time the U.S. has complained about an incident involving a RC-135U and a SU-27.</s>

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot. The gun was secured properly in a hard rifle case with padlocks and chains, but the thief managed to break the car's window and use a rope and another vehicle to rip the case free. The theft occurred just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The agent also reported the theft of his gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools. The rifle has not been recovered, and the police are unsure if the thief specifically targeted the agent's car.</s>

In July 2012, Luigi Costa allegedly killed his neighbor Terrence Freebody in Red Hill, Canberra, due to his declining mental state caused by dementia and alcohol abuse. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen examined Costa and testified that his mood fluctuated during the incident, and his confused mental state was evident from the trail of faeces leading to the toilet. The jury can return a not guilty verdict if Costa's unstable mindset at the time of the attack can be proven.</s>

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty in their 1-0 win against Burnley, despite Leighton Baines having a better penalty record. Barkley's penalty was saved by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton, but Mirallas later scored the winning goal.</s>

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the Holland America Line's ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico, and the cruise line suspects a murder-suicide. The FBI and Puerto Rico Port Authority are investigating the incident, which occurred on a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise that departed from Tampa, Florida on March 29.</s>

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has achieved a winning start as the coach of Curacao in the World Cup qualifying. Curacao advanced to the second qualifying round in CONCACAF for the 2018 tournament after drawing 2-2 in a second-leg match at Montserrat, winning 4-3 on aggregate. Kluivert's team won 2-1 on Saturday in Willemstad, helping Curacao progress to the next stage of 2018 World Cup qualification. Kluivert, whose mother is from Curacao, was a World Cup losing semi-finalist in 1998 as a player and last year as assistant to coach Louis van Gaal.</s>

Esteban Cambiasso, an experienced footballer, believes that keeping Leicester City in the Premier League would be as rewarding as winning a trophy. Despite being at the bottom of the table, Cambiasso remains optimistic and compares the challenge to his previous successes in European competitions. He joined Leicester City in the summer and has quickly become a key player, but his future with the team beyond his current one-year deal is uncertain.</s>

A 23-year-old mother-of-two, Gemma, is at risk of being banned from seeing her children due to her refusal to stop drinking and partying. Her mother, Debbie, who has been caring for the children since they were four months old, is considering banning Gemma from her home and the children after discovering her drug use and suspected stealing. Debbie claims Gemma is unfit to have the children and has been neglectful since their births.</s>

In a match between Chelsea and Manchester United, Chelsea forward Eden Hazard scored a goal, but the Sky Sports punditry team believed there was a foul in the build-up. Chelsea captain John Terry made a strong challenge on United striker Radamel Falcao, causing him to fall. Pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness agreed during their half-time analysis that play should have been stopped for Terry's rough tackle on Falcao.</s>

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway, but everyone on board was safely evacuated. The fire occurred after a rear tire blew out, and it destroyed everything in the bus's back lounge except her Bible. The band's two other members were not on the bus at the time.</s>

Scottish scientist Dr. Adrian Quarterman is working on a space laser project that could potentially be used to power homes in the future by converting sunbeams into energy. The laser satellites would orbit Earth, using mirrors to harvest sunlight and convert it into laser light, which would then be sent back to Earth using semi-conductors. This technology could make solar power viable in Scotland and help restore power in disaster-hit areas. However, the lasers will not be powerful enough to cause harm or be used as weapons.</s>

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old predatory convicted paedophile with an obsession with young girls, has gone missing from a psychiatric unit in Hampshire. Munden was detained under the Mental Health Act after sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus. He has a history of possessing indecent images of children and has a fanatical obsession with young girls. Munden suffers from learning difficulties and autism, and authorities are urgently searching for him.</s>

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to pay back over $2.6 million in gifts after being sued by Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, Donald Sterling's wife. Shelly Sterling accused Stiviano of targeting wealthy older men and claimed that Donald Sterling used the couple's money to buy her expensive gifts. Stiviano argued that there was nothing wrong with the gifts and that she never took advantage of Donald Sterling. The court decision sets a precedent for injured spouses to recover damages from recipients of ill-begotten gifts. Donald Sterling's downfall came after an audio recording of him making racist remarks surfaced, leading to his ban from the NBA and loss of ownership rights in the Los Angeles Clippers.</s>

Thierry Henry criticized Arsenal's recent transfer dealings and urged the club to purchase four top players in the summer, including a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and striker. He believes these additions are necessary for Arsenal to have a chance at winning the Premier League title. Henry also questioned whether Arsenal can win the league with Olivier Giroud as their first choice striker, citing Chelsea's success after buying key players last season.</s>

A young woman testified in Sydney's District Court about the severe impact of years of abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, who has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim expressed fear for her future relationships and stated that Van Ryn stole her right to share her body with someone for the first time. She had kept the abuse a secret until he was caught, and since then has attempted suicide. The hearing continues.</s>

Arsenal teenager Serge Gnabry, who has been out for over a year due to a serious knee injury, is feeling better and better as he prepares for his return. The 19-year-old midfielder played 90 minutes for Arsenal Under 21s against Reading on Monday and is now over his injury worries.</s>

A 23-year-old accountant, Jacob Phillips, died after falling down a 70ft cliff when he ran away from a taxi to avoid paying the fare. After a night out with friends in Cardiff, Phillips and his friends got out of the taxi to use an ATM but did not have enough money to pay for the ride. Phillips ran in one direction while his friends ran in another. The taxi driver, Dave Sidaway, chased Phillips but did not know the dangerous location of the cliff. Phillips was found dead the next day by a dog walker at the base of the cliff in Penarth, South Wales. The coroner's court recorded a verdict of accidental death.</s>

Last summer, thousands of holidaymakers experienced passport delays, with many having to pay extra or missing their trips. Despite the HM Passport Office making a £42 million profit during the chaos, only 2,191 compensation applications were approved between April last year and January this year, resulting in a total payout of £203,066. Ministers refused to provide a blanket refund for affected families.</s>

A timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, dating back to the 1930s, is up for sale with original features such as stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, and vintage cupboards. The semi-detached property has a guide price of £200,000 to £250,000 and includes the original bathroom, kitchen, and wood-panelled hallway. The house is double-glazed but may require renovations, making it a potential perfect family home for those with a passion for antiques. The property will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.</s>

Colin Kaepernick started as a backup to Alex Smith but became the 49ers' starting quarterback in 2012 after Smith's concussion. He led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, but they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.</s>

Anne Rice, born in New Orleans, lived in Texas and San Francisco before moving back to New Orleans. Telemundo is an American Spanish-language TV network owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal's division, NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.</s>

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone and Colchester, formed the band Blur with Graham Coxon after attending Stanway School. Their debut album, Leisure, was released in 1991 to mixed reviews. Blur's music is influenced by various genres, and their self-titled debut album achieved worldwide success in 2001. Albarn released his debut solo album, Everyday Robots, on 28 April 2014, featuring collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, as well as samples from Lord Buckley's rants.</s>
Mogadishu, also known as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, housing many important national institutions.</s>
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails from their 1992 debut EP, Broken.</s>
Andrew Kevin Walker, born on August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA award.</s>

The passage describes two different adaptations of the "Shooter" story. In the 2007 film, Bob Lee Swagger, a Force Recon veteran played by Mark Wahlberg, is framed for murder by a rogue private military company. In the TV series, also featuring Bob Lee Swagger as the lead character, played by Ryan Phillippe, the protagonist is an expert marksman living in exile who returns to action upon learning of a plot to assassinate the president.</s>
House, also known as House, M.D., is an American TV medical drama that aired on Fox for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.</s>

In 1971, Charles Manson was found guilty of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, carried out by members of his group at his instruction. He also received convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald Shea. After being charged, his songs were released commercially.</s>

Sean Justin Penn, born on August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He began his acting career in television and later gained critical attention for his roles in crime dramas and other films. Penn received multiple Oscar nominations and won two Academy Awards for Best Actor for his roles in Mystic River and Milk.</s>

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman, known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer and the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring, he continued to be prominent in the game as an administrator, selector, and writer for three decades.</s>

L.A. Reid is a music industry executive who has held prominent positions, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of Island Def Jam Music Group, all under Sony Music Entertainment.</s>

Brad Wilk is a drummer known for his work in rock bands Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000, 2007-11) and Audioslave (2001-07). He co-founded Rage with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in 1991 and later joined Prophets of Rage in 2016. Rage is a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner.</s>

The Millers was a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013 to July 18, 2015, with 34 episodes across two seasons. The show was cancelled on November 14, 2014, during its second season.</s>

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards was an American politician and the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. She was a Democrat and first gained national attention as the state treasurer of Texas. Richards was defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush. She was the second female governor of Texas and known for her outspoken feminism and one-liners. Ann Richards, a jazz singer, was her wife and the wife of pianist Stan Kenton.</s>

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman, directed by Verona, and starring Janet Leigh, an American actress, singer, dancer, and author who wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.</s>

Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios, also known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who significantly contributed to the establishment of Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as sovereign states, free from Spanish rule.</s>
The Bermuda Triangle, also called the Devil's Triangle, is a western North Atlantic Ocean region where numerous aircraft and ships have reportedly vanished under unexplained circumstances.</s>

Advertising is a form of marketing communication that uses nonpersonal messages to promote or sell products, services, or ideas through various mass media, including old media like newspapers, magazines, television, radio, outdoor advertising, and direct mail, as well as new media such as search results, blogs, websites, and text messages.</s>
Private Lives is a 1930 comedy of manners play by Noël Coward and a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.</s>
Maurice Harold Macmillan, a British Conservative politician and statesman, served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.</s>

Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira, Chalkidice, in 384 BC. He joined Plato's Academy in Athens at 17 or 18 years old and stayed until he was 37. After Plato's death, Aristotle left Athens and became the tutor of Alexander the Great at the request of Philip II of Macedon, starting in 343 BC.</s>

David Mordechai Packouz, born on February 16, 1982, is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented the guitar pedal drum machine, BeatBuddy, and is the CEO of music technology company Singular Sound.</s>

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons, winning championships in high school, college, and with the Lakers. He was selected first overall in the 1979 NBA draft, won an NBA Finals MVP Award in his rookie season, and retired three times. Johnson was named one of America's most influential black businessmen in 2009 and had various business interests, including being a part-owner of the Lakers.</s>

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo from Los Angeles, formed in 1994, consisting of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. They have released three albums and gained popularity in 1997 through their TV series and supporting large rock acts.</s>

James VI and I was the King of Scotland and King of England and Ireland after the union of the Scottish and English crowns in 1603. He aimed for a single parliament for both countries, achieving his goals in Scotland but facing challenges in England, including the Gunpowder Plot and conflicts with the English Parliament.</s>

Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the eighteenth series of the British reality TV show Big Brother, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley, a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist. Bentley has been narrating the UK version of Big Brother since 2000 and is known for his voice-over work and Geordie accent.</s>

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state in Germany, bordering Brandenburg, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia, and Bavaria, as well as Poland and the Czech Republic. It is the tenth largest state in Germany with an area of 18,413 km2 and the sixth most populous, with 4 million people. Saxony has a history spanning over a millennium and is known for its quality wine production, being one of the northernmost wine regions in Europe.</s>
East End Park was a major league baseball park in Cincinnati's East End neighborhood, while "In the End" is a song by American rock band Linkin Park.</s>
Mel B, also known as Brown, started her solo career by releasing the song "I Want You Back" featuring Missy Elliott under Virgin Records.</s>
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus, younger sister of Miley and Trace Cyrus.</s>

Mohra (Pawn) is a 1994 Indian action thriller film directed by Rajiv Rai and starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah. The film, released on July 1, 1994, became the second highest grossing Indian film of that year and received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Originally, Divya Bharti was considered for the female lead, but after her death, Raveena Tandon replaced her. The film is also known for its popular songs.</s>
"Hourglass" is a song by British electronic duo Disclosure, and it is featured on James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.</s>

Shane Black, born on December 16, 1961, is an American multi-talented professional in the film industry, known for writing the 1987 action film Lethal Weapon and directing his first film, Kiss Kiss Bang Bang, in 2005.</s>
A View to a Kill (1985) is the fourteenth James Bond film, starring Roger Moore as the final MI6 agent James Bond.</s>
Papua is the largest and easternmost province of Indonesia, located in western New Guinea. It was previously known as Irian Jaya and included all of Indonesian New Guinea.</s>
The passage states that Augustus likely passed away due to natural causes, but there were unverified claims suggesting his wife Livia might have poisoned him.</s>

Jennifer Lopez entered the music industry in 1999 with her debut album On the 6 and the hit single "If You Had My Love." In 2001, she became the first woman to have a number one album and film simultaneously with J.Lo and The Wedding Planner. After her second divorce, she had a high-profile relationship with Ben Affleck, which influenced her 2002 album This Is Me... Then. She later married Marc Anthony and starred in box office successes like Shall We Dance. In 2008, she gave birth to twins and returned to prominence in 2011 with her role on American Idol and the hit single "On the Floor."</s>

A working animal is a domesticated animal trained by humans to perform various tasks, such as providing tractive force, milking, or herding. While wild animals can sometimes be trained for novelty or entertainment, they lack the traits of trustworthiness and mild temper found in true domesticated working animals.</s>

The passage discusses two Billboard charts: Top Latin Albums, which is crucial for Spanish language albums in the American music market, and Regional Mexican Albums, a genre-specific chart for Mexican music, both published by Billboard magazine. Additionally, it mentions the 1998 direct-to-video comedy film "Billboard Dad" directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen.</s>

Vedam is a 2010 Telugu drama film directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi, featuring Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.</s>

Men in Black II (MIIB) is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film featuring Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.</s>

Robert Palmer is a writer and musician known for his books, music journalism for the New York Times and Rolling Stone, producing blues recordings and a film soundtrack, and playing clarinet in the 1960s band the Insect Trust.</s>

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer who is best known for overseeing the completion of the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after his father, Gutzon Borglum, passed away in 1941. The film Underdog is directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. It stars Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice talents from Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.</s>

The Freeport Doctrine was a concept introduced by Stephen A. Douglas during the second Lincoln-Douglas debate in 1858 in Freeport, Illinois. These debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven encounters between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate. The debates in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton attracted significant crowds from neighboring states, as the issue of slavery was of immense importance to citizens nationwide.</s>

Easy A is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck, written by Bert V. Royal, and starring Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.</s>

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941, is an American author known for her gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. Camden is a city in New Jersey with a population of 77,344 as of the 2010 Census, making it the 12th most populous municipality in the state. In the early 1900s, its population mainly consisted of European immigrants.</s>
Bret Easton Ellis is a writer who penned the screenplay for the 2013 film The Canyons, an American erotic thriller-drama directed by Paul Schrader.</s>

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates between Republican candidate Abraham Lincoln and incumbent Democratic Senator Stephen Douglas in Illinois.</s>

Homer is the ancient Greek author of the epic poems Iliad and Odyssey, which are central to Greek literature. Joe R. Lansdale is an American author who wrote the mystery/suspense novel The Thicket.</s>

The passage describes Audioslave, a four-piece band consisting of Chris Cornell, Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. The Soyuz rocket was commissioned for the Soviet human spaceflight program, launching Soyuz spacecraft for 8 unmanned test flights and 19 manned launches. In 2000, Rage Against the Machine released their fourth studio album, Renegades, through Epic Records. That same year, de la Rocha quit the band due to growing tensions, leading to a brief hiatus. The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index consisting of 30 financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. The passage provides information about Vietnam, an eastern country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. Vietnam is one of the four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.</s>

James VI and I was the King of Scotland and King of England and Ireland after the union of the Scottish and English crowns in 1603. He ruled both kingdoms in personal union, with separate parliaments and laws, but advocated for a single parliament. He faced difficulties with Parliament during his reign in England.</s>

Danielle Cormack, born on December 26, 1970, is a New Zealand stage and screen actress. Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented Thatcherism, a set of policies that have been both praised and criticized in British history.</s>

Valencia is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia in Spain and is the third largest city after Madrid and Barcelona. Speech recognition (SR) is a sub-field of computational linguistics that focuses on developing methods and technologies for computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text. It involves knowledge from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications of SR include voice user interfaces, call routing, domotic appliance control, search, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft direct voice input. The advances in SR are evident in the increase of academic papers and the adoption of deep learning methods by major industry players such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC.</s>

Richard Alf, an American businessman and former comic book store owner, co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970 along with Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry. The event was initially known as the Golden State Comic Book Convention and later as the San Diego Comic Book Convention before adopting its current name. Alf served as the chairman of the event from 1970 until his death in 2012.</s>

France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl are tied for the lead at 16 under par in a golf tournament. Northern Ireland's McIlroy, who is aiming for his first title since May, is at 15 under par along with Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat. McIlroy, a four-time major winner, had a strong round with an eagle on the 12th hole but also experienced some difficulties. He is currently leading the Race to Dubai and has a significant point advantage over England's Danny Willett. English golfers Chris Wood and Richard Bland are in fifth and seventh place respectively.</s>

Sheikh Ali Salman, the leader of Bahrain's main opposition party al-Wefaq, has called for national dialogue to address the ongoing crisis in the country. He believes that the government must show its willingness to offer concrete solutions and work with reformists within the royal family, such as Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa. Sheikh Salman also urged the UK and US governments to put more pressure on Bahrain to improve human rights and democratic practices.</s>

Christopher Hogwood, a prominent conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), passed away at his home in Cambridge after an extended illness. Hogwood was a key figure in the early-music movement and worked with numerous leading orchestras worldwide. He founded the AAM in 1973 and directed it for over 30 years, during which the ensemble produced more than 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood was also a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service scheduled for a later date.</s>

In the year ending March, there were 57 homicide victims in Scotland, the lowest number since 1976 and half the number from nine years ago. The majority of these cases involved sharp instruments, particularly knives. Alcohol and drugs were a factor in 31% of cases. Only one homicide case from 2015-16 remains unresolved. While there is a downward trend in homicides, Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman Claire Baker cautions that sexual crime is at a 45-year high and violent crime with attempted murder and serious assault has increased by 27%.</s>

The Cherries lost 2-1 to Sunderland, becoming the first team to lose to the Black Cats in the Premier League this season. Dan Gosling scored their first goal in three games, but they were unable to find an equalizer despite creating numerous chances. Bournemouth manager Eddie Howe expressed frustration with their inability to score and emphasized the importance of moving on from the loss.</s>

The passage discusses Australian Prime Minister Mr. Abbott's stance on preventing deaths at sea by stopping illegal boat migrants. Australia detains these migrants and resettles them elsewhere. The New York Times criticized this policy as "inhumane, of dubious legality and strikingly at odds with the country's tradition of welcoming people fleeing persecution and war." Mr. Abbott has suggested that European leaders consider adopting similar policies, but the New York Times finds this unconscionable. Mr. Abbott also made controversial comments comparing the Islamic State to the Nazis, which angered Australian Jewish groups.</s>

The US has suspended talks with Russia on Syria, accusing Russia and the Syrian government of intensifying attacks against civilians in Aleppo. The US had warned it would halt the talks unless Russia stopped bombing the city. Since the end of the ceasefire two weeks ago, Aleppo has come under heavy aerial bombardment, with hundreds of people, including children, dying. The US has suspended its participation in bilateral channels with Russia that were established to sustain the cessation of hostilities. Russia has regretted the US move, accusing it of shifting the blame for the collapse of last month's truce.</s>

The UK government is considering selling high-value social housing properties when they become vacant, a proposal supported by think tank Policy Exchange. The sale could raise £4.5bn per year, which would be used to build 80,000 to 170,000 new social homes. Critics argue that this would push low-income families out of expensive neighborhoods and create segregated communities. The government counters that the proposal would help make better use of social housing stock and address the waiting list of 1.8 million people.</s>

A 25-year-old man named Gareth Colfer-Williams died at his home in Swansea, where a measles epidemic has affected 942 cases. Although measles was diagnosed, the main cause of his death could not be established, and an inquest will be opened on Tuesday for further tests. Since November, 83 people have required hospital treatment for the illness. Mr. Colfer-Williams had been treated for asthma at Morriston Hospital before developing a rash and passing away. Public Health Wales confirmed measles but further tests are needed to determine the cause of death. The family is unsure how he contracted measles as no close family members have it, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter.</s>
Vincent Hudson, 54, has been charged with a historical offence involving a boy under 16 in 2001 and is set to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.</s>

In a National League match, Neil Aspin's promotion-chasing team faced Adam Lockwood's side. Guiseley took the lead with a goal from Jake Lawlor, but Gateshead leveled the score with a goal from Wes York. Both teams ended with a 1-1 draw.</s>

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of the football club, plans to replace two stands to increase capacity instead of building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has faced delays due to a town green application. The project was approved by Bristol City Council in November, and majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed that work will begin in May if there is no judicial review by March.</s>

Cuadrilla, a shale gas drilling firm, has suspended its operations after a 1.5 magnitude tremor occurred, marking the second tremor in two months. The company will examine data collected by the British Geological Survey (BGS) before deciding whether to resume. Shale gas drilling, or "fracking," has been controversial due to environmental concerns, but the Commons energy select committee has called for its support in the UK with proper regulation and industry practices. The BGS is monitoring fracking as a precaution and has found that the recent tremors share a similar location and mechanism.</s>

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old bagpiper from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud for playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner in April 2015, giving the impression he was collecting cash for the charity. He denied three counts of fraud and claimed the banner was a tribute to the victims. Carpenter, who has played in the city centre for over 30 years, will be sentenced in January.</s>

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0 in a Championship match. Grant Ward scored the opening goal, followed by Luke Varney's goal after a mistake by QPR's goalkeeper Alex Smithies. Tom Lawrence completed the scoring with a calm finish. QPR struggled to create chances, with Sandro hitting the post late in the game. The win moved Ipswich up to 14th place, while QPR slipped to 15th.</s>

The passage discusses Wells, a 23-year-old cricket player who performed well in the T20 Blast last season, scoring 373 runs at a strike rate of 138.66. Wells is excited about the club's positive direction and praises the coaches for creating an environment of elite performance.</s>

The Reds, ranked fifth in National Two South, secured a 29-12 victory against third-placed Chinnor, marking their second consecutive win. Key players Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams led the team, making over 70 tackles during the game. In their upcoming eight games, the Reds will face seven teams below them in the table, as well as league leaders Old Elthamians. Despite the win, coach Churcher believes there is room for improvement and emphasizes the need to build on their recent performance.</s>

A 28-year-old man, Nazrul, also known as Nazu, was arrested in Kolkata for allegedly raping a 74-year-old nun. This incident sparked outrage in India and led to protests across the country. Nazrul is the sixth person arrested in connection with the crime, with eight suspects identified and two still untraced. All five previously arrested individuals have named Nazrul as the rapist. Police acted on a tip that Nazu, who had fled to Bangladesh, was returning to Kolkata by train. In May, Milon Sarkar was arrested as the alleged leader of the gang involved in the attack.</s>

The passage discusses an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, who explains the reasons behind changes in consumer purchases. Factors such as the introduction of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports influenced the types of items popular among UK consumers. The interactive video also examines shifts in brand ownership and ranking in the UK. The passage provides links to additional non-interactive resources on related topics.</s>

Two incidents occurred where elderly women were tricked by callers claiming to work for BT and gaining remote access to their computers to steal money. The first incident took place in Sandyhills on 15 September, and the second in Stranraer seven days later. Police warn people to be cautious when giving remote access to their computers and not to share banking details or account numbers over the phone.</s>

Duffy, a 37-year-old former Scotland assistant coach, has joined the third-placed Championship side Featherstone on a one-year contract after leaving Swinton Lions. He will lead the team in their final league game against Toulouse and in the upcoming Super 8 Qualifiers. Featherstone chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy as a fantastic coach and credited his remarkable work at Swinton. Duffy, who had a 16-year playing career with Leigh, Widnes, and Salford, has been replaced by his former assistant Stuart Littler at Swinton.</s>

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, a medic, and a coastguard helicopter responded to an incident at Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve. The rider, with head injuries and cold from lying unconscious on wet sand, was treated and flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales for further care.</s>

A UN conference in Geneva decided to dedicate part of the radio spectrum to a global flight tracking system to improve the current ground-based radar system. This decision was influenced by the disappearance of flight MH370 in 2014, which exposed weaknesses in worldwide air navigation systems. The new system will enable real-time tracking of aircraft using satellite transmissions and will be adopted by November 2016, as set by the UN's aviation arm, the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO).</s>

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at the age of five, was found at 18 living with his father in Cleveland. His father, Bobby Hernandez, was arrested and charged with tampering with records. The FBI received a tip after Julian faced issues applying for college, and they worked with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to confirm his identity. His mother has been notified, and his father is being held at a jail in Ohio with a $250,000 bail. Authorities had previously suspected the father as the culprit when the boy went missing in 2002.</s>

The passage discusses a fire that occurred on 2 March at a site in Duncan Street, reducing train services and causing travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the incident. The company, which was run by Asset and Land Group, was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, according to the fire service. The EA decided to revoke the environmental permit, effective from 7 August, after considering the facts and concerns raised by the fire service. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.</s>

The pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia has proposed two bills related to the situation in Ukraine, particularly Crimea, where separatist and pro-Russian sentiments are strong. The first bill would allow Russia to accept a territory from a neighboring state if its people express a desire to join Russia, bypassing the current requirement for a treaty. The second bill would expedite the process for issuing Russian passports to Ukrainians, aiming to support the Russian-speaking population in Ukraine.</s>

The passage discusses the history of McLaren, a once-great Formula 1 team that has experienced a significant decline in recent years. Despite having 182 grands prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, the team has struggled in recent seasons. The slump began in 2013, and while they have two world champions in their cars, Fernando Alonso and Jenson Button, they have not achieved the same level of success as in the past. The team's history has been cyclical, with periods of triumph followed by decline. Ron Dennis, who has been involved with McLaren since its inception, believes that the team will eventually return to its former glory and break Mercedes' dominance in F1.</s>

On 27 January, 44-year-old Thomas Baker, known as Tommy, was found badly injured at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool after being shot in the head and chest. He later died in the hospital. Three Liverpool men, aged 29, 29, and 32, have been arrested and are in police custody for questioning. Detectives believe the shooters had been waiting outside Phoenix Gym for about an hour before the incident. Police are still searching for a silver VW Polo and have asked for people captured on CCTV near the meat market to come forward as they may have key information for the investigation.</s>
