YouTube star Bas van Velzen, known for his free-kick skills, visited Liverpool's Melwood training ground, where he was mistaken for a competition winner. He impressed Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic with his dead-ball skills. Van Velzen described the experience as amazing and enjoyed playing football with his idols. He also surprised Balotelli by unveiling the forward's infamous slogan t-shirt.</s>

The passage discusses how carriers of the BRCA1 gene, like Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of death from breast cancer by having their ovaries removed. A study found that this procedure can cut their risk of dying from breast cancer by over 60%. Women with a BRCA1 mutation who have their ovaries removed within two years of diagnosis experience a 73% reduction in death compared to those who never undergo the procedure. The protective effect of oophorectomy against breast cancer is apparent immediately after diagnosis and lasts for 15 years.</s>

A married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were tragically killed by an Amtrak train on Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina. The train, number 80, the Carolinian, was traveling from Charlotte to New York City when the accident occurred on property owned by Norfolk-Southern. None of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, but there was a delay of about two hours and 45 minutes before the train continued its route. The couple may have lived in a homeless camp, according to a man who met them while collecting scrap metal.</s>

Carlos Toro, a former Medellin cartel member, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s. In exchange for his cooperation, he was promised US citizenship, which has not been granted. Now 66 and retired due to declining health, Toro faces deportation and fears for his life if sent back to Colombia. Despite his significant contributions to the DEA, including aiding in the prosecution of Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, the agency has refused to help him with his citizenship.</s>

The US body that regulates internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for potentially illegal actions in using the new '.sucks' domain name. The company has been charging exorbitant fees to celebrities and companies, such as Kevin Spacey and major brands, to remove their names from the domain. ICANN has sent a letter to the US Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to determine the legality of Vox Populi's actions.</s>

A mother was arrested 27 years after her stillborn baby's body was found in a village pond. The baby's body was exhumed last year, and a DNA sample led the police to the mother. The woman explained that the baby was stillborn and she had concealed the pregnancy from her family and friends. The police have ruled out foul play, and the woman remains on bail while the CPS decides whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby was reburied at St Peter's Church in Norfolk, and was given the name Peter.</s>

A taxi driver, Michael Young, has been ordered to pay compensation to a passenger, Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of the moving car. The incident occurred five years ago when Young mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to "do a runner" and drove him back to the rank to teach him a lesson. When Hicks objected, Young continued driving, leading to Hicks jumping from the vehicle at over 20mph. Hicks developed epilepsy and now requires round-the-clock care from his mother. The exact amount of compensation is yet to be decided but is expected to be around 50% of what the family requested, potentially hundreds of thousands of pounds.</s>

Tornado sirens were sounded in Kansas as several storms brought reports of twisters. A tornado was spotted near Goddard, moving northeast and posing potential risks to other communities. CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers warned of nighttime tornadoes being the most deadly and dangerous. Other tornado sightings occurred in southwestern Kansas. Kansas was not the only state affected, as a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage, flooding, and fallen trees. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes.</s>

Luke Rockhold is preparing to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight fight in New Jersey. Rockhold aims for his fourth consecutive victory and a title shot. He plans to dominate Machida by cutting him off and progressing slowly, making him fight Rockhold's fight. Rockhold believes he has various advantages over Machida and respects his fighting style. Machida, confident in his own abilities, thinks he can stop Rockhold and earn a title shot. Both fighters are well-prepared for the upcoming match.</s>

An aeroplane touched down on a runway without deploying its landing gear and skidded along the runway on its belly in Fort Pierce, Florida. The light general aviation aircraft, an Aerostar plane, approached the Aero Acres residential airpark and touched down without its landing gear deployed. The propellers ricocheted off the ground and the wings bounced up and down from the impact. The pilot re-engaged the engines and took off back into the air. The plane's pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, managed to fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. The most common cause of a gear-up landing is human error, when the pilot forgets to deploy the landing gear before touchdown. The FAA is investigating the incident.</s>

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in midfielder Yaya Toure's performance this season but has vowed to support him until the end of the season. The club is reportedly open to offers for the Ivorian player as they look to overhaul their aging squad. Toure, who has two years left on his £220,000-a-week contract, has faced criticism amid Manchester City's faltering Premier League campaign. City goalkeeper Joe Hart believes the players should take responsibility for their poor performances, but Pellegrini maintains that he chooses the players.</s>

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," had his extradition to Italy dropped and was allowed to remain in the UK. Rancadore was given a seven-year sentence by an Italian court in 1999 for being a member of the Cosa Nostra. In February, he lost his battle against extradition, but his case expired in October, leading to the withdrawal of his European arrest warrant. Although his conviction remains intact, Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished once a period of more than double the time of the penalty has passed.</s>

The passage discusses the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown, where Mr. Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls and ridden by AP McCoy, is one of the three 7-2 co-favorites. Other co-favorites include Irish horse Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's sprinter Sacre, ridden by Cheltenham Gold Cup winner Nico de Boinville. Mr. Mole will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race, and his final book of rides will be finalized on Friday morning. McCoy announced his intention to quit riding after winning with Mr. Mole at Newbury in February. The other runners in the Celebration Chase include Mick Channon's Somersby.</s>

The mother of a girl murdered 40 years ago recently saw crime scene photos of her daughter's body and now wants revenge. Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter, Marcia, was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcia's body was found 33 days after she disappeared. Ritter's then-husband advised her against seeing the body and the crime scene photos, which she finally viewed last year with the help of a metro police lead investigator. Barrett was found guilty of second-degree murder and sentenced to 44 years in prison.</s>

Rory McIlroy believes it is essential for him to win the Masters at some point to complete the career Grand Slam. The world number one golfer aims to claim his first Green Jacket and become the sixth player to win all four major titles. McIlroy has just one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances and hopes to complete his Grand Slam with a victory at Augusta later this month.</s>

The passage highlights various trending stories from the week, including four rainbows appearing in the New York sky, exotic dancers being banned from wakes in China, a lip-plumping trend inspired by Kylie Jenner, 102-year-old Alice Barker's prom-posal, Ewan McGregor's casting in "Beauty and the Beast," Johnny Depp's transformation in "Black Mass" trailer, a creative pregnancy announcement referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," and a military dad's photobomb.</s>

The passage reveals that 272 children were hospitalized in England in the past 12 months due to being born brain damaged from exposure to alcohol in the womb, according to the official Health and Social Care Information Centre. The actual number of affected children could be higher. The World Health Organization estimates that at least one in 100 babies born in the UK could suffer learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure, amounting to about 7,500 cases every year. The passage also shares the story of a teenager with Foetal Alcohol Syndrome and discusses the various medical issues associated with alcohol consumption during pregnancy. Pregnant women are advised not to drink alcohol, but some experts believe the guidance should be changed to advise women not to drink at all during pregnancy.</s>

An axe-wielding robber, Shaun Andrew Mckerry, attempted to rob a store in Shildon Post Office and Stores, County Durham. However, his attempt was foiled when the shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, tackled him to the floor, and Dhillon's wife, Sam, hit Mckerry with a baseball bat. Mckerry was arrested by the police and later jailed for six years after pleading guilty to attempted robbery. Mckerry, a former juvenile offender, had been arrested 80 times by the age of 15 and earned the nicknames "Boomerang Boy" and "Homing Pigeon Boy" for always returning home after committing crimes.</s>

Four Royal Navy sailors have been charged with gang rape at a Canadian barracks and must stay in Nova Scotia until they are tried. They were given unusual bail conditions, including surrendering their passports and living at the Stadacona Naval Base in Halifax. The sailors will continue to work for the Royal Navy and draw their current pay. They are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, which are punishable by up to 14 years in prison.</s>

A mother of a four-year-old boy with Netherton's syndrome, a rare skin disease affecting only 70 people worldwide, was reported to the police for child abuse by a stranger who mistook his condition for abuse. The boy's skin appears red and inflamed with a scaly appearance, requiring regular application of creams to prevent drying out. The mother has faced taunts and ignorance from the public, and the family has struggled with the challenges and stigma associated with the rare condition.</s>

The controversial Protein World advertisement featuring a bikini-clad model has caused a backlash among feminists and body image campaigners, leading to a Change.org petition with over 50,000 signatures calling for its removal. Transport for London (TFL) has confirmed that the posters will be removed as they have reached the end of their three-week advertising period. The advertising standards authority has received over 200 complaints about the adverts promoting an unhealthy body image.</s>

Rail firms have faced criticism for planning fare hikes of up to 87% just ten days after the general election, despite party leaders pledging to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has requested First Great Western to urgently review its decision to increase fares on trains running through his Witney constituency. Train companies have three windows every year to increase unregulated fares, which make up around half of their total revenue.</s>

Former soldier John Young, 66, was left blinded in one eye after being hit with a brick thrown through his front door by vandals. The newlywed pensioner and his wife, Elaine, were in their home in Oldham when the attackers began throwing stones at their windows. When John confronted the attackers, he was struck in the face with another brick, resulting in serious injuries to his eye and forehead. Despite emergency surgery, doctors were unable to save his eyesight. The couple, who were married just three weeks prior, now feel unsafe in their home and are considering moving. Police have launched an investigation but have not identified a motive for the attack.</s>

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton has signed a new one-year contract extension after a successful return from injury. The 25-year-old missed the 2014 season due to leg injuries from a road accident that killed his father. Poynton made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi and will be available for the start of the 2015 season, committing himself to the county until the end of the 2016 season. Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's character and work ethic and hopes the new contract will boost his confidence.</s>

A five-year-old boy named Harley Renshaw, who was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer, has been declared cancer-free after battling the disease for a year. Harley created a superhero mask to help him feel stronger during his treatment, and his story gained international attention. Doctors, amazed by his bravery, awarded him one of Cancer Research UK's Little Star Awards, and he became the face of the charity's Kids and Teens campaign. Harley will undergo regular check-ups to ensure he remains cancer-free.</s>

Jack Grealish, a 19-year-old football player, is at the center of a tug of war between the Republic of Ireland and England for his international future. However, Aston Villa's coach, Tim Sherwood, advises Grealish to focus on his club career and continue to force his way into the Villa first team. Grealish's father, Kevin, also agrees that his son should concentrate on club football first. Jack Grealish is expected to choose between Ireland and England at the end of the season.</s>

The passage discusses the high landing fees for private jets at various airports around the world, with some surprising hubs charging the most. Private jet travel is a growing trend among the wealthy, with the industry being worth billions of dollars. The busiest times for private jet travel coincide with major sporting events, such as the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix. The most expensive airports for landing fees are in Japan, with Haneda Airport in Tokyo being the most costly. Other airports in the top 10 list include Dublin, Bristol, Toronto, Darwin, LaGuardia, and Salzburg.</s>

The passage describes a video of Cooper, a Labrador, eating an ice cream cone quickly at a McDonald's drive-thru with his friend Daisy. The video has been viewed over seven million times, with some viewers finding it cute and hilarious, while others criticize the owner, Katie Gallegos, for feeding her dogs ice cream. Gallegos, who runs a dog resort, defends her decision, stating that Cooper is in great health and Daisy gets only a few licks due to her size. The dogs also enjoy visiting Starbucks for a "pup-uccino," which consists of whipped cream in a cup.</s>

Gary Locke, former Hearts boss and assistant at Kilmarnock, has been appointed as the permanent manager of the club after signing a three-year deal. Since taking over as interim manager in February, Locke has lost only one game in seven and has now secured the position after successful results.</s>

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, claims that her five-year-old autistic son's school threatened to suspend him due to the essential oils he wears to help manage his condition. The oils, made by Doterra, were deemed a distraction to other students. Despite receiving a letter stating the oils created a problem for staff and students, Kemp plans to continue using them, as they help her son stay calm and focused. The Lake County School District later stated they would not suspend the child, citing it as a health issue. The family uses oils with scents such as lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.</s>

A beach-side apartment complex in the Hamptons, the Sandpiper complex, was destroyed by a fire that spread through 90 condos on Wednesday afternoon. The cause of the fire is unknown, but it was so intense that it melted the paint off nearby buildings. Twelve fire crews attempted to control the flames, but they could not get inside any of the summer homes. The building manager, Rob Taber, lost everything in the fire. The complex is used as a holiday home by residents between May and November.</s>

The passage describes the Queen's love for horses and her recent ride on her black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. Despite being 88 years old, the Queen remains an enthusiastic equestrienne, although she has reduced her riding time due to a knee injury. She has never worn a riding helmet, preferring to use silk scarves instead. The Queen breeds fell ponies at Hampton Court and has a stud specializing in Highland ponies at Balmoral. Fell ponies, one of the oldest equine breeds, have a long history of use as pack animals and in trotting races. Today, they remain a popular choice for riders of all ages.</s>

A dispute between two Brisbane neighbors over noise levels resulted in the death of 55-year-old Leon Yeaman, allegedly killed by a single punch from 28-year-old Phillip Pama. The incident occurred when Yeaman was making noise in his yard at around 9 pm on Thursday night, disturbing Pama, a shift worker and father of three, who was sleeping at the time. Pama, who has no history of violence, was granted conditional bail and will return to court on May 18.</s>

A 52-year-old music teacher, Yulia Simonova, was arrested for attempting to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old former student, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. Simonova offered 100,000 rubles for the job, but police set up a sting operation and arrested her when she handed over the money to an undercover officer posing as the hitman. She now faces 15 years in prison for attempted murder.</s>

Chelsea football manager Jose Mourinho reveals he talks to God every day, but never about football or discusses the game with his wife. He and his family have worked with the World Food Programme as ambassadors against hunger. Mourinho tries to separate his professional and family life and has a strong faith in God. He only prays for things in his personal life and never about Chelsea. Mourinho claims to be a good person and tries to support people he doesn't even know. Chelsea is currently at the top of the league.</s>

A TV legend, Bob Barker, returned to host "The Price is Right" for the first time in eight years, joining Drew Carey for a segment of the show. Barker, 91, previously hosted the game show for 35 years before stepping down in 2007.</s>

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. for allegedly attempting to break into a house at midnight. He was charged with attempted burglary and destruction of property. Baldwin's security clearance was revoked, and he was put on leave. His arrest follows a high-ranking supervisor being put on leave for misconduct allegations, which are also being investigated by the Homeland Security Department's Inspector General.</s>

A freelance photographer, Atif Saeed, risked his life to capture an image of a hungry lion from just a few feet away at Lahore's safari park. Armed only with a camera, he crept to within 10 feet of the lion before the clicking sound of the camera's shutter alerted the lion, forcing him to retreat rapidly.</s>

A woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was found unconscious and later pronounced dead on March 22 in Brooklyn. She had a distinctive tattoo on her right leg, which the NYPD has released images of in hopes of identifying her. The tattoo is a heart with the name "Monique" etched across a ribbon within it and a rose on top. The cause of her death is still unknown, and anyone with information is asked to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.</s>

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered, two-bedroom home on the back of an old flatbed truck after returning from the UK and not being able to afford a full-sized lot. The project took a year and a half and cost around $25,000. The self-sufficient home, located in Nelson, New Zealand, features wood and steel construction, stained glass windows, and a wood-fired stove. The couple plans to build another similar home in the future.</s>

The passage states that children who share iPads in class perform better in early literacy tests than those who don't, according to researchers. This finding contradicts the general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers' skepticism about using technology as a teaching aid in non-IT classes. The research, conducted by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University, found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class over an academic year significantly outperformed their peers in classes without iPads or with individual devices. Shared iPad students scored around 30 points higher than students who used the device individually and non-iPad users. Blackwell suggests that the difference is due to collaborative learning around the technology and recommends that schools reconsider how tablets are used, especially in earlier grades, to make the technology more effective.</s>

The passage is about a two-legged piglet that has become an internet sensation after a video of it learning to walk on its front trotters went viral. Born with no back legs, the piglet has mastered balancing on its front legs and foraging for food. The piglet, nicknamed "Super Pig," belongs to farmer Ms. Duan in Sichuan Province, China, and has attracted many visitors. This is not the first time an animal with two legs instead of four has gained attention in China, as a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo also became a star attraction for walking on its front paws.</s>

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was injured when he was hit by Francesco Dracone's car during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana. Dracone spun while exiting his pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips received stitches for a cut on his leg and was released. Many cars struggled with traction due to rain before the race, and Dracone did not finish, ending up in 23rd place.</s>

A husband in Rio de Janeiro brutally murdered his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, by smashing her head into concrete paving 11 times and shooting her in the face five times. The husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, confessed that he committed the act out of jealousy over men looking at her. The couple had been married for only four days. Neighbors reported hearing arguments and the husband accusing his wife of being a "slut" and a "whore." After the murder, Severiano stole a neighbor's car, which was later found by police with four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest inside. Severiano now faces life in prison.</s>

Sarah Wilson, journalist and author of the best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," opened up about her personal battle with mental illness, revealing she almost took her own life due to anxiety. In a candid interview with Women's Weekly Australia, Wilson shared that a combination of factors, including stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and distant family, led her to believe her life was not worth living. She believes depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked and that acknowledging this connection can help address the increasing rate of Australian women affected by stress and anxiety. Wilson now accepts that she is an "anxious person" and warns that anxiety is becoming the "new depression."</s>

An Oregon woman, Elena Curtin, who was seven-months pregnant, was charged with second-degree assault for hitting her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar after finding her using heroin in her bathroom. Prosecutors dropped the charge, stating Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage." Oregon law allows for the use of physical force against an intruder who refuses to leave a resident's home. Curtin's defense attorney claimed the ex-girlfriend harassed and threatened Curtin, and the ex and boyfriend had a history of drug use. If Curtin had been convicted, she would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of almost six years.</s>

Gemma the pit bull was filmed in California being fed treats, but her owner tricked her by adding broccoli. Gemma showed disgust, chomped on the vegetable, and spat it out on the floor. The passage hopes the two children living with Gemma learn to love their greens. Gemma also enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.</s>

HSBC has apologized after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The issue occurred because the bank's page for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, which was shut down in 2011, allowed the porn site to take over its address. HSBC removed the hyperlink from its main website and denied any association with the external site, offering apologies to the public for any inconvenience caused.</s>

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, called 911 after a fire broke out in his home in Clinton, providing firefighters with instructions to rescue him and his nine-year-old sister, Aaliyah, who were trapped on the second floor. Marcus stayed calm throughout the 11-minute call, reassuring his sister and giving directions to the rescuers. Firefighters entered the room by breaking a window and rescued the siblings. All family members were taken to the hospital with non-life threatening injuries.</s>

The passage describes amazing pictures of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay, South Coast of New South Wales. The images were taken by photographer Andy Hutchinson, who described the sight as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton emitting light. The glow is caused by noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton that blossoms in spring and autumn and occurs naturally in 90% of cases. The algae is carnivorous and preys on another type of algae called diatoms, giving off the luminous glow as a defense mechanism. A similar display was observed in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014.</s>

New tests, such as Endopredict, can pinpoint genetic markers in tumors to determine the aggressiveness of breast cancer and help patients avoid chemotherapy. After surgery, cancer cells are screened in a lab, and women can be informed within days of their risk of recurrence. For some women, the test can accurately identify a low risk, as low as 5%, which may not require chemotherapy. The majority of women with breast cancer receive chemotherapy after tumor removal to prevent recurrence, but the side effects can be difficult to endure. Experts believe that for certain women, chemotherapy may not be necessary, and the new tests can help patients make informed choices. Most tests are currently available privately and cost around £2,500, but breast specialists hope they will soon be available on the NHS.</s>

Over 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy in the last nine years, with HMS Ocean having five emergency evacuations. At least one woman was also airlifted from HMS Illustrious. A strict "no touching" rule is in place at sea, suggesting the women conceived before boarding or during leave. This data comes after Commander Sarah West was investigated for alleged misconduct. Women have been serving on Royal Navy ships since 1990, and in 2014, around 9% of personnel were female.</s>

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material was found on the rooftop of Japan's equivalent to the White House, raising concerns about potential terrorism involving drones. This discovery occurred on the same day a Japanese court approved a government plan to restart two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant, a move unpopular among many Japanese due to the dangers of nuclear energy. The drone, equipped with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing small traces of cesium, a common byproduct of nuclear reactors, has raised concerns about future terrorism attempts during the Olympics and G7 summit using drones.</s>

A security guard from China, Lu Xincai, takes his 84-year-old Alzheimer's-suffering mother to work with him on the back of his motorbike every day to ensure she doesn't get lost. He ties a sash around both of their waists for safety and rides slowly to allow them to chat during the hour-long journey. His mother has been given her own room at his workplace, a bank, and he checks on her throughout the day. Lu feels a duty to care for his mother in return for her devotion to caring for her children.</s>

A major study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington found that heavy drinking among Americans rose 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, largely due to rising rates among women. Binge drinking is defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more drinks for men on a single occasion at least once during the past month. The increases are driven largely by women's drinking habits as social norms change. In 2012, 8% of Americans were considered heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers.</s>

UN officials warn that doctors are putting the health of women and their babies at risk by performing caesarean sections too frequently. The procedure should only be carried out when medically necessary, as it can lead to infections and even death. The current rate of caesareans in England is over 25%, more than double the rate in the early 1990s. The WHO suggests this figure should ideally be between 10-15% due to the dangers and costs involved. Planned caesareans cost the NHS more than natural births and can lead to significant complications, disability, or death.</s>

A woman, Michelle Filkins, was arrested for breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for a week, and selling the owners' items in a yard sale. She has been charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Filkins was discovered by the owner, Mark Conklin, on April 17, and was arrested after she falsely claimed ownership and fled the scene. The police found a broken window and a gray Nissan pickup truck linked to Filkins. She is scheduled to appear in court on May 14. Police are asking anyone who purchased items from the yard sale to return them, as they are considered victims, and are assisting in seeking restitution.</s>

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was reunited with its owner after Albury police officers posted a series of humorous photos on her Facebook page to track her down. The phone was handed in to the police station on the NSW-Victoria border. The officers used the unlocked phone to post selfies and photos of the phone in various locations around the station, eventually informing Bella that she could collect her phone. The post received a positive response from her friends and the officers, who were labeled "legends" for their approach. Bella was able to reclaim her phone without providing her name, as the officers recognized her from the Facebook page. She has since added a password to her phone and expressed gratitude to the police for their sense of humor and assistance.</s>

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was tragically killed after getting caught in a fight between two adult hippos in the Isimangaliso Wetland Park in Eastern South Africa. The calf's mother watched in horror as it was thrown into the air and dragged along the water's surface. The two male hippos had been fighting for some time, and the mother stayed with her herd, believing it to be safer. A tour operator, Stacey Farrell, witnessed the incident and described the heartbreaking scene. The baby hippo ultimately died from its injuries hours later.</s>

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is on sale for £575,000, a bargain price for the area, but it has only three years left on the lease. The property, in need of renovation, could be worth up to £6 million if the lease is extended. The apartment is one of two maisonettes being sold with short leases in the exclusive Egerton Place area. The current freeholder is the Welcome Trust, and negotiating a lease extension could cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million.</s>

Starbucks experienced a computer outage at 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, causing baristas to give away free drinks. The issue has since been resolved, and stores are expected to resume normal operations. The outage was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, and the company has apologized for any inconvenience.</s>

Terrorists are undergoing training in rural areas of West Wales, including Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, according to an officer from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. These locations are also being used to radicalize Muslims. Detective Constable Gareth Jones emphasized that terrorism-related issues are not confined to large cities. Incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales can be traced back to 1998. The rugged terrain of the Brecon Beacons in Powys helps prepare soldiers for warfare. In recent years, several terrorism-related incidents have occurred in Wales, including the 7/7 bombers and an al-Qaeda-inspired gang plotting terror attacks. Community intelligence is vital for authorities in combating terrorism.</s>

A species of whale, the Omura's whale, thought to be extinct was found washed up on a West Australian beach. This is the first sighting of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. The discovery is significant for scientists as very little is known about the species, which was only described in scientific journals in 2003. The Omura's whale is usually found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. It has a sleek body shape and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be recovered for further scientific investigation and possible public display in museums.</s>

The passage discusses the role of hormones in presidential candidate considerations and the bias against women in the workplace. A female businesswoman argues that Hillary Clinton's hormones might make her irrational and start an unnecessary war, but the passage points out that male hormones have also impaired decision-making in male leaders. It highlights the gender bias in the workplace and how it affects women's potential, citing examples of overt and covert bias. The passage concludes that equality benefits everyone and that our nation, economy, and families would be stronger if there were more women in leadership roles.</s>

Veteran actor Robert Hardy is auctioning off his extensive collection of antiques, including a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, due to his decision to downsize his home. The 89-year-old actor, known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and as Winston Churchill, has collected over 200 items throughout his career, which will be sold at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire. Hardy, a keen military historian, studied English with J.R.R. Tolkien and is an expert on the medieval longbow.</s>

Michael Scott Shemansky is wanted as a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky. He has been on the run since Saturday after failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son. The body was discovered at their shared home in Winter Garden, Florida, during a well-being check by an out-of-state family member. An initial investigation found foul play. Shemansky is already on parole for battery on law enforcement and has a history of bipolar mental illness. Neighbors believe divorce proceedings may have pushed him over the edge. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not yet confirmed how Sandra Shemansky was killed. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without any provisions or medication. Anyone with information on his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities.</s>

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The International Association of Athletics Federations Council decided to bypass the usual bidding process due to a unique strategic opportunity to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene previously failed to host the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. IAAF President Lamine Diack stated that the decision was made to take advantage of a key market and promote the global development of the sport.</s>

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model, was jailed for 16 years for setting a honey trap to lure professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, in an attempt to steal his winnings. Granger befriended Hassan using her good looks, and he showered her with gifts, cash, and trips to fancy restaurants. After going back to his flat with him one night, she left the door unlocked for her boyfriend and an accomplice to enter, tie up Hassan, and kick him to death while ransacking his home. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter but not murder, while her co-defendants, Kyrron Jackson and Nicholas Chandler, were found guilty of murder and jailed for life with a minimum term of 36 years.</s>

Cesc Fabregas, Chelsea midfielder, has experienced a decline in form since Christmas, raising questions about his durability. Despite a strong start to the season, his performance has dropped, and he has struggled in recent matches. Fabregas' form has been a concern for Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho, as the team needs wins in their remaining games to secure the Premier League title.</s>

West Ham is considering a deal for Jamaican youngster Deshane Beckford after his impressive trial. The 17-year-old forward from Montego Bay United trained with West Ham's academy and has received offers from clubs in Belgium. Beckford is considered one of the top prospects from the Caribbean. West Ham is also announcing season tickets at the Olympic Stadium for as low as £289, with the cheapest pricing strategy in the Barclays Premier League to fill the 54,000 capacity stadium for the 2016-17 season.</s>

Police have dropped an investigation into a vicious assault on a huntsman, Mike Lane, three months after it took place, despite a wealth of evidence pointing to the identity of a suspected attacker. A video of the incident and a dossier of evidence, including names of saboteurs and their car registration numbers, was given to Wiltshire police after the assault. The attack occurred during a hunt, and the victim suffered concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. Wiltshire police confirmed they had stopped the investigation pending further information, but their failure to identify, charge, or prosecute anyone involved has dismayed hunt supporters across the country.</s>

Adam Gadahn, a prominent American member of Al Qaeda, was killed in a U.S. government counterterrorism operation in January. He was known as the American mouthpiece of Al Qaeda and was involved in many statements on behalf of the organization. Gadahn converted to Islam in 1995 and moved to Pakistan in 1998. He became Al Qaeda's chief official English-language propagandist and appeared in numerous videos threatening attacks on the United States and other Western interests. In 2006, he was indicted for treason and material support to Al Qaeda by a federal grand jury in California.</s>

The passage discusses a five-year-old Chinese boy named Mai Zizhuo who has gained popularity in China for his exceptional basketball skills. A viral video showcases his ability to score hoops and dribble two basketballs simultaneously, impressing fans and netizens alike. Mai's talents have drawn comparisons to the country's previous basketball star, Yao Ming.</s>

Tom O'Carroll, a former leading member of the notorious Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, who was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals," attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. The organization, established after the phone-hacking scandal, is campaigning against the Independent Press Standards Organisation, which it deems "biased and unfair." Hacked Off seeks to have MPs set up a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry.</s>

The Icebergs Club pool at Bondi was drained on Thursday for a unique catwalk presentation as part of Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The event, organized by lifestyle brand Ten Pieces, featured a monochrome capsule collection of unisex clothing designed to be worn in 20 different ways. The show took place on an unseasonably warm day, with guests enjoying nibbles and drinks while watching models walk through the empty pool and along the break wall with a beautiful ocean backdrop.</s>

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan spent a day at a safari park in Northern California with his wife, Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and daughter, Lamysa. They enjoyed posing with and feeding various animals, including a rare white tiger, giraffes, and sea lions at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his next fight against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about a potential match with British rival and IBF welterweight champion Kell Brook in June.</s>

A Palestinian teenager's name, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, will be removed from an Israeli memorial commemorating fallen soldiers and terrorism victims after his family and others complained. Abu Khdeir, 16, was killed by three Israelis in July. His family objected to his inclusion on the memorial wall, and Almagor, an organization representing victims of terror in Israel, also opposed it. The National Insurance Institute of Israel, which maintains the memorial site, will remove Abu Khdeir's name following his father's complaints.</s>

A boy in California was filmed by his father, YouTube user Lionel Hutz, chasing the family cat around the garden to use its belly as a pillow. The cat initially allows the boy to rest on it but eventually gets up and moves to another spot. The boy follows the cat, and the cycle repeats until the cat decides to go inside. Later, the boy and cat are seen making up, with the boy feeding the cat treats.</s>

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia is ongoing, with witness Robert Kushner, a former drug dealer, testifying about police wrongdoing. Kushner lost his varsity coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after revealing his past involvement in selling marijuana. He claimed that undercover officers stole cash and marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. Kushner passed a background check when hired in 2010, but his history was unknown to the school. He has faced further legal issues since then, but maintains his innocence and expresses regret for the impact on the students.</s>

An explosion at a chemical plant in Fujian province, China, injured six people and caused a large fire. The plant, located in Zhangzhou city, produces paraxylene (PX), a potentially carcinogenic chemical used in the production of polyester films and fabrics. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility due to an oil leak. Five of the six injured were hospitalized. Over 600 firefighters controlled the blaze. The plant had previously experienced an explosion in July 2013, and its construction has sparked protests in several cities due to pollution concerns.</s>

Aston Villa teenager Jack Grealish, known for wearing his socks high and using children's shinpads, says he won't change his superstition despite referees telling him to pull his socks up. Grealish made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR and hopes to get more starts before the end of the season.</s>

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has suffered irreversible brain damage, according to her grandmother. Although she is no longer in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive. Her father, Bobby Brown, recently claimed that she is awake, but her grandmother's statement and a source close to her condition contradict this, stating that her neurological state has not changed for nearly three months. She is undergoing a rehabilitation process, but the quality of her life remains uncertain.</s>

Russia is close to making the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Germany's Sabine Lisicki. Pavlyuchenkova won 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3, while Svetlana Kuznetsova beat Julia Goerges in straight sets. Pavlyuchenkova struggled with Lisicki's power, while both players had issues with their serve. The result puts Russia one win away from reaching the final and potentially winning their first Fed Cup title since 2008.</s>

Residents of New South Wales are being warned to brace for more floods and damage as another storm is predicted to hit later this week. Meteorologists say an East Coast low, the same weather system that hit the state last week, could hit the region again, with heavy rain possible from Thursday. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that more storms will hamper clean-up efforts, as they still have over 4,000 jobs from the 24,196 requests to complete. The SES is particularly worried about the effect more wild weather would have on the hard-hit Hunter region.</s>

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model, denied claims that she attempted suicide after Italian media reported she was found by her mother in her apartment. Moric posted photographs of her injuries on Instagram and explained that she collapsed due to low blood pressure after a domestic accident. She clarified that her boyfriend was in Naples at the time and that she is recovering at home after being treated in the hospital. Italian media previously reported that Moric had tried to commit suicide in 2009 after taking an overdose.</s>

The passage discusses the anticipation of the British public for the arrival of the second child of Kate and William. A poll shows that Diana is the favorite name for a girl, with Alice and Charlotte as other popular choices. For a boy, James and Alexander are the top preferences. Many people hope for a girl, with only a small percentage wanting a younger brother for George. The public also supports William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.</s>

A suicide bomber killed 17 people and wounded 64 others, including an Afghan lawmaker, during a protest in eastern Afghanistan. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other group has claimed the attack. The protesters were en route to a larger rally against the provincial governor.</s>

Dani Alves, a Brazilian right-back, is likely to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. He has had a successful seven-year tenure with the team, winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League titles. However, the 31-year-old player could not agree on a new deal with the club, leading to his departure from the Nou Camp this summer. Alves' agent and ex-wife, Dinorah Santana, announced at a press conference that her client had turned down a three-year contract extension with a 60% participation requirement in matches. She stated that the negotiations are over and that it is surprising that Barcelona has not considered renewing Dani's contract by April.</s>

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old football player, has urged Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Argentinian team Boca Juniors. Osvaldo believes that Pirlo and Totti would be a good fit for the team and would be loved by the fans.</s>

The passage describes an 18-year-old jockey, Lewis Ferguson, who had a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse during a race at Wincanton. Despite the fall, he only suffered a cut on his nose and was back riding out the next day. Ferguson's fall has become an internet sensation, and he jokes about considering a gymnastics career after racing.</s>

The passage discusses the release of the Avengers: Age of Ultron movie and its impact on England flanker James Haskell. Haskell, the London Wasps captain, posted a photo on Instagram dressed as Robert Downey Jr.'s character, Iron Man. The passage also highlights Haskell's rugby career, including his time with Stade Francais, Ricoh Black Rams, and Highlanders, as well as his return to Wasps in 2012 and surpassing 100 appearances for the club.</s>

The wide leg trouser is a prominent SS15 trend, offering an alternative to skinny jeans. This style has made a comeback since the 1970s and can be achieved in various materials such as denim. To wear this look confidently, pair it with high heels and a simple top. Denim is considered the easiest way to achieve this trend, with brands like Gucci and Topshop offering their versions. Wide leg trousers can also be dressed up for an evening look with options from Celine and Stella McCartney.</s>

The University of Michigan decided to proceed with a screening of the film "American Sniper" despite objections from some students. Over 200 students signed a petition asking the school not to show the movie as part of UMix, a series of social events. Some students believed the movie's depiction of the Iraq war reflected negatively on the Middle East. However, there was a backlash, and a counter-petition asked school officials to reconsider. The university's vice president for student life stated that canceling the movie was a mistake and that the show would go on, emphasizing the university's value for freedom of expression and students' right to make their own choices. UMix will offer a screening of the family-friendly "Paddington" for those who would rather not attend "American Sniper."</s>

Two French tourists allegedly tried to set a quokka on fire using an aerosol spray and a lighter on Rottnest Island, Western Australia. The quokka survived but was singed by the flame. The suspects, aged 18 and 24, were evicted from the island, charged with animal cruelty, and will appear in court on April 17.</s>

102-year-old dancer Alice Barker, who performed at the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar in the 1930s and 1940s, had never seen footage of herself dancing. With the help of filmmakers and Jazz-on-Film.com's Mark Cantor, Barker watched "soundies" (early music videos) at her nursing home, expressing delight at seeing herself dance for the first time.</s>

The passage discusses the decline of people washing their own cars in Britain, with new figures showing that a third of men have never washed their own car and 75% of women never wash their own car. Factors contributing to this decline include the rise of hand car washes, more shops opening on Sundays, and larger vehicles making it more difficult to clean. People are more likely to wash their cars during holidays, but some cities and car brands have higher rates of car washing than others.</s>

Martin Skrtel praises Steven Gerrard's impact on him since joining Liverpool in 2008 but believes the team can overcome the challenge of replacing him. Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa and aims to end his Liverpool career by making the final against Arsenal. Skrtel considers Gerrard one of the best players in the world and credits him for helping him settle at the club. Despite Gerrard's departure, Skrtel believes Liverpool have potential replacements and will work as a team.</s>

At the age of 75, Jack Nicklaus achieved a hole in one during the Par-3 contest at Augusta National, playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. This was Nicklaus' first ace on the hallowed turf of Augusta. The day saw five hole-in-ones, tying the record from 2002. Camilo Villegas also achieved two aces but lost to Kevin Streelman in a play-off. Nicklaus, a six-time Masters winner, is one of five men to complete the career grand slam.</s>

Tornado sirens were sounded in Kansas as several storms brought reports of twisters. A tornado was spotted near Goddard, moving northeast and posing potential risks to other communities. CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers warned of nighttime tornadoes being the most deadly and dangerous. Other tornado sightings were reported in southwestern Kansas. Kansas was not the only state affected, as a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage, flooding, and fallen trees. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes.</s>

An Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, pleaded not guilty to a charge of second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris, whom he intended to subdue with a taser. The judge granted Bates permission to go on a family vacation to the Bahamas, which sparked criticism from Harris's family. Bates' preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. The family's lawyer claims Bates wasn't qualified to be on the force but received preferential treatment due to donations and friendship with the sheriff. The Tulsa County Sheriff's Office denies these allegations.</s>

Conor McGregor, a 26-year-old Irish fighter, is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11. He has unveiled a new tiger tattoo on his stomach and a gorilla eating a heart tattoo on his chest. McGregor claims to have greater motivation to win the title than Aldo has to defend it for the eighth time. The two fighters have a tense relationship, and at the end of March, McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin.</s>

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott skolled a beer at an Australian rules function, drawing criticism from anti-drinking campaigners who claim he is glorifying binge drinking and associating being a man with drinking alcohol. Cultural studies professor Julie Robert argues that Abbott's actions set up a culture where drinking is about speed and quantity rather than socializing with friends. Critics argue that the Prime Minister should be setting an example of responsible drinking practices.</s>

Indiana has experienced a significant increase in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases tied to Scott County. This outbreak is among intravenous drug users and primarily involves the use of the high-powered painkiller Opana. In response, Governor Mike Pence approved a short-term needle exchange program, which has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants. However, the future of the program and legislation allowing needle-exchange programs in other counties is uncertain, as Pence opposes needle exchanges as an anti-drug policy.</s>

An Arsenal fan tested his girlfriend Saskia on her knowledge of the football club by making her take an exam with multiple choice questions, tables, and a section for her to explain her answers. Saskia scored 87%, impressing her boyfriend and avoiding being dumped. She received praise from fellow football fans for her knowledge and creative answers. Some people felt the boyfriend took things too far, while others were inspired to test their own partners.</s>

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former Medellin cartel member, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years after fleeing Colombia in the 1980s. In exchange for his cooperation, he was promised US citizenship, which has not been granted. After retiring due to declining health, Toro faces deportation and fears for his life if sent back to Colombia. His information helped in the prosecution of drug lords Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his valuable service, the DEA has refused to help Toro with his citizenship, leaving him in legal limbo and unable to collect social security benefits.</s>

A 14-year-old girl in India set herself on fire after being allegedly gang-raped by five men from her village and being told by her family to keep quiet about the attack. She is now fighting for her life in Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital with 70% burns. The incident has drawn attention to the heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, following the ban of a documentary about the gang rape and murder of an Indian student in Delhi. Recent attacks in India have resulted in street protests, with many calling for more protection for women.</s>

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal dreams of beating rivals Manchester City in Sunday's derby at Old Trafford but will have to do so without Robin van Persie, who is ruled out due to not being fit enough to play. Van Gaal is preparing his team for the match, with players training in the sunshine ahead of the game. A win against City would put United in a strong position in the table and increase their chances of qualifying for the top four. Van Gaal acknowledges the challenge that City will pose to his team and emphasizes the importance of controlling aggression during the match.</s>

Arsenal and Liverpool fans staged a protest against rising ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. The protest was sparked by the £5.14 billion TV rights deal and the £64 starting ticket price for the match. Fans displayed banners both inside and outside the stadium, expressing their dissatisfaction with the increasing costs of following their clubs. Supporters from various fan groups organized the event, calling ticket prices "extortionate" and urging for tangible reductions in line with working-class earnings to prevent a potential loss of future fans.</s>

A newborn baby named Star was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition, shortly after birth. After an unsuccessful attempt to unblock her bile ducts, Star's parents were informed that she would need a liver transplant to survive. Neither of her parents were suitable matches, but her maternal aunt, Shanell, volunteered to give part of her liver. The transplant was successful, and Star has since made a good recovery, thanks to her aunt's selfless act.</s>

In Audi's football challenge, Chelsea players Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake competed against Loic Remy and Willian in various rounds, including shooting balls into a car's boot and playing football over a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 Plus. Hazard and Ake won the first two rounds, but Remy and Willian redeemed themselves by winning the final challenge. Willian accidentally smashed the wing mirror off one of the Audi cars during the challenge.</s>

A former Fortune 500 executive, Robert Dellinger, caused a highway crash in December 2013 that killed a Vermont couple, Amanda Murphy and Jason Timmons, and their unborn baby. Dellinger initially claimed he was attempting suicide when he drove his pickup truck at over 100mph across a median and collided with an oncoming SUV. During his sentencing, Dellinger denied being suicidal. He pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and faces 12 to 24 years in prison. Dellinger's defense argued that he was suffering from Ambien withdrawal, a psychiatric drug overdose, Prozac, and advanced symptoms of multiple sclerosis at the time of the crash.</s>

Lacey Spears, a woman from Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for poisoning her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, with salt. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed his desire for her to be placed in general population, hoping she would not survive. Spears was found guilty of second-degree murder and showed no emotion during her sentencing. The judge stated that she suffers from a mental illness, and prosecutors argued that she poisoned her son for attention. Spears' lawyer plans to appeal the verdict, claiming she is innocent and blaming the hospital for negligence.</s>

The passage discusses the arrival of an improved influenza vaccine in Australia, which includes protection against new strains H3N2 and B/Phuket. The vaccine stocks are arriving a month later than expected due to these additions. The decision to include these strains was made after a spike in flu-related deaths in the northern hemisphere, as the previous vaccine was not a good match against them. High-risk groups will be able to access free, government-funded flu shots from April 20. Dr. Alan Hampson, who chairs the influenza specialist group, recommends that everyone should get the vaccine, as it also provides protection against H1N1. He hopes that the new vaccine will prevent more deaths per capita than the previous one.</s>

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are facing criticism from National Geographic magazine and potential budget cuts that could threaten the historic site's management. The tomb, located in Springfield, Illinois, is facing financial challenges as the state faces a crisis and the governor has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages the site. The site has also been criticized for having "all the historical character of an office lobby" and its "incongruous art deco style." Despite these challenges, the tomb has undergone recent repairs and renovations, leaving it in excellent physical condition.</s>

The passage discusses the resurgence of nineties and noughties fashion trends, highlighting some of the worst offenders. These trends include chokers, bucket hats, camouflage print, taking it to the max with designer prints and double denim, UGG boots, daisy dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outfits, and harem trousers. The passage showcases how celebrities and fashion fans are embracing these trends, despite some being considered horrific by those who wore them originally.</s>

In a busy week for trending stories, highlights include four rainbows appearing in the New York sky after heavy rain, a crackdown on exotic dancers at wakes in rural China, the Kardashians inspiring a lip-plumping trend called the #KylieJennerChallenge, 102-year-old Alice Barker's prom-posal controversy, Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast', Johnny Depp's transformation in 'Black Mass' trailer, a creative pregnancy announcement referencing 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air', and a military dad's original photobomb.</s>

The Miami Open celebrated two milestones as Serena Williams achieved her 700th career victory and advanced to the semi-finals, while Andy Murray reached his 500th win. Williams overcame Germany's Sabine Lisicki in a three-set match but was unable to face her sister Venus. Instead, she will face Romania's Simona Halep for a chance to reach the final.</s>

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani figurehead for humanism, love, and tolerance, was shot dead at her cafe in Karachi after leading a discussion group on the topic of disappearances in Baluchistan. Her exuberant exercise of free speech made her stand out nationwide, and her death has broken hearts across the country. No one has claimed responsibility for her shooting, and police have not named any motive. Mahmud's cafe, known as T2F, was a magnet for those seeking secular wisdom and a place for freedom of thought.</s>

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu healer, has lived as a refugee in India's only Muslim-majority state, Jammu and Kashmir, for 70 years. Denied citizenship rights, he and thousands of West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) have been unable to own property or vote in state elections. However, after Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party won a share of power in the state, there is hope that the refugee status that has plagued them for decades may be shed. The WPRs' continuing refugee status has trapped generations in abject poverty, as they are denied residential rights, including the right to buy land, vote in state polls, or work in the state government. The Bharatiya Janata Party is expected to champion the refugees' cause, potentially improving their conditions.</s>

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a move to Premier League leaders Chelsea this summer. The club has reportedly made an offer of around £4 million for the Japanese international. Chelsea plans to loan Muto to partner club Vitesse Arnhem next season. However, the 22-year-old is keen to join a club where he will play regularly and develop his potential. Muto's former coach, Ranko Popovic, believes Muto has great potential and could be a big hit at Stamford Bridge. Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho is aware of the Japanese player but has refrained from commenting further on the transfer.</s>

The passage discusses the change in Australia's policy of selecting their best players regardless of where they play, which contrasts with England's policy of not selecting players based on their overseas performance. The author argues that England should follow Australia's example and allow coach Stuart Lancaster to pick the best players, even if they play for clubs like Toulon. The passage highlights the benefits of having the best possible squad for a home World Cup and emphasizes that players should not be penalized for choosing to play overseas.</s>

The passage discusses the development of Greenstone, a device created by Open Garden to strengthen off-the-grid networks for the Firechat app, which allows users to send messages without an internet or mobile signal. Firechat uses a feature called the Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) in Apple's iOS 7 and a similar feature in Android that works over Bluetooth. MCF creates a wireless mesh network connecting phones within Bluetooth or Wi-Fi direct range, enabling message transmission between nodes. Greenstone acts as a beacon or booster to help messages move around these networks more easily. The app has chatrooms for "everyone" and "nearby" options, allowing users to send messages securely and anonymously. Greenstone is still under development and currently works with Firechat at a range of around 20ft (6 meters).</s>

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle aims to eradicate negativity surrounding the word "fat" by embracing it as a body-positive description of her own physique. During a TED talk, she revealed that she also calls herself "short" and "wife," noting that each of these words is an honest description of what she is. Lillian insists that "fat" does not have to be used as a synonym for "ugly" and believes that exposure to body diversity can lead to greater acceptance and preference for different body types. Through her burlesque performances, she aims to expose her audiences to a "fat" body in a positive, glamorous way, challenging societal norms of desirability.</s>

Theo Walcott and seven Arsenal teammates, including runway model Olga Sherer, participated in a photoshoot for Paris' oldest fashion house, Lanvin, which is the club's official tailor since 2013. Walcott has been mostly on the bench this season, appearing in only 17 of Arsenal's 33 Premier League games. The team will wear similar attire in their FA Cup final match against Aston Villa on May 30th.</s>

A collection of props and puppets from over 50 productions, created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker, will be auctioned off on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on propstore.com. The collection is worth an estimated $746,100, with some items expected to fetch more than $40,000. Items from various films, including Men in Black, Batman Forever, and How the Grinch Stole Christmas, will be sold to the highest bidder.</s>

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, tragically fell to his death while skiing with his family in the French Alps. The boy became separated from his mother and headed into dense woodland, where he fell over a 164ft drop. Footprints in the snow led police to his body. Carwyn's family described him as a daring, outgoing, and determined youngster with a handsome smile that lit up any room. The family expressed their devastation and utter heartbreak over the loss of their beloved son.</s>

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old schoolgirl from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia after being bullied for her weight and feeling pressured to be a size zero. She began hiding food, lying about eating, and surviving on just one piece of fruit a day. Her health deteriorated to the point where she collapsed and was put on a heart machine. After spending a week in the hospital, Laura received support from eating disorder organizations and started her recovery. She is now working with eating disorder teams and child and adolescent mental health services, and her body image and confidence have improved, allowing her to reach the semi-finals of Miss Teen GB, a competition that aims to promote positive and confidence-building experiences for young girls, away from size zero stereotypes.</s>

Liverpool supporters expressed their desire for Raheem Sterling to remain at the club during the unveiling of the new home kit at Anfield. The kit, designed by New Balance, is part of a record-breaking £300 million four-year deal. Sterling, who recently rejected a £100,000-a-week contract, was applauded when a fan urged him to stay with the team. Teammates Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet also unveiled the new kit, and the players discussed their excitement for the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa.</s>

The largest high-definition map of dark matter has been produced by the University of Manchester, allowing a 3D view of dark matter across one-eighth of the night sky. This map will enable astronomers to study how galaxies formed in the universe. The map was created using data captured by the Dark Energy Camera, a 570-megapixel imaging device used for the Dark Energy Survey. The project aims to map 12.5% of the sky over five years, with the ultimate goal of revealing the nature of dark energy.</s>

Manchester United has made an official approach to sign 21-year-old PSV Eindhoven star Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal keen to make him one of his first signings this summer. Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season and was named in van Gaal's 23-man World Cup squad last year as Holland finished third in Brazil. PSV's technical director, Marcel Brands, has confirmed that there has been contact with Manchester United, Paris Saint-Germain, and a third big European club, with bigger amounts of money being discussed this time compared to last summer's £15 million offer from Tottenham.</s>

Chelsea's youth team defeated Manchester City's young side 3-1 in the Academy Stadium. Tammy Abraham scored a fierce drive and two volleys, while Dominic Solanke added a third goal. Isaac Buckley-Ricketts scored for Manchester City. Chelsea's players, such as Tammy Abraham, Dominic Solanke, and Jake Clarke-Salter, performed well, while Manchester City's Kean Bryan and Isaac Buckley-Ricketts made significant contributions to the game.</s>

Presidential candidate Marco Rubio believes people are born with a sexual preference but insists that state legislators should decide whether or not to allow gay marriage. He does not think same-sex marriage is a constitutional right and believes that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. Rubio stated that if a family member or staffer he cared for decided to have a same-sex wedding, he would attend even if he disagreed with their decision.</s>

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish and Latvian couple, embarked on a dream to discover different parts of the world by bicycle. After quitting their restaurant jobs in Manchester, they began their open-ended odyssey on the road, covering almost 7,000 miles through 16 countries in 356 days. They live frugally, spending less than three euros each per day, and rely on free accommodation and their bicycles for transportation. Their main expense is food, which consists of pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal fruits, and vegetables. They started in London and worked their way through Europe, with plans to continue into Asia and the Americas.</s>

A couple from Texas, who had their wedding in 2012, is suing James Evans, the owner of Premiere Photos, for allegedly printing racial slurs on the bottom of their photo booth snapshots. The couple hired attorney Cathy Hale, who said that the bride's sister waited to tell them about the incident to not ruin their special day. Evans denies the allegations and claims there is no evidence linking his company to the offensive caption. The couple is seeking an apology, and if they don't reach an agreement, the case is set for trial in July.</s>

England full-back Mike Brown is adopting a cautious approach to his recovery from a concussion setback, unsure of when he will return to play for Harlequins. Brown pulled out of a match against Saracens last weekend and is determined not to suffer an extended break. He is being careful not to get into a situation like Ireland's Johnny Sexton, who was stood down for 12 weeks due to concussion. George North, a Northampton wing, has been advised by leading medics not to play again this season after suffering four quick-fire concussions.</s>

The passage suggests that smartphone use and increased internet connectivity may be contributing to a decline in the frequency of sexual activity among couples in the UK. According to research by Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, the average heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, compared to four times a month in 2000 and five times a month in 1990. Factors such as more people living alone and the blurring of boundaries between work, home, and personal life have also been proposed as possible explanations for the decline in sexual activity.</s>

Tibetan Mastiffs, once highly sought-after and commanding prices up to £1.2 million, are now facing a decline in popularity in China. This decline is partly due to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which has reduced the practice of giving the dogs as gifts to influence officials' decisions. Additionally, recent bans on owning dogs weighing over 50 kg in several Chinese cities have impacted the breed's popularity. As a result, many Tibetan Mastiffs are being sent to slaughterhouses, where their meat is used in cheap hotpots, and their skin for leather belts. Animal-welfare workers have rescued groups of the dogs being transported to slaughterhouses, with some in cramped cages and suffering from broken bones. The decline in the Mastiff market has also led to poor-quality dogs being offloaded to abattoirs by unscrupulous breeders.</s>

A survey in Paris found that every woman surveyed had experienced sexual harassment on public transport, with half of them being assaulted before the age of 18. The poll led to calls for a campaign to address sexist and threatening behavior on buses and trains. The report highlighted that these attacks limit women's freedom and called for better education and awareness to combat the issue.</s>

Direct Line, a Leeds-based company, launched a competition called #EverydayFix, where groups designed products to address common everyday emergencies. The top ten emergencies were identified through a survey, and three products were shortlisted: Snooze, a silent alarm clock that connects with your phone; Forget Me Lock, a device that attaches to a key and indicates whether a door is locked or open; and Nipper, a portable phone charger that uses household batteries. People can vote for their favorite product on Twitter, and the winner will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign and potentially developed into an actual product.</s>

A police crime commissioner, Vera Baird, is under investigation for awarding over £500,000 of taxpayers' money to a charity she co-runs with the force's chief, Sue Sim. The charity, Victims First Northumbria, supports crime victims in the area. Critics accuse Baird and Sim of a conflict of interest, and the Ministry of Justice is investigating the situation.</s>

Five individuals were involved in a horrific assault on a 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce, who was beaten, tied to a chair, and covered in offensive tattoos. The ringleader, Corry 'Corey' Campbell, believed Valecce had hurt his cat, Pebbles, and took revenge. Three people have been sent to prison, and two are awaiting sentencing. The incident occurred in the basement of Campbell's mother's house and was filmed by the attackers. Valecce suffered severe injuries and has since had the tattoos removed.</s>
